Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th inst., and with reference to the quarterly statements for the Crookedwood Boarding School, transmitted to the Department of Interior, I point out that because the aggregate maximum number of pupils for the Wesleyan Boarding School at Crookedwood, Neville and Five Hills, for whom the per capita grant has been provided and authorized is 45, it has only been possible to allow at Crookedwood for 42 during the quarter referred to.

The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa

The Indian Commissioner informs us that the reason why the full amount granted to the Board School for the fifth quarter has not been paid in full is because the school has overrun the average attendance for which an appropriation has been made, but that he has written to provide further means if possible so that the additional number of children may be paid for.

I am instructed to write to you to urge the same thing. In the past two years this school has had an attendance larger than the number provided for in the estimates and payment in full has always been made until now. When I wrote to you on the 16th February, 1870, about the estimates for the current year, I pointed out that the average attendance at that time was 48.
Winnipeg,

Sir,

As you were informed, the temporary mission was not before you at the time when the estimates were being prepared, but this accident we hope does not hinder it impossible to pay now the grant that has been so well earned. It is but $60 per capita at the best, and thus it seems to act down without action (for it practically amounts to that since the larger grants had been paid during previous quarters) and the balance left after personally the cost of carrying on the school, is not to be thought of. We by this letter to urge our representations to them of the Commissioners, and to urge that the necessary amount of money be provided.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Andrew B. Baird

Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of 2nd inst: enclosing, for report, various requests made by the Presbyterian Church, to enable it to carry on its educational work among the Indians during the fiscal year 1891-'92, embodied in a letter from the Rev. A. B. Baird, and in reply to report as follows:

1st. $1700.00 for completion of school building at Crowstand.

In connection with this it is observed that Mr. Baird states that the Supt. General promised a grant of $1000.00 and that it is found that the new building will cost $2700.00, also that the Church has already expended $2700.00 in the erection of buildings for this school. This being so, the additional grant of $1700.00 if allowed, will represent a contribution, on the part of the Department, of one half the cost of buildings, or the proportion of the cost of buildings for schools of this class, which I have recommended in my suggestions for the government.

The Deputy of the

Supt. Gen'l of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
government of Indian schools, to be borne by the Department, and I would therefore beg to recommend the grant to its favourable consideration.

2nd. Birtle for new building and purchase of land in connection $10,000.00. This sum I have included in my Estimates, because, although to recommend a grant for more than half the buildings would be inconsistent with the rule hereinabove referred to, I am led to believe there is some special understanding with regard to this school, between the Superintendent General and the Church.

3rd. Increase of number of pupils to whom per capita grant is given in the Industrial Schools so as to make the number equal to the probable average attendance, for Crowstand, 75; Round Lake, 55; Muscowetung or Lake's End, 40; File Hills, 30; Birtle, 30; Portage la Prairie, 12; Edmonton, 12.

I have placed opposite the numbers asked for by the Church, those which I think provision should be made for.

With regard to this, it may be observed that these schools are not Industrial, but belong to the class of Boarding schools on or contiguous to Reserves.

As Department is aware, fault has had to be found
with overcrowding at Crowstand school, and it is not considered that including the new building, there will be proper accommodation for more than 50 pupils, therefore I am unable to recommend that more than that number be provided for in the estimates.

It has to be remembered too that the substitution of these schools for Day schools on Reserves is a measure still in the tentative stage, and that the Department can not be expected to at once provide for the boarding of all the children who could be secured.

It seems moreover that in calculating upon the probable attendance at these Boarding schools, sufficient allowance has not been made for the necessity, and difficulties in the way of filling the Industrial School, about to be opened in this neighborhood.

Should this school prove the success which is hoped, the Department would doubtless see fit to enlarge its accommodation, and it would be far better policy to direct our efforts to getting as many children as possible into it, where they would enjoy, among other superior advantages, that of being at a greater distance from their Reserves, than would be the case were they at the Boarding schools.

4th. That the per capita grant be increased from $60 per annum to at least $75.

With regard to this I beg to inform the Department that in a letter addressed to me by the Rev. Mr. Baird, on 7th inst.: he requested permission to withdraw this request.
request, and to substitute the following, viz:

(a) That the Birtle and Crowstand schools be raised from the rank of schools receiving $60 per caput, to that of schools receiving $100 per caput, as is the case with the schools at Elkhorn, St. Paul's &c., and along with this, of course, that they be required to meet the conditions required of such schools.

(b) That our other schools which receive now $60 per caput, namely, Lake's End (i.e., Muscowetung's), Round Lake and File Hills, receive, in addition, a grant towards the payment of Teacher's salary, to the amount of $300 per annum, for any number of pupils under 25, and an addition $300 if the number exceeds 25.

The object in making this change of request is said to be to enable the proposed increase to follow the lines along which the Department is already acting, and so avoid the establishment of an altogether distinct class of schools.

With regard to the original and alternative proposition, I beg to remark that I am unable to recommend that the Birtle and Crowstand schools be raised to the rank of those receiving a per caput grant of $100.

The force of the argument that there is too great a difference between the $60 and the $100 grant cannot be admitted, because the first cost of instituting the branches of trade instruction required, in return for the higher grant, seems to be lost sight of, also that much more is exacted in other directions, such as better clothing and a larger staff of Teachers.
The intention in giving a grant of $300 towards the salary, as proposed in my suggestions already referred to, was to provide for the payment of tuition given to day scholars, for whom the boarders' per capita grant made no provision, and I can not resist the feeling that it would have been well to have limited the assistance to boarding schools off Reserves to $60 because all the Denominations now have Industrial schools, to which children can be sent for higher education, nor do I see why the Department should bear the whole cost of the maintenance of the Boarding schools.

Since however the Superintendent General has decided that the grant for boarders in schools on Reserves where day scholars attend shall be $60 per annum, and the fixed salary for the Teacher shall be $300 in addition, it does seem that in order to preserve equality of treatment between such schools and Boarding schools off the Reserves receiving the $60 but no Teacher's salary, some new plan has to be devised. After much consideration I have decided to suggest, with a view to meeting the altered circumstances, the following change of my suggestions as already laid before the Department, viz: that all Boarding schools on or adjacent to Reserves receive the $60 grant.

That for payment of Teacher's salary the per capita grant of $12 as provided under the old Orders-in-Council, be reverted to, and that this be given irrespective of the $60, whether for boarders or day scholars attending boarding schools.
This would do away with the objection that the fewer the boarders the larger the per capita grant proportionately becomes through the allowance of the fixed Teacher's salary of $300 per annum.

The following will show the application of the comparative methods of payment.

The second paragraph of the Indian Commissioner's letter of the 31st ultimo is by no means clear, and in order to understand what he wishes to convey to the Department it is necessary to refer to the letter from the Rev. Dr. Baird.

The facts appear to be that the Presbyterian Church finished, at its own cost, one school building at Crowfoot for which the sum of $2700.00 was expended. This building did not afford the necessary accommodation, and the Superintendent General seems to have promised Dr. Baird that

To the Deputy Minister of Indian Affairs
that $1,000 would be provided by the Department toward the construction of the new building. It appears now however, that this new building which was originally intended to be two stories in height would not afford the accommodation necessary owing to the increase in the number of pupils, and Dr. Reid states that the church committee were induced by officers of the Indian Dept. and by the necessity to add another story to the building, which cost, when finished, $2,700. (the same amount as the original cost) and Dr. Reid now wishes to receive the sum promised him by the Committee $1,000 and a further grant of $700 in all $2,700 and thus the cost of both buildings will be borne in equal proportions by the Government and the Church authorities.

Memorandum

The undersigned begs to submit, herewith, a letter from the Rev. Andrew B. Baird, one of the Joint Commissioners of the Synod of the Presbyterian Church in Manitoba and the North West Territories, submitting a copy of a communication made by him to the Indian Commissioner at Regina, in which he makes certain suggestions in respect to additional assistance which it is considered by the Presbyterian Church should be given them to enable them to carry on the educational work with Honourable Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
which that Church has charged itself among the Indians, during the next fiscal year.

The undersigned also submits herewith, a letter of the 31st ultimo from the Indian Commissioner, reporting upon the application made by the Presbyterian Church for additional grants through Mr. Baird; first, with regard to the $7500 asked for completion of the school building at Crow's Head, Coles Reserve, Treaty 4, the Rev. Mr. Baird states that it will cost $17,000 in addition to the $10,000 which he says the Superintendent General promised him towards the completion of the building and that the Church has already expended $2,500 on the buildings at that point. He, therefore, applies that this amount of $7,500 be estimated for and paid by the Department.
Department to equalize the cost of the buildings between the Church and the Department when the buildings are completed being $2,700 each, and the total amount to the gross sum of $5,400.

The undersigned concurs in the view of the Indian Commissioner, that this proposition is a fair one, and should be acceded to by the Department.

The second proposal made by Mr. Board is, that a new building for the Boarding School at Birle be erected and land purchased in connection therewith, at a cost of $10,000. The Indian Commissioner states that he had included this sum, for the above purpose, in his estimates, inasmuch as he had been informed that there was some special understanding respecting the schools between the
The Superintendent General and the Presbyterian Church.

The third proposition made by Mr. Baird is that the number of pupils at the various Boarding schools to whom a per capita grant is given be increased so as to make the number admissible there to equal to the probable average attendance.

The Indian Commissioner recommends in the case of all Boarding schools, excepting two, namely those at Lake's End (formerly Muscowpetung) and Birtle (which are recommended both by Mr. Baird and by the Commissioner) for 40 and 30 pupils respectively, a reduction in the number of pupils asked for. For instance: at Crow Island Mr. Baird asks for 75, and Mr. Reid recommends 50. At Round Lake, Mr. Baird asks for 65, Mr. Reid recommends 42.
At File Hills Mr. Baird asks for 30, Mr. Reid recommends 12.
At Fortage Laprairie Mr. Baird asks for 12, Mr. Reid recommends 10.
At Edmonton Mr. Baird asks for 12, Mr. Reid recommends 10.

Mr. Reid bases his recommendations on the amount of accommodation that can properly be given at the several institutions and which he thinks would be sufficient for the numbers recommended by Mr. Baird, and that the reduced numbers are as large as the buildings will accommodate. The Indian Commissioner further states that the substitution of Boarding schools for Day schools is still in the tentative stage, and the Department should not be expected, therefore, to at once provide for the boarding of all children who could be secured.

With
With regard to the foregoing reasons given by Mr. Reed for not allowing the number of pupils asked for by Mr. Baird, the undersigned considers that his first reason is a sound one; for, as alleged by him, there is not sufficient accommodation for the additional pupils asked for by Mr. Baird, permission to increase the number of resident pupils to that applied for by Mr. Baird should not certainly be granted; but he can not agree with the second reason therefore, as the undersigned holds that the Department should be prepared to provide for as many Indian children at the Boarding schools as can be obtained, and as are suitable for being received thereat.

The third reason given by Mr. Reed for not allowing a greater number at the various Boarding schools is probably also...
also worthy of consideration, namely, that the Presbyterian authorities have not in their calculations as to the probable attendance at the Boarding schools, taken into account the recent establishment of the Industrial school at Regina, in regard to which Mr. Reed very properly remarks that, if it should prove a success, the accommodation thereof should be enlarged, and the efforts of the Department directed to obtain as many children as possible for it.

The fourth proposition made by Mr. Baird is, that the per capita grant at the Boarding schools at Berilo and Elwoodland be increased from $60 to $100 per annum, the rate paid at the schools at St. Paul's, Elkboro, &c., and that the other Boarding schools in receipt of $60 per caput, namely, those
those at Lake's End, Round Lake, and Ojib Hills, receive in addition $300 per annum each towards the teacher's salary, for any number of pupils under 25 and an additional $300 if the number exceeds 25. In connection with this proposition the Indian Commissioner remarks that he is unable to recommend that the schools at Birch and Crowstand be put upon the same footing as regards capitation allowance, as the schools at Elk Horn, St. Paul's, etc., inasmuch as at this latter class of schools branches of instruction in trade are required and better clothing and a larger staff of teachers than are expected at schools such as that at Birch and Crowstand. In connection with the two systems last referred to, the Indian Commissioner submits a comparative statement, and according to the method now recommended by him for adoption, the amount that would be received at the various Boarding schools, whether on or off Reserves, both as regards per capita and salary allowance, would be dependent upon the number of pupils boarding thereat, as shown by the returns received from those schools.

Sir,

The Memorandum dated 8th June 1891, of the Superintendent General, with reference to the proposed grant to the Presbyterian Church of $500, as a contribution from the Government towards the establishment of the Boarding School at Crowfoot has been referred from Council to the Minister of Justice.

With reference to the statement in the Memorandum that the Presbyterian Church authorities have undertaken
undertaken to secure to the government, after patent to the title of the building has been issued to them, a joint interest in the ownership of the land on which the present buildings are located in consideration of the grant of $1000. The minister of justice directs me to refer you to the similar case of the late Chief Indian Orphanage at Monctonville. It appears that the object of your department in this case is the same as it was in the case of the grant made in aid of that institution.

Viz.:
Viz., to ensure that the property shall not, without the consent of the Superintendent General, be dedicated to other uses than those at present contemplated. If this be so the minister thinks that, unless some special reason to the contrary exists, the plan of securing this object which was adopted with reference to the Orphanage at Kenleyville had better be followed in this case, i.e., when the letters patent for the site of the building are issued a condition should be inserted in them providing that the lands shall not, without
without the consent of the Superintendent General, be issued for any purpose other than that of an Indian Boarding School.

Have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant containing the information that in the Estimates now before Parliament the number of pupils provided for at the Crowstand Boarding School has been reduced from thirty to twenty.

We have received this information with very great surprise and disappointment, and I am instructed by our Committee to protest strongly against the proposed reduction.

The grant for thirty pupils has been made for the last seven or eight years and there never has been the faintest suggestion that the Government did not think the money well expended. I need only now refer to the recently published report of the Department of Indian Affairs to show that in the opinion of the Inspector, Mr. Walsworth, the school is now being efficiently carried on, the staff intelligent and enthusiastic, the premises in good

The Indian Commissioner,
Regina.
good and orderly condition and the school enjoying the confidence of the Indians.

From the same report it appears that there are now forty-two children from the Swan River Agency in the Regina Industrial School. Of these, considerably over thirty have been pupils in the Crowstand Boarding School, from which it appears that it is not surpassed by any school in the Territories as a feeder for the Regina School.

We ask therefore, both in the interests of the Regina School and in the interests of the Crowstand School, the efficiency of which is seriously threatened, that the proposed reduction be not carried into effect.

I am instructed to say that the making of such reduction without longer notice and without giving any reason, appears to the Committee in the light of a breach of faith; and assuming as we do that the reduction has not been made at your suggestion, we ask you to co-operate with us by writing to the Department at Ottawa and giving such reasons as seem most forcible to you, to show why the proposed reduction should not be carried into effect.

I have the honour to be,

These improvements necessitate the tearing down of the greater part of the present buildings to make room for the new, so that for six or eight weeks it will be almost impossible to carry on school work, for the want of accommodation.

On the other hand this School on account of its isolation is an expensive one to keep up, so that we could not possibly afford to lose any part of the School grant.

Last year with the sanction of your Department, and without loss of grant, our children were allowed an outing at their homes for three weeks, the school supplying them with food and having oversight of them, seeing that they changed their soiled clothing regularly and attended Church on Sundays, as the School is on the Reserve, it is possible thus to see that all goes well with the children while they are having their vacation.

Dear Mr. Macquarrie,

Your letter is in hand, asking for a full statement of the recent misconduct of some of our pupils in conjunction with graduates from the Reserve. My reason for not speaking of this before was simply my distaste for putting the disgraceful affair on paper, and besides, I did not see that any good could come from so doing. If you had come up, I had intended telling you about it as I also intended telling Mr. Fraser at the next meeting of Presbytery. I do not want you to think I had any desire to conceal anything from the Committee which they had a right to know. I shall give you a full statement of the matter, and if any further investigation is needed, I shall be only too glad to give any assistance I can in the hope that the Committee may give me some assistance in preventing any recurrence of the matter.

To get at the beginning, it will be necessary to go back before my time. The fall before I came to Crowfoot, a number of the larger girls got out of their dormitories a number of times, meeting outside with several young men from the reserve. One of these was a graduate from our school. One was a graduate of Regina who was working here as farm instructor. The others were young married men from the Reserve. The leaders among the girls were a graduate of Regina who was working in the offices, and I think also an Indian girl who was living here as the adopted daughter of Mr. Gilmore. The young men who were concerned were forbidden to come on the school grounds again while Mr. Gilmore was here. His adopted daughter was sent to a friend at Suitulula and the other girl was discharged.

About a year after I came here, some of our own boys and girls succeeded in getting their windows open and getting out, the girls going to the boys dormitory and the boys going to the girls two or three times before they were caught. I employed such means as punishment and individual talks as I thought best to make them see the wrong they had done, and to keep them from doing it again. Since then, extra precautions have been taken to guard against any more trouble. The windows were blocked so that they could only rise a short distance, while the stops were actually nailed on. The doors also were kept locked. The Indian boy or girl, as
you may know, yields easily to any impulse or desire and from twelve upwards their passions are peculiarly strong. Thus, although we have seen many pleasing signs of improvement occasionally there would be outbreaks of a restless spirit in some. But on the whole we had much reason to be pleased with the apparent growth of a better moral tone. Last winter was perhaps the most free from anything disagreeable in the conduct of the girls and boys of such a period that I have known since coming here.

On April 1st, I sent home two of the larger boys to work preparatory to being discharged. They came to the school occasionally during the week and always on Sunday to Sunday School, and also to the evening meeting. Nothing suspicious could be noticed in any of their conduct.

About the middle of May, Mr. Blowett, the Indian Agent heard from a young Indian in his employ that something was wrong at the School. Next day, he was able to give me more particulars, and I at once proceeded to investigate. About the beginning of May, two young men from the reserve came to the school one night, and went up to the little girls dormitory, but when they found only little girls they went down again. They told this to the two boys who had just gone home from school, and started them thinking about doing the same. On Sunday night, May 5th, after all the staff were asleep, the two school boys from home accompanied by one of our boys from his own dormitory went up the fire escape to the girls window with a couple of knives and other things, which they passed to the girls, asking them to open the window. Either the girls could not, or would not do it, and the boys went away. The girls had tried or made pretense of trying to open the window. By Thursday following, the boys had got possession of a screwdriver and with it, loosened their own windows, and then passed it to the girls who also loosened theirs, so it would open easily. That night, four of our largest school boys went up to the girls dormitory and stayed for a time. Next night, Friday, May 10th, two boys from the reserve came and went up. One of these was the one who had been deep in the trouble in Mr. Gilmore's time and the same that had gone up to the little girls dormitory a few weeks before. The other was one of the boys I had sent home. This fellow fellow, Campbell Shingosch by name,
had a bottle of whisky in his pocket. He gave it to the girls and three
of them drank some of it. My own opinion is that this having the whisky there,
was merely an accident. He did not come up for the purpose of bringing
it or giving it to the girls. The other boy, Wallace Shingoose and Freddie
Goto the other boy whom I had sent home came the next night, Saturday, and went
up to the same dormitory. On Monday night following, four of the girls went
out and went around to the boys dormitory. The next day I discovered
the trouble and of course there was no more.

Now you will ask what has been done to the guilty parties.
Those who were pupils of the school including the two boys who had gone
home to the reserve, I punished. I wanted to get a heavy sentence passed
on the young fellow who had brought the whisky because he is a bad case,
but the Agent allowed him to go free on condition of his giving certain
information which led to the conviction of a white man in Massack who had for
a long time been supplying the Indians with whisky. I intend forbidding
him to come on the school property for a certain term. I would have liked
very much to have prosecuted for house breaking and make an example of him,
but dreaded the publicity it would give.

A couple of weeks ago, Mr. Graham, the Inspector of Indian
Agencies was here and I gave the whole account to him. I suppose it was
through his report it reached the Department.

Since this occurred, I have taken extra precautions to
prevent any more trouble and everything has been well lately.

In conclusion, let me repeat what I said before, that I
shall be pleased to give any necessary assistance to any investigation the
Committee may desire to make. I might say too, that Presbytery meets
here next week, and I shall lay the whole matter before Mr. Fraser, and the
other members of the Presbyterial Committee.

I thank you for your kind words of sympathy, and assure
you that none of you can know the sore disappointment this whole affair
has been to every member of our staff.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

The Committee appointed to enquire into the complaints made by the Indian Department against the Crostland Indian School, met in the Crostland School on Thursday, 8th August, 1907.

The letters from the Department on Indian Affairs were read and considered. In the opinion of the Committee, these letters should have been accompanied by a copy of the correspondence on which the Department based its complaints, and the names of some parties on whom the Committee appointed to investigate might have called for a statement of facts. Nothing of this kind having been done, the only parties to whom the Committee could apply for information, were the members of the School staff and the Indian Agent.

The Committee questioned every member of the staff who was within reach, (it being the season for holidays the Teacher and assistant Matron were absent) and had a conversation with the Indian Agent, and found that all were agreed as to the facts regarding the pupils and ex-pupils of the School going to the dormitories of the girls at night. The letter of Mr. McWhinney to the Secretary of the Synodical Indian Mission Committee, dated July 8th, copies of which were sent to the Secretary of the Department of Indian Affairs and the Secretary of the Foreign Mission Committee contains all the information the Committee has received, save the opinion expressed by the Indian Agent that such conduct had been going on from time to time during the Winter.

The Committee learned that a similar occurrence had taken place at the School before the appointment of Mr. McWhinney, the present Principal, and that one of the culprits in the present instance was involved in the former. The Committee learned further from various sources that like occurrences had happened at other Schools.

The Committee found that the Principal and every member of the staff were deeply grieved at the occurrence, and that the precautions taken to prevent such consisted in having the bedrooms of the members of the staff, (with the exception of that of the Principal who occupies a separate building) close to the dormitories of the boys and girls, the doors of the dormitories locked and the windows so blocked that they could not be raised high enough.
to permit a child to crawl through. Indeed, the only further precaution anyone could suggest, was to bar the windows with iron rods—a precaution precluded by the danger of fire. The success with which plots of various kinds have been planned and carried through, not only in Indian schools but in schools of all nationalities, compels the Committee to require further evidence before acquiescing in the statement of the latter from the Secretary of the Department of Indian Affairs, that the scandalous occurrences reflect seriously on the management of the Institution. The Committee regrets the occurrence exceedingly but does not think there is any blame attaching to the Principal or the staff who did advise him.

Complaints regarding Mr. McWhinney's method of bringing truant boys back to the school.

The Committee questioned Mr. McWhinney regarding the complaint that he had on one or two occasions in bringing truant boys back to the school, tied a rope to their arms, fastened the rope to his buggy and so compelled the boys to run behind the buggy; and was told that the following are the facts of the case:

The ringleader of the boys in the case out of which the complaint arose had run away from school four times last year and four or five times this year, and in each case he had induced one or more smaller boys to accompany him; that in the case referred to in the complaint, he had induced two to accompany him, one about his own size and one smaller; that Mr. & Mrs. McWhinney had followed them in the buggy and found them about eight miles from the school in company with the father of the two smaller boys; that Mr. McWhinney told the boys that they must go back with him, that he would take the smallest of them in the buggy, but, as there was not room for all in the buggy, the two larger boys would have to run behind; that arranged thus, all went well until, approaching a bluff half a mile from the starting point, Mr. McWhinney noticed that the boys were preparing to escape; that Mr. McWhinney then stepped, brought the boys to the buggy, tied a rope loosely round the arm of each and drew the rope...
over the back of the buggy and the seat, but did not fasten it to the buggy in any way; that Mr. McWhinney had not thought of thus tying the rope to the boys until he was face to face with the danger of the boys running away from him after he had found them and thus impairing the discipline of the School.

Mr. McWhinney admitted that he had asked Mr. Graham, (whether in the terms quoted in the letter of the Secretary of the Indian Department or not, he was not sure) as to what else he could do; but so far was he from refusing to take Mr. Graham's advice that the question was put with the desire of getting advice; that Mr. Graham did advise him not to tie the boys behind the buggy again, but to get the Indian Commissioner's permission to transfer the unruly boy to a distant school whence he could not get home; and that he, (Mr. McWhinney) had, acting on this advice, requested and got the Commissioner's permission to transfer the boy to another school, and that so far, the threat to do this had proved sufficient to keep the boy at school.

The Committee agree with the Indian Department that boys should not be brought back to any school tied with ropes, not because to do so is necessarily either cruel or wicked, but partly because to be seen bringing back boys tied thus is all but certain to lead to complaints of cruelty; and even more, because such a practice is in danger of degenerating into cruelty. Whether any particular case is actually wrong, must be determined by its circumstances. There is no doubt of the danger to which the boys would be exposed if the ropes had been made fast to the buggy as well as to the boys; but the ropes were not fastened to the buggy. The Committee can see no cruelty in making boys walk, or even run for reasonable distances. The distance these boys partly walked and partly ran behind Mr. McWhinney's buggy was between seven and eight miles; they could, and did help themselves along by clinging to the buggy; and Mr. McWhinney assured the Committee that the horses trotted slowly when they did trot and that they walked a considerable part of the way.
The Matron also gave the Committee the assurance that the boys were none the worse for their experiences behind Mr. McWhinney's buggy.

The Committee therefore believe that there was no wrong done on this occasion, and it is satisfied, and believes that the Department should be satisfied, with Mr. McWhinney's assurance that this method of securing the boys should not be tried again.

In conclusion, the Committee is convinced that the management of the Crowstand School has been on the whole excellent, and that the School is at present in very good condition.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

Convenor.

George Enkwayas has for at least two years given great trouble by his frequent attempts to run away from the School. In this, he has been encouraged by the sympathy of his parents, and the fact that they make much of him on his return to his home. I have talked both to the parents and to the boy, reasoning with them both as to the wrong and folly of such conduct. This boy's offense is always aggravated by his inducing one or more smaller boys to accompany him in his truancy, and thus exposing their health as well as his own to serious danger, they, often setting out at nights or on wet days, to go a distance of ten miles.

He ran away at least four times last year and four or five this year. The usual punishment inflicted was whipping. I tried to get his father to punish him but failed. Usually they would bring him back when he went home. I tried to persuade his father to some form of co-operation by which the boy's truancy might be stopped. Shortly afterwards, the boy ran away again, and as on other occasions, persuaded two boys, one about his own size and one smaller, to accompany him. I drove up to the Reserve to look for them. About eight miles from the School, I met the three boys accompanied by the father of the two smaller boys and at once told the boys that they must go back to school with me. As my wife was along with me, there was not room for all in the buggy, so I took the little boy into the buggy and told the two others that they must run behind. At first they were not tied in any way. After going a little distance, while drawing near a bluff, the boys showed unmistakable signs that they were going to make a break for liberty. I stopped and tied a rope loosely around one arm of each and threw the other end of the rope over the back of the buggy and over the seat. The rope was not tied to the buggy in any way. Thus we proceeded to the school, the horses walking or trotting slowly, so that the boys could follow without danger of hurting themselves in any way. Some of the Indians saw us going home and at once reported that the boys were tied to the buggy.
When Mr. Graham the Inspector was here a few weeks later, two Indians complained to him about the matter. He asked me for a statement of what had happened and I told him as it is set down here. He agreed that the boys should be punished and that discipline must be maintained, but advised me not to do anything like the foregoing again, as it might create dissatisfaction among the Indians. This, of course, was my own intention when I saw how the Indians felt. I asked him what method he would advise in dealing with such cases, and he advised me to request the Indian Commissioner to permit me to transfer the boy to some school at such a distance that the boy could not go home from it. I have done this, and the Commissioner has consented to the transference if it should be necessary to take this step. I told the boy and his father about this, and since then, there has been no trouble.

In answer to questions, Mr. McWhirter said, "The tying of ropes on the boys' arms and making them run behind the buggy was not intended as a punishment but as a preventative against running away. I asked the boys several times while on the way to school if they were tired, and one of them answered that they were not."

Dear Dr. Farquharson,

Your letter to hand, asking for a full statement of the recent misconduct of some of our pupils in conjunction with graduates from the Reserve. My reason for not speaking of this before was simply my distaste for putting the disgraceful affair on paper, and besides, I did not see that any good could come from so doing. If you had come up, I had intended telling you about it as I also intended telling Mr. Fraser at the next meeting of Presbytery. I do not want you to think I had any desire to conceal anything from the Committee which they had a right to know. I shall give you a full statement of the matter, and if any further investigation is needed, I shall be only too glad to give any assistance I can in the hope that the Committee may give me some assistance in preventing any recurrence of the matter.

To get at the beginning, it will be necessary to go back before my time. The fall before I came to Crowstand, a number of the larger girls got out of their dormitories a number of times, meeting outside with several young men from the reserve. One of these was a graduate from our school. One was a graduate of Regina who was working here as farm instructor. The others were young married men from the Reserve. The leaders among the girls were a graduate of Regina who was working in the school, and I think also an Indian girl who was living here as the adopted daughter of Mr. Gilmour.

The
The young men who were concerned were forbidden to come on the school grounds again while Mr. Gilmour was here. His adopted daughter was sent to a friend at Suitaiula and the other girl was discharged.

About a year after I came here, some of our own boys and girls succeeded in getting their windows open and getting out, the girls going to the boys dormitory and the boys going to the girls two or three times before they were caught. I employed such means as punishment and individual talks as I thought best to make them see the wrong they had done and to keep them from doing it again. Since then, extra precautions have been taken to guard against any more trouble. The windows were blocked so that they could only rise a short distance, while the stops were securely nailed on. The doors also were kept locked. The Indian boy or girl, as you may know, yields easily to any impulse or desire and from twelve upwards their passions are peculiarly strong. Thus, although we have seen many pleasing signs of improvement occasionally there would be outbreaks of a restless spirit in some. But on the whole we had much reason to be pleased with the apparent growth of a better moral tone. Last winter was perhaps the most free from anything disagreeable in the conduct of the girls and boys that I have known since coming here.

On April 1st, I sent home two of the larger boys to work preparatory to being discharged. They came to the school occasionally during the week and always on Sunday to the Sunday school, and also to the evening meeting. Nothing suspicious could be noticed in any of their conduct.

About
About the middle of May, Mr. Blewett, the Indian Agent, heard from a young Indian in his employ that something was wrong at the school. Next day, he was able to give me more particulars, and I at once proceeded to investigate. About the beginning of May, two young men from the reserve came to the school one night, and went up to the little girls dormitory, but when they found only little girls they went down again. They told this to the two boys who had just gone home from the school, and started them thinking about doing the same.

On Sunday night, May 5th, after all the staff were asleep, the two school boys from home accompanied by one of our boys from his own dormitory went up the fire escape to the girls window with a couple of knives and other things, which they passed to the girls, asking them to open the window. Either the girls could not, or would not do it, and the boys went away. The girls had tried or made pretence of trying to open the window.

By Thursday following, the boys had got possession of a screwdriver and with it loosened their own windows, and then passed it to the girls who also loosened theirs, so it would open easily. That night, four of our largest school boys went up to the girls dormitory and stayed for a time. Next night, Friday, May 10th, two boys from the reserve came and went up. One of these was the one who had been deep in the trouble in Mr. Gilmour's tame and the same that had gone up to the little girls dormitory a few weeks before. The other was one of the boys I had sent home. This older fellow, Campbell Shingosesh by name, had a bottle of whiskey in his pocket. He gave it to the girls and three of them drank some of it. My own opinion is that his having the whiskey there was
was merely an accident. He did not come up for the purpose of bringing it or giving it to the girls.

The other boy, Wallace Shingosch and Freddie Cote the other boy whom I had sent home came the next night, Saturday, and went up to the same dormitory. On Monday night following, four of the girls went out and went around to the boys dormitory. The next day I discovered the trouble and of course there was no more.

Now you will ask what has been done to the guilty parties. Those who were pupils of the school including the two boys who had gone home to the reserve, I punished. I wanted to get a heavy sentence passed on the young fellow who had brought the whiskey because he is a bad case, but the Agent allowed him to go free on condition of his giving certain information which led to the conviction of a white man in Kamsack who had for a long time been supplying the Indians with whiskey. I intend forbidding him to come on the school property for a certain term. I would have liked very much to have prosecuted him for house breaking and made an example of him, but dreaded the publicity it would give.

A couple of weeks ago, Mr. Graham, the Inspector of Indian agencies was here and I gave the whole account to him. I suppose it was through his report it reached the Department.

Since this occurred, I have taken extra precautions to prevent any more trouble and everything has been well lately.

In conclusion, let me repeat what I said before, that I shall be pleased to give any necessary assistance.
assistance to any investigation the Committee may desire to make. I might say, too, that Presbytery meets here next week, and I shall lay the whole matter before Mr. Fraser, and the other members of the Presbyterial Committee.

I thank you for your kind words of sympathy and assure you that none of you can know the sore disappointment this whole affair has been to every member of our staff.

Yours respectfully,

(Signed) W. McWhinney,
Principal.

Dear Sir,-

The report of the sub-committee appointed by the Indian Mission Committee of the Synods of Manitoba and Saskatchewan to visit the Crowstand School and to enquire about the management of the School, as requested by your Department, was considered at a Meeting of the Committee held recently and I was instructed to send you a copy of the report, which I now enclose, and to state that the Committee after full consideration of the said report, agreed on motion by Dr. Patrick and seconded by Dr. DuVal to adopt the report; hence the report becomes that of the full Committee.

I should explain that your kind letter enclosing the correspondence your Department had had about the matters complained of at Crowstand did not come into the Committee's hands until after its visit to Kennebec. We are none the less indebted to you however for your kindness in sending the copies of the correspondence. We sincerely trust that this will be satisfactory too.

Yours truly,

James Farquharson,
Secy. of Committee.
The Committee appointed to enquire into complaints made by the Indian Department against the Crowstand Indian School, met in the Crowstand School on Thursday, 8th August, 1907.

The letters from the Department of Indian Affairs were read and considered. In the opinion of the Committee, these letters should have been accompanied by a copy of the correspondence on which the Department based its complaints, and the names of some parties on whom the Committee appointed to investigate might have called for a statement of facts. Nothing of this kind having been done, the only parties to whom the Committee could apply for information, were the members of the School staff and the Indian Agent.

The Committee questioned every member of the staff who was within reach (it being the season for holidays the teacher and assistant Matron were absent) and had a conversation with the Indian Agent, and found that all were agreed as to the facts regarding the pupils and ex-pupils of the School going to the dormitories of the girls at night. The letter of Mr. McWhinney to the Secretary of the Synodical Indian Mission Committee, dated July 8th copies of which were sent to the Secretary of the Department of Indian Affairs and the Secretary of the Foreign Mission Committee, Toronto, contains all the information the Committee has received, save the opinion expressed by the Indian Agent that such conduct had been going on from time to time during the Winter.

The Committee learned that a similar occurrence had taken place at the School before the appointment of Mr. McWhinney, the present Principal, and that one of the culprits in the present instance was involved in the former. The Committee learned further from various sources that like occurrences had happened at other schools.

The Committee found that the Principal and every member of the staff were deeply grieved at the occurrence, and that the precautions taken to prevent such consisted in having the bedrooms of the members of the staff, (with the exception of that of the Principal who occupies a separate building) close to the dormitories of the boys and girls, the doors of the dormitories locked and the windows so blocked that they could not be raised high.
Enough to permit a child to crawl through. Indeed, the only further precaution anyone could suggest, was to bar the windows with iron rods—a precaution precluded by the danger of fire. The success with which plots of various kinds have been planned and carried through, not only in Indian Schools but in schools of all nationalities, compels the Committee to require further evidence before acquiescing in the statement of the latter from the Secretary of the Department on Indian Affairs, that the scandalous occurrences reflect seriously on the Management of the Institution. The Committee regrets the occurrences exceedingly but does not think there is any blame attaching to the Principal of the staff.

Complaints regarding Mr. McWhinney's method of bringing truant boys back to the School.

The Committee questioned Mr. McWhinney regarding the complaint that he had on one or two occasions in bringing truant boys back to the School, tied a rope to their arms, fastened the rope to his buggy and so compelled the boys to run behind the buggy; and was told that the following are the facts of the case:

The ringleader of the boys in the case out of which the complaint arose had run away from school four times last year and four or five times this year; and in each case he had induced one or more smaller boys to accompany him; that in the case referred to in the complaint, he had induced two to accompany him, one about his own size and one smaller; that Mr. and Mrs. McWhinney had followed them in the buggy and found them about eight miles from the school in company with the father of the two smaller boys; that Mr. McWhinney told the boys that they must go back with him, that he would take the smallest of them in the buggy, but, as there was not room for all in the buggy, the two larger boys would have to run behind; that arranged thus, all went well, until approaching a bluff half a mile from the starting point, Mr. McWhinney noticed that the boys were preparing to escape; that Mr. McWhinney then stopped, brought the boys to the buggy, tied a rope loosely round the arms of each and drew the rope over the back of the
buggy and the seat, but did not fasten it to the buggy in any way; that Mr. McWhinney had not thought of thus tying the rope to the boys until he was face to face with the danger of the boys running away from him after he had found them and thus impairing the discipline of the School.

Mr. McWhinney admitted that he had asked Mr. Graham (whether in the terms quoted in the letter of the Secretary of the Indian Department or not, he was not sure) as to what else he could do; but so far was he from refusing to take Mr. Graham's advice that the question was put with the desire of getting advice: that Mr. Graham did not advise him not to tie the boys behind the buggy again, but to get the Indian Commissioner's permission to transfer the unruly boy to a distant school whence he could not get home; and that he, (Mr. McWhinney) had, acting on this advice, requested and got the Commissioner's permission to transfer the boy to another school, and that so far, the threat to do this had proved sufficient to keep the boy at school.

The Committee agrees with the Indian Department that boys should not be brought back to any school tied with ropes, not because to do so is necessarily either cruel or wicked, but partly because to be seen bringing back boys tied thus is all but certain to lead to complaints of cruelty; and even more, because such a practice is in danger of degenerating into cruelty. Whether any particular case is actually wrong, must be determined by its circumstances. There is no doubt of the danger to which the boys would be exposed if the ropes had been made fast to the buggy as well as to the boys: but the ropes were not fastened to the buggy. The Committee can see no cruelty in making boys walk, or even run for reasonable distances. The distance those boys partly walked and partly ran behind Mr. McWhinney's buggy was between seven and eight miles: they could, and did help themselves along by clinging to the buggy: and Mr. McWhinney assured the Committee that the horses trotted slowly when they did trot and that they walked a considerable part of the way.

The Matron also gave the Committee the assurance that the boys were none the worse for their experience behind Mr. McWhinney's buggy.
The Committee therefore believe that there was no wrong done on this occasion, and it is satisfied, and believes that the Department should be satisfied with Mr. McWhinney's assurance that this method of securing the boys would not be tried again.

In conclusion the Committee is convinced that the management of the Crowstand School has been on the whole excellent, and that the School is at present in very good condition.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

James Fraser. Convener.

Mr. McWhinney's statement regarding
the bringing back of the truant boys.

(written to his dictation)

George Kakewayas has for at least two years given great trouble
by his frequent attempts to run away from the School. In this, he has been
encouraged by the sympathy of his parents, and the fact that they made much
of him on his return to his home. I have talked both to the parents and to
the boy, reasoning with them both as to the wrong and folly of such conduct.
This boy's offence is always aggravated by his inducing one or more smaller
boys to accompany him in his truancy, and thus exposing his health as well
as his own to serious danger, they, often setting out at nights or on wet
days, to go a distance of ten miles.

He ran away at least four times last year and four or five this
year. The usual punishment inflicted was whipping. I tried to get his
father to punish him but failed. Usually they would bring him back when he
went home. I tried to persuade his father to some form of co-operation
by which the boy's truancy might be stopped. Shortly afterwards, the boy
ran away again, and as on other occasions, persuaded two boys, one about
his own size and one smaller, to accompany him. I drove up to the Reserve
to look for them. About eight miles from the School, I met the three boys
accompanied by the father of the two smaller boys and at once told the boys
that they must go back to school with me. As my wife was along with me,
there was not room for all in the buggy, so I took the little boy into the
buggy and told the others that they must run behind. At first they were
not tied in any way. After going a little distance, while driving near a
bluff, the boys showed unmistakable signs that they were going to make a
break for liberty. I stopped and tied a rope loosely around one arm of each
and threw the other end of the rope over the back of the buggy and over
the seat. The rope was not tied to the buggy in any way. Thus we proceeded
to the school, the horses walking or trotting slowly, so that the boys
could follow without danger of hurting themselves in any way. Some of the
Indians saw us going home and at once reported that the boys were tied to
the buggy.
When Mr. Graham the Inspector was here a few weeks later, two Indians complained to him about the matter. He asked me for a statement of what had happened and I told him as it is set down here. He agreed that the boys should be punished and that discipline must be maintained, but advised me not to do anything like the foregoing again, as it might create dissatisfaction among the Indians. This, of course, was my own intention when I saw how the Indians felt. I asked him what method he would advise in dealing with such cases, and he advised me to request the Indian Commissioner to permit me to transfer the boy to some school at such a distance that the boy could not go home from it. I have done this, and the Commissioner has consented to the transference if it should be necessary to take this step. I told the boy and his father about this, and since then, there has been no trouble.

In answer to questions, Mr. McWhinney said, "The tying of ropes on the boys' arms and making them run behind the buggy was not intended as a punishment but as a preventative against running away. I asked the boys several times while on the way to school if they were tired, and one of them answered that they were not."

INDIAN DEBAUCHERY.

Wild Times on the Kamsack and other Reservations.

Girls' School Broken into and Inmates made Drunk and maltreated — Whites and Halfbreeds took a Hand in the Orgies.

(Special Despatch to the Globe)

Winnipeg, Nov. 28. — Unscrupulous whites, bad halfbreeds and Indians in search of excitement, have been debauching the Indians on the reservations at Kamsack, Keyes and Pelly, forcing the Dominion Government to take action and institute wholesale prosecutions. Debaucheries have been indulged in which have left some participants lying in the bush in an incapacitated state for two days at a time. The Indian School was broken into, and the occupants of one of the girls dormitories have been intoxicated and assaulted by a band of young roughs, and gambling and vice have been rampant at Kamsack where the Indians, whites and halfbreeds have indulged in wild and disgusting orgies. These are facts obtained by the Department of Indian Affairs, which placed the matter in the hands of the Canadian Detective Agency.

Mr. Charles Driver, the local superintendent, despatched a detective to the scene of the alleged trouble, with the result that some forty odd prosecutions are taking place, while a report has been received by the Department showing that the state of affairs was deplorable. As far as information has been received there have been twenty-three convictions. After working for some time the detective collected sufficient material to convict a large number of offenders, and the Department decided on stamping out the evil at once. Notice was sent to the reserve that a "give-away" dance, and Indian dance, that usually results in excesses and vicious freedom, would take place at Kamsack on November 21. All the suspects therefore were counted on attending, and when they did there was a wholesale raid by the police who worked from early morning of Thursday and the greater
part of the following day, in placing the men they wanted under arrest.

On Saturday morning the court was opened at 10 o'clock, and many fines and sentences were imposed. A man who ran a butcher shop there was sent to jail for nine months, and fined $900.
Ottawa, November 28, 1907.

Re Crowstand School.

As per your request Operative No. 16 reports that while at Kamsack he received information from Mr. Blewett, the Indian Agent, that on or about the 15th. of May 1907, some boys gained entrance to the Crowstand School by climbing up a fire escape and entering the girls' dormitories. Mr. Blewett also informed Operative that he had informed Mr. McQuinney, Principal of the School. Operative asked if Mr. McQuinney had done anything in the matter, and Mr. Blewett replied in the negative, and added that the guilty parties should have been arrested.

On the 14th. of November last Operative interviewed Mr. McQuinney, who corroborated the statements made by Mr. Blewett, and added that he had got statements from the girls with the names of those who broke into the School, the guilty parties being Campbell Levright, Wallace Lingush and Fred Cote.

Mr. McQuinney stated that the evidence of the girls was that these three came into their room on the date mentioned with a bottle of whiskey, and remained there for the rest of the night.

Operative asked Mr. McQuinney if he wished the guilty parties prosecuted, and he replied in the affirmative.

Operative then interviewed Campbell Levright who admitted breaking into the school in company with the other two mentioned, and also to having a bottle of whiskey which was given to the girls.
Later, in conversation with Mr. McQuinney, the latter asked Operative if he was going to take the case up, and Operative said that he thought that the information should be laid by Mr. McQuinney, who could produce the evidence that he had from the girls, and Operative could, if desired, conduct the case. Mr. McQuinney then said that he thought that it had better drop as prosecution would mean the trio being sent to Yorkton for trial, and McQuinney gave Operative the impression that his primary reason for not prosecuting was that he wanted to avoid being brought into it himself. Mr. McQuinney stated that it would mean a lot of exposure, and he thought that by this time the three of them had got a pretty good scare. Mr. Blewett and Mr. Crawford were present during this conversation.

Respectfully submitted

Canadian Detective Bureau Ltd.

Per (sd.) C. Driver,
Superintendent.

Sir,

I have your letter of the above date and number and in reply would say that the matter referred to came to my notice while visiting Pelly Agency.

I note that you say the Agent states that the Principal has admitted the truth of the report. This is entirely different to what the Principal gave me to understand when I was enquiring into the case. In fact, I was led to believe that nothing very serious had taken place and that the ex-pupils in question had not gone into the dormitories at all; and that the report in circulation was a gross misrepresentation in every particular. Mr. McWhinney said that the ex-pupils in question were seen in the basement by the Matron, talking to some of the larger girls. I could not see that there was any great wrong in this, and Mr. McWhinney assures me that he investigated the matter most thoroughly and this is all that took place. He added that he dismissed the ex-pupils.

On the other hand the Indians, the principal of whom

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
whom is Joe Cote, say that the circumstances as reported by the Agent are true. Of course I know that Cote has very little use for Mr. McWhinney and wants to see him removed, and anything he says should be corroborated.

I was just about writing a report on this matter when I received your letter and intended advising you to have the Agent summons the supposed guilty parties before him and if there is sufficient evidence they should be punished.

You ask me to investigate and ascertain whether there has been laxity in the management and if so where the fault lies. Of course you are aware that the Principal does not live in the school, but has his residence two or three hundred yards from it. There are times when the Farming Instructor, whose duty it is to look after the boys, is away and three or four ladies are left alone in the building with all the children. There are a great many changes in the position of Farmer and it is not natural to expect a man who is only there for a short time to take such an interest in this branch of the work as the Principal should have. I think perhaps there is a little weakness here. Then again, the building is poorly laid out for securing proper oversight of the pupils. The guests staff, with the exception of the farmer, sleep in the main body of the building in rooms opening from either side of a hall at the end of which is a door leading into another hall, off of which are
are the two boys' dormitories and the farmer's bedroom. If the farmer should not be in his room you can see that a great deal could go on without the knowledge of those in the main building. On the occasion of my last visit I found huge padlocks on the doors and the Principal carrying the keys. The children were locked in these rooms at night like animals. I instructed the Principal to not lock the doors of these rooms but the doors of the main house. Situated as these dormitories are a fire could gain great headway before the children could be released, especially when the responsible head is one quarter of a mile away.

I think Mr. McThinney is unwise in taking the chances that he does, situated as he is, by employing Indian labour and letting them sleep in the house when he is not there himself. One of the men he had engaged on this occasion is a character unfit to be trusted.

If the Agent is instructed to proceed with the case and sufficient evidence is obtained to convict, and punishment meted out, I think it will perhaps have a lasting effect. I think also that the Principal might be told that when he engages Indian labour, especially ex-graduates of suspicious character, he must arrange to have them sleep outside the buildings. This is all I can suggest in the matter.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

In accordance with instructions contained in your letter above quoted I beg to say that I have just returned from the Pelly Agency and Crowstand school, where I went to make further enquiries into the alleged ill-conduct of certain pupils and ex-pupils of the school. I have made a thorough investigation and little if anything is to be added to what I have already reported. The meeting that took place between the ex-pupils was in the basement of the school at a time when the general work of the school was still going on and as nearly as I could find out it was about 7 o'clock in the evening early in October, when it would not be very dark. The male ex-pupils had on different occasions been working in the basement and the girl pupils who had or had not business there were seen talking to these boys. I have read the Agent's report to you on the matter, and it would certainly appear from it that something serious had taken place, and I have no doubt that the Indian, Pierre Cadotte, mentioned in his report, made statements that made the Agent believe such to be the case. However, I was able to see this woman and she told me that all she knew was what her daughter, who is a servant in the Agent's house, had told her. When I questioned the girl she denied ever have told her mother anything of the kind. This denial took place.

Dear Sir,

The Presbyterian Association of Indian Mission Workers expect to hold their annual Convention here at our School during the last week of July. Last year we invited you to be at our meeting in Winnipeg but you were not able to go so. Now this year both on behalf of our School and on behalf of our Association I would give you a very hearty invitation to be present. I am certain you could be of great assistance to us and it would be a good opportunity for you to get in touch with the workers and see many of the perplexing questions more from their standpoint. I do not say this as we have any particular axe to grind but simply that an all-round benefit might accrue to the cause of Indian education.

You will remember that Rev R. P. MacKay D. D. spoke to you last fall about certain changes I was proposing in view of the rebuilding of the School here. Briefly they were these:- Instead of building a large new boarding School I advised building a small boarding School on the centre of the Reserve including a day-school department in connection with it. All pupils who were too far away to attend as day pupils, all pupils who had not proper homes, all recruits for the first year or two should be boarding pupils. The purpose of having the small pupils or recruits attend as boarding pupils at first is that they may get a grounding in English. In the past this has been the weak point in the day-school system. Then all pupils who were
near enough and had spent the proper probationary period as boarding pupils should attend as day pupils.

The following are the reasons which led me to recommend this course:

1. The Indians are becoming more and more insistent in their demands for a day-school.

2. The homes here in a large number of instances have reached a stage when they are able to care for their children as well as the average white home.

3. The parents would be benefited by the added responsibility.

4. A home of even fair quality can do more for a child than the best institution.

5. Now when changes are to be made is the time to choose such a course as will be best for the average family.

I have intended to lay this plan before you ere this but was waiting until our Church Officials should show signs of accepting it. Gradually I think they are coming round to it. You see this would involve some special arrangements with the Department and for this reason I would like to have you at our Convention where the matter will no doubt come up in some form.

Hoping to have a favourable reply from you I Am,

Yours Respectfully,

According to your request I here submit my report of the conduct of the two boys Alfred T. Mooseau No. 142 and Louis Severight No. 141.

1. Both boys gave considerable trouble last year by playing truant.

2. On the thirteenth of last June after several acts of truancy Alfred Mooseau made two attempts in one day (while I was absent) to burn the School by setting fire to the frame work in the basement. I disciplined him severely at the time for it and he promised he would never do the like again.

3. On Feb 13th and again on March 2nd Louis Severight broke into our store rooms and stole articles therefrom. On one of these occasions he was accompanied by Alfred Mooseau.

4. On March 4th these two boys accompanied by another boy broke into an unoccupied house belonging to a farmer who lives near the School and stole several articles therefrom.

After this act I warned Louis Severight that any further misconduct of this kind would result in the case being reported to yourself and the police. I also told his father and asked him to talk to the boy.

5. Last Sunday March 16th when I returned from my work on the Reserve at six o'clock I found neither of these two boys were in the School for supper. When I rung the bell for our evening meeting at 7.30 they did not appear. But while all the larger pupils and the staff were in the class-room these boys went
into the basement and set fire to the frame work using some gasoline which they had secured to insure the success of the undertaking. Fortunately we discovered the smoke just in time to get it put out. Had it gone for a few minutes longer all the School would have been destroyed besides seriously endangering the lives of a number of little girls who had gone to bed in that particular part of the building. As soon as the fire was put out a search was made and these two boys were discovered around the buildings. Their mitts and their clothing smelt strongly of gasoline and they made no attempt to deny what they had done. After some questioning they admitted that their object was to destroy the School so they could all go home.

From the foregoing it appears quite evident that one or both of these boys should be sent to a reformatory for several years. To send them home would not do as this would be just what they are wanting. Neither would it do to send them to a reformatory for a few months as at the end of this term they would return home and this again would satisfy their schemes.

In conclusion I may say I have tried every means to show these boys the folly of their conduct and the wrong as well, but reason, kindness and punishment seem to have all failed.

Hoping that some speedy action may be taken to dispose of this matter, I Am,

Yours Respectfully,

To Mr W. G. Plewett,
Indian Agent, Kamsack, Sask.

Sir,

In the ten years I have been principal of Crowstand I have had very little trouble as a rule in recruiting for pupils. But during the last few years there has been a persistent agitation for a day-school and as a result it has taken more persuasion to get the parents to send their children in to school when they were at the required age. As you are no doubt aware I have recommended to our Church that a new school be built on the Reserve which will combine the features of a day and boarding school. The Indians have expressed themselves as satisfied with this but they seem to think this change can be brought about in a few weeks or months. Some of the meddlesome ones have been giving us considerable trouble for some time by talking to the children and stirring up discontent with the present school. This was what caused us to have such an epidemic of truancy last fall and which led to the transfer of several pupils to other schools.

During the past winter it led to two boys trying to burn the school. Last summer one of these boys made a similar attempt. This spring there are a number of pupils who should come into school but I expect I may have considerable trouble to get them in. They want to wait until this school is closed and the school on the reserve is opened. I don't believe in coaxing these people to put their children in school. It makes them think they are conferring a favour instead of receiving one. Neither do I want to ask the agent to employ compulsion if it can be avoided. Now I think the following course by the Department would be of great service to us and of benefit to these people as well.

Let a letter be sent to the Chief
and head men of Cote's Reserve telling them that until another School is established it is their duty to support the Schools they have. Let them understand that this will not in any way hinder the new school being built. Warn them against this continual habit of fault finding and causing discontent amongst the pupils. Call their attention to the harm it has done in the past and that a continuation of such a course can bring no good but only more harm. Instruct them to see to it that all children seven years of age or over must be put in school at once—either here or elsewhere.

Such a letter sent through the Agent Mr Blewett would I think do an immense amount of good. Remember I do not ask the Department to instruct them to put their children into our School but simply that according to the regulations they must be sent to School. A great deal of this trouble has been caused by the Chief being dissatisfied with me. I have always treated him right but have refused to let him run me as he wanted. Last summer I arranged a meeting between these men and some of our leading church officials to give them an opportunity to say anything they had to say. Chief Cote after agreeing to be there played absent. The two Headmen were there but the only fault they found with me was that I had advised them not to crowd in too large numbers into a house where one of these same men was sick and that I had advised that the young children should be kept away as much as possible from around a dying consumptive. They claimed I was interfering with them caring for the sick. When I asked Chief Cote why he had not been there he said that he was afraid the officials were not friendly towards him. I mention these things to show the petty conduct of these men. I told these same
Officials of our Church that I would be quite satisfied to resign if they saw fit, but they insisted on my remaining here as in their opinion there was no sufficient grounds for my leaving.

Now I should be very much pleased if such a letter be written at once. It would let the Indians see that the Department was standing by the Schools. It might be as well to not say from what source this information has come.

Hoping this may meet with your approval, I Am,

Yours Respectfully,

W. McWhinney

Dear Sir:

On December 17th in the year 1910 I bought a carcass of beef from an Indian named Howard Wolfe of Cote's Band, and paid him therefor $24.35. This beef was sold to me under the usual permit form by which Indians receive permission for sale of their produce. This beef was for use in our School and when we came to use it we found it was not good. The first we cooked gave off a peculiar odor like burned bones. When the matron reported this to me I ordered one of the men to cut up another quarter and see if it was the same. When he attempted to do so a sort of matter ran out of one of the joints. I ordered that no more of it be used and sent word to the Indian to come and take it away. I also notified Mr. Agent Blewett of the occurrence, and asked him to collect $22.00 of a refund from the Indian. This has been very difficult to do and so far I have been able to get only $7.00 of it.

Last fall when Mr. Agent Taylor was in charge this Indian sold two oxen and fifteen dollars of it was retained to purchase a heifer. This heifer has not yet been purchased and the money is still in the Agent's hands. Now what I want to ask is if this money could not be applied to wipe out this old debt to our School. We have been out of our money quite long enough and if this opportunity passes it is hard when another will arise. I might say that this Howard Wolfe is a young unmarried man and the purchase of the heifer does not seem so important as it would be in some other cases. Also the unavoidable way as far as I was concerned in which the debt occurred should be considered. Hoping you may see your way clear to instruct the Agent accordingly, I am Your respectfully,

W. McWhinney.
Referring to your letter of 14th inst No. 116741/1, I beg to say that I have tried to urge on the Indians here the benefits gained by sending their children to a training school, and have pointed out to them that they are very much indebted to the Department for giving them a free school and home for the children. I have not only been very unsuccessful in getting any results in the way of pupils to enter Crowstand School, but I have made many of the Indians more at me and that much harder to get to work on their land, because they say the Principal is not doing good work and that I am backing him up so that I too must be wrong. These Indians are intelligent in one sense, but are too easily swayed by outside influences, in preference to Departmental instruction. I must say that there have been far too many desertions from Crowstand School the last year, and far too many girl graduates from school turning out prostitutes, and boys becoming drunken loafers. When I urge on an Indian to send his child to school, he at once refers to this and asks me if I want his child to become like that, and it is very hard to refute his arguments and get him to see otherwise. I have done my best in this work, but there seems to be some influence, unknown to myself or the Principal, at work against us.

On receipt of the above quoted letter, I went into the subject again, with the Indians and they said that they were willing to send their children to school but not so long as Mr. McWhinney was there as principal, because they

they said he had too much work to do, as a clergymen and could not look after the children as he should.
