Sir,

I beg to say that I have, with the aid of Mr Bradford, acting Principal of Crowstand School, finished the investigation of happenings at that school in March and May last and herein give chief particulars.

From statements of five of the larger girls, signed by these girls in the presence of witnesses, I find that during March last H. Everett, then farmer at the school, entered the girls dormitory alone on two nights and spent some time in the company of two girls in separate beds. A few nights after this, Everett, with five boys from the Reserves adjacent, entered the same dormitory and spent about half an hour there, each boy (except one who had no girl) got into bed with the girls. The girls deny that any immoral acts were committed, but in the case of three older ones, I doubt the truth of this. About the same time seven boys of the school pupils got out of their dormitory on two nights and climbed up the fire escape to the girls dormitory, but the girls say they did not get in, the boys also said the same, but by removing a piece of lath fastened on under the window by a small nail, they could easily have entered. (One boy afterwards told the Indian Police that they had often been in the girls dormitory nights). In May last, from statements signed by Harriet Papequash and Clara Fiddler, Everett had these two girls, separately in his private room, and locked the doors and had sexual intercourse with them. The Indian Police reported this to me while Mr Mc Whinney was sick but I did not care.

The Secretary

Dept of Indian Affairs

Ottawa, Ont.
care to act till he was well enough to leave on furlough. I found after that he knew of the irregularities and had dismissed Everett, so that before I had definite facts to proceed on, Everett had left this district. I have had the Principal lay an information and have issued a warrant for him and will try to bring him to justice. I would like advice as to what I had better do regarding the Reserve men who were in the school with Everett that night. The girls in question are 14 and 15 years old.

As soon as the Cote Indians heard about this, when their children came home for holidays on Friday last, they had a meeting and decided to ask the Department to reconsider the Day School proposition, stating that they did not want to send their children back to Crowstand School again. They all agreed to ask for the Day School, except one man, that is all who were present, the list presented to me contains 18 names for and 1 against.

This unfortunate affair will make it doubly hard to get pupils for Crowstand School and I doubt very much if any will go except we apply the authority granted in the School Regulations.

There are, belonging to Cote Band, altogether some 50 children of School age.

The School Building at Crowstand is not at all suitable for good, safe and healthy work and if the Boarding School is to be continued a new school should be built at the earliest possible moment, before more serious things happen.

I wish to express my appreciation for the splendid help given me all through this investigation, by Mr Bradford, who is doing his best to keep a good school at Crowstand.

Dear Sir,

I came over here from Walkerton yesterday afternoon and on arrival found your letter of the 11th re misconduct at Cowanand School with the Agent's report enclosed. The following is my statement of the affair alluded to in this report.

On May 22nd last, I had occasion to go up to Mr. Everett's room to see him regarding some of the work. When I knocked at his door he opened it and asked me to come in. I saw at once something unusual was wrong and he then proceeded to confess to me that he had been having unlawful intercourse with some of the girls in his room. He was led to confess this by the fear that the other young man had already found it out and was likely to make it known. I asked him a few questions and then told him he must leave on the train that night. My reasons for taking this course were (1) I was only out of bed a few
(2)

I was unable to undertake the serious task of making any investigation. I had found from past experience that in such a matter the brunt of the prosecution would fall upon me. (2) Mr. Everett had always shown himself to be a young man of high honor and principle. He was young and acted foolishly and thoughtlessly sometimes but otherwise had been trustworthy. When he told me of what he had done he was completely overcome with shame. I felt that it was a case of a well meaning young man who had fallen in a time of weakness and to prosecute him would only ruin his life and give publicity to a matter that I hoped might otherwise be kept quiet.

His own conscience I felt would be the best punishment for him and for all concerned. Besides I had no evidence except his own confession.

With regard to his being in the dormitory, I know nothing about this. I am satisfied that the statement made by the boys that they were often in the girls' dormitory is untrue. I do not think any of the schools take so much care as we do at Crowfoot to see that the windows are made safe against anyone
getting out or in. My arrangements in that regard were so very secure that a few years ago Mr. Inspector Graham insisted that in case of fire it was a source of danger to the pupils and asked me to relax some of my precautions. The statement that the girl window could be opened by removing a piece of lath fastened by a small nail is a mistake. None of the windows could be opened as easily as that.

As the Agent says, the building is not such as to make such occurrences impossible. But it is well known that we have used every effort to have new buildings and nothing has been done. Yet when the like of this happens, the blame falls not on those who have neglected to put up suitable buildings but on the staff who are doing all that any set of people can do to make things safe. Of course some will blame me for keeping such a man as Mr. Everett. As I said before he seemed an honorable young fellow. Once or twice I had heard things which reflected upon him and I at once probed them to the bottom and found
nothing in them. The ladies on the staff also looked upon Mr. Everett as all right in this regard at least.

I cannot tell you how mortified and cast down I was when I found this matter out last May. But on account of my then state of health I had to, as far as possible put it out of my mind. Now this letter he brought it all back again with promise of difficulties with the Indians when I return. Occurrences like this happen occasionally I believe in every Indian boarding school. In our case these are always reported while in other schools the agents there take the view that no good can come of reporting them and they are kept quiet. Indian boys and girls have strong sexual passions. They know of cases of loose conduct on the part of their own fathers and mothers and they think lightly of these offenses. In boarding schools where there are both sexes the temptation is strong because of their seeing each other every day.

The burden of this responsibility of
Keeping things right has been a heavy one and it was this which made me advise the semi boarding and day school to put more of this responsibility upon the parents. The best remedy of all is separate schools for boys and girls.

You ask me what to advise in this matter. Apparently the Agent has thoroughly investigated the matter. I do not know whether he intends to blame me or not but we can detect at least a shadow of that. All that I can advise would be to press upon the Department the great need for them carrying out their promise and take steps at once to build the new school. In the meantime if the Indians do as the Agent say they intend and refuse to send their children, the Department must bring pressure to bear or we must close up for the time.

If there is any other information or help which I can give let me know and I shall cheerfully give it.

Yours sincerely,

W. Newlin
Maxwell, Aug. 20, 1914,

Dear Dr. Grant,

Your letter in reply to my report on the Crowland trouble reached me last night. Under ordinary circumstances it is almost certain I should have not only reported the trouble to you in Toronto but have instituted proceedings against Everett. But as I pointed out before my health was in such a condition that I wanted to take a course that would relieve me of all possible worry. In the past I have not hesitated to push matters such as this to the limit, but in return have not, as I know, received any credit from the Department for so doing, while locally I have been blamed for being over zealous. In view of these facts I did what at the time seemed to me best. It needs to be remembered too that the information I had did not show Everett to be so deep in wrongdoing as it now appears he was.

These troubles, lamentable.
as they are, have been occurring more or less for many years, before as well as since I came in charge. In a properly built school this danger could be very much lessened. In our present school I do not know of any change that could be made that would be of much value. I have been thinking deeply over the best course for the future and the following is what I would advise.

1. Get the Government immediately to build a day school in a central location that would accommodate fifty pupils.

2. Close Browntown School and rent the property until time improve or a suitable sale can be made.

3. If it be found later that a residence for boarding pupils is needed, that can be erected then. The building of a day-school would simply be the first step in carrying out any plan of a Boarding and Day School.

4. This should be done at once to have it in operation by winter. We can't carry on the boarding school if any considerable number of our pupils do not come back.

I do not know if you are
aware that Miss Hope Laver, our teacher, was called home suddenly to Wolford about two weeks ago, by town trouble. Dear Dr. Grant,

Referring to your letters of the 19th. and 22nd. ultimo with enclosure and to our recent conversation regarding the Crowland Boarding school, I beg to say that having given this matter careful consideration I have come to the conclusion that it would not be well to continue the co-education of the sexes in this school any longer, and for this reason it has been decided to return the girls to their parents so that their mothers may be in a position to look after them until other suitable arrangements can be made for their education.

The school may be kept on for boys exclusively and Mr. McWhinney is being instructed to discharge all the girls and return them to their homes.

Dear Dr. Grant:

Your letter today was something of a bolt from the blue, saying that the Department had said that they had notified me to return the girls to their homes. As yet I have received no such notice but no doubt it will come along in time. I have also asked the Agent and he has received no intimation of any such action.

I have written the Department since receiving yours, telling them that if the girls are sent home the boys will have to go too as we cannot maintain a school building such as this on a grant earning list of twenty pupils or thereabouts. If they are going to begin building at once, it puts a different face on the matter, but they give no assurance of this. They could not build at a cheaper time as there are plenty of men wanting work and it would also supply work to some of the Indians who otherwise will be hard up this winter. Moreover, it would be a patriotic act to start such a work at the present time. The greater part, if not all these Indians will be anything but pleased to have their children sent home and no other school provided.

Now, as to File Hills, as the matter at present appears, I am very unwilling to go there for the following reasons:

1. The action of the Department in closing this School is in a sense a way of saying that I cannot run this School properly and if this is their attitude I would not want to take charge of another School where the plan of the school building is such that it would be very much harder to maintain proper
conduct between the sexes.

2. I am informed that there is no satisfactory residence for a Principal apart from the school.

3. There is no place anywhere within reasonable distance where my own children could go to school unless they went to school with the Indian pupils, and anyone who has had experience in this work knows that this is not desirable. I have as much real fondness for the Indian children as anyone, but I feel I must safeguard the welfare of my own two little girls.

4. I feel that I am in a better position as far as my own standing and influence is concerned to do good work as a missionary among the Indians here than I have ever been before and therefore I feel that I should stay.

5. If the school is built I would like to be here to work out the plans I have formed.

Now Dr. Grant I do not want you to think that I am writing this letter in a spirit of shirking or selfishness. I would be delighted to take this position simply because you wish it, and to help you out, but these considerations I have named are not to be lightly set aside.

I shall likely write again when I hear from the Department. I would like to know just what they mean when they say "better to have some change".

Hoping that affairs here and at File Hills also may straighten themselves out satisfactorily, I am,

Yours sincerely,

W. McWhinney.

Dear Sir,

Through a letter received from Dr A. S. Grant, H.M. Superintendent, I have learned the following:

1. You regard my action in regard to the Everett affair as inexcusable.
2. You seem certain that I have lost the confidence of the Indians on these Reserves.

In regard to the first of these questions, I suppose you have seen the explanation of my course which I sent to Dr Grant in August and which I also stated to Mr Inspector Graham when he was here after my return to work. I admit that looking at the matter now my action might be called weak. But let me tell you that if most men had been in my position at that time they would have refused to take any part in the management of the School and let it run as it pleased until my substitute arrived. I should not have been bearing any responsibility at all at that time, considering the illness I had just come through, but I tried to do what I could to keep everything going right until my substitute Mr Bradford arrived. In view of this I think it most unfair that I should be judged so harshly for not showing the firmness which has usually marked my management. But aside from this many reasons could be given to justify what I did. Mr Bradford, who was acting Principal during my absence, and whom Mr Blewett commended for his help in the investigation has told me since I came back that if the matter had been left as I settled it, it would have been better for all. Others here in a position to understand
the whole circumstances are of the same opinion. No man can justly accuse me of neglecting to protect the Indian from the whiteman. I could point to instance after instance where I have been more active in securing justice for the Indian than the employees of the Department. Therefore without fear of contradiction I can say that in this matter I will take second place to no one. Notwithstanding all this I frankly admit that my action might be construed as weak in this instance, but I claim it was amply excused by the condition of my health.

In regard to the second matter I admit that there have been times in the past when such a statement would have been at least partly true, but at the present time it is without foundation. Never in all the years that I have been at Crowstand has my hold upon these Indians been so great or their attitude towards me so cordial. In regard to the past it must be remembered that I came here a few months before the advent of the railway and the influx of the white people. The second year the town of Kamsack was started on the Reserve and in my efforts to warn and protect the Indians from the unscrupulous white I sometimes earned the ill-will of both. The Indian at that time could not see that I was acting for his good. I admit too that like most people I made mistakes at times, but it was usually by being too zealous in the interests of the Indians. I think most whitemen may be excused for occasionally making mistakes in dealing with Indians. Then for the last few years there has been a group of men, of whose existence the Department is well aware, who have made no secret of their aim to get the Indians to surrender their land in order that their financial schemes might be advanced. I have op-
posed these men and as a result they have tried for several years to injure myself and our School in the eyes of the Indians. I stated this fact before Mr Graham and Mr Blewett on the 31st of August last. You are aware Mr Scott that these men have tried to hinder the building of our new School for which we have been asking for years. But I am pleased to say that in the face of all this I have at the present time the confidence of these people as fully as any man could very well expect. As soon as these people learned that I was returning to my work at the first of September every child was eager to return to School and the people were willing to send them. None were more pronounced in showing this good feeling than Chief Cote who has so often opposed me in the past.

If conditions at File Hills were suitable for my own family, and the Department and the Church wished me to go there under ordinary conditions I should like to accommodate them, but I would never consider going for the reasons you have given, viz., that I have failed here. Rather than do this I would quit Indian work altogether, much as I desire to remain in it for the good I think I can do.

In the foregoing I have spoken plainly and I think it should be plain that my action in the Everett affair does not deserve the condemnation you have given it, and also that I still have the confidence of the Cote Indians.

I Am,

Yours Respectfully

W. McWhinney

Sir,

In my trip West, last fall, I visited the Pelly agency, and saw Dr. Tran, but he was busy, and W. G. Bluet was away, officially, (but I saw them afterwards,) so I visited the Crowstead school, alone, and, if you remember, in my report then, I did not recommend it very highly, and my opinion of it now, it is even worse than then, when I made my recent inspection, October 28th.

The school is an old building, run by the Church, with Rev. Mr. McWhinney as Principal. He, Mr. McWhinney, said, when I was leaving, the other day, that he supposed that I would make a report, and I told him yes, but I could not say anything to recommend the institution, and he replied, no, that he could not expect anything else, as he knew that it was not up to the standard, but that he had asked a number of times for a new school, and did not feel like spending money on the institution, as it was. As far as I am concerned, as your Inspector, I may say, without exception, that it is the worst residential school I have had to visit, for the Department, as yet. The building, according to what I have been led to believe, has to be kept in proper repair, by the Church, and I cannot see that anything whatever, has been done to keep it such. It is in the most dilapidated condition.

While visiting the wash-rooms, I found both in the boys' and girls', they were very unsanitary.
In the boys' wash-room, there were only three old, rusty, dented basins, for the whole class to use, and no individual towels.

The dormitories, by no means, were kept up to the standard. The water, which had been used for washing, was thrown out close to the school, with no proper drainage from it.

The building did not have screens for the windows, and the flies were very numerous, and had free access for entrance.

The children were healthy enough, but looked uncared for and not decently clad, and in going through different parts of the institution, I went to the store-room, and found sufficient clothing there to clothe the whole reserve efficiently.

From hearsay I do not consider that the moral conditions are what the Department expects, and in my opinion, if I may be allowed, I would like to suggest that the whole boarding school be entirely done away with and that a good day school, with a suitable supervisor, be established, and that a fairly good hospital should be built there also for the care of the sick. I think, in Dr. Tran, you have a good medical man.

Yours respectfully,

O. I. Grain,
Medical Inspector,
Dept. of Indian Affairs.

Dear Dr. Grant -

I. Grant, of Winnipeg, who visited this school on the 28th ultimo. I regret to have to say that Dr. Grant's report confirms and emphasizes previous reports as to conditions at this institution.

We are of course aware that the building is far from satisfactory, but the Medical Inspector states that no attempt whatever has been made to keep it in any repair. He found the wash-rooms unsanitary, and especially mentioned the boys' wash-room in which he found three old rusty, dented basins for the whole class room to use and

no individual towels.

The dormitories were not kept up to the standard, and the water which had been used for washing had been thrown out close to the school with no drainage facilities to carry it away. The windows were screenless and attempt was made to keep out the flies, which were very numerous.

Dear Dr Grant,

Yours of recent date with enclosures from the Indian Department and your reply came to hand last night. Truly these Judas friends of mine are staying by me. Only, one has thrown off the mask at last.

I shall deal with the various items in the report as follows:

This report is evidently based upon a visit made by Indian Agent Blewett Oct. 21st in company with Dr Tran of Kamsack and Dr Graham, Chief Medical Officer for the Department.

1. On the morning of that visit I was most strongly impressed with the evident purpose of Mr Blewett to find something amiss. I attributed this to the fact that he was displeased with me at that time because I had at the request of some of the Indians drawn out a petition for them to circulate in opposition to the exchange of the present Reserve for another. I suggested sending this to the Department through Mr Blewett, but they objected saying they would not trust him to send it. Their reason for saying this evidently was that they knew he had been using his influence to get the Indians to agree to the exchange, and therefore would not want this petition to go in.

2. The statement in regard to the Dormitories is unfair as I claim these are always in first class condition, being scrubbed every week.

3. The statement that the children were poorly clothed is false, unless he bases his statement on the fact that as nearly as I remember one little boy had lost his garter and his stocking was down. Sometimes a person might come along and see boys or girls with torn garments. We all know
clothing will tear and wear out sometime. But as soon as this is noticed it is at once changed. What more could be done?

3. The statement that the children were dirty is also false. The pupils are bathed every week and are made to wash under oversight of some member of staff at least three times a day. But we know that when children are playing they may be clean now and in five minutes be dirty. Any reasonable person should allow for this.

4. The wash-rooms are kept in as good condition as can very well be expected considering the condition of the buildings. They are carefully swept every day and scrubbed from time to time as necessary. But they may be clean one day and if there is a little dampness the mud comes in and the floors are dirty again. I remember the morning of this inspection that the wash basins were not as clean as they should have been, but when hard water is used in washing the soap sticks very easily and makes them look dirty. Usually they are cleaned up every morning but on that particular morning the boy who should have done this had neglected his work and there had not been time to have this set right.

5. The only really just cause of complaint was the boys water closet which I admit was not in cleanly condition, but anyone who has had to do with any school where outside closets are used knows that it is very difficult to keep them in good condition. I had been unusually busy about that time and the cleaning up of this closet had been overlooked. It was attended to directly afterwards.

Let me say further that for two or three years Mr. Blewett has not
given our School any inspection worth the name unless when he came in company with the Inspector Mr Graham. He comes occasionally counts the names on the register and that is about all. Allowing for the condition of our buildings I claim the condition generally was as good as usual with the exception of the boy's closet. Yet I have not heard of any adverse reports in the past. In fact his annual reports, which are the only ones I have seen have been quite complimentary as a rule.

For the last three years at least we have expected each winter that by another year we would have a new building. On this account we have refrained from spending any money on repairs except what was the most necessary to tide over the short time we expected to be using the buildings. In this way the character of our buildings have been certainly on the downward trend, but I deny that the work has been lowered in quality except that during the past autumn we have been disturbed to some extent by the reports that the School was to be closed and by the fact that I have been unable as yet to obtain a permanent teacher since Miss McLaren left in August. It would be well for the Indian Department to realize however that several other things animate and inanimate on the Pelly Agency have been on the downward trend in a most decided way for the past few years.

I hope the foregoing explanation may be satisfactory. I have not tried in what I have written to make any counter attack on the Indian Agent. Anything which I have said which may reflect upon him has come out incidentally in defending my own position. I have always tried to work in harmony with the Agent and to support his
authority with the Indians. Where I could not approve I have if possible kept silent. I am sorry that Mr. Blewett has seen fit to make this attack upon our School as it will make our relations less pleasant in the future.

I Am,

Yours Respectfully,

Rev. W. McWhinney

Dear Mr. Scott,

Yours of Dec. 9th received, also your letter dealing with the Medical Inspector's report of Crowstand.

You refer to my statements in a previous letter regarding Indian Boarding schools. I am fast coming to the conclusion that the proper place to educate these Indians is in day schools on their own reserves, and that alongside of these we should carry on our mission work, the Government being responsible for the schools. Dear Dr. Grant,

I have to thank you for your letter of the 11th instant and for your expression of opinion as to the place of day schools in our educational system. On several reserves, principally in Saskatchewan, we have tried what we call "the improved day school system", with a considerable degree of success where we have been able to obtain the services of properly qualified teachers. We engage, preferably, a man and his wife, the former to take charge of class-room work, and the latter the teaching of domestic science to the girls at the school and general field matron work on the reserve.

There are, however, reserves on which the Indians are so located that it is almost impossible to obtain regular attendance at the day schools without which no reasonable degree of success can be attained.

Dear Mr Scott,

Your letter of the 16th Inst. has come to hand. Please accept my thanks for sending the plan of the proposed school. I sincerely hope nothing will be allowed to hinder the work being proceeded with this season. There are no doubt difficulties in the way but these will have to be met and solved in any case and will be just as easy or easier now than later. I am well aware that this is something of a new venture but I think that Indian workers in the past have been too unwilling to break new ground in order to find solutions for the difficulties which we all admit. I do not think the general tone of educational, moral and religious work was ever so promising as it has been lately. I believe therefore that this combination of the two kinds of schools is the only arrangement which will meet the present needs. It is an experiment I admit, but I have great confidence that it can be made a success.

I think the financial problem can be met quite successfully. But if we get the results the Department should be willing to make the grant suitable. I have always held that it was a mistake to ask the schools of different sizes to live on the same per capita grant. The smaller schools cost more per pupil than the larger schools. Therefore most principals try to get their attendance as high as possible, although it is generally admitted that the small school which can be run on the lines of a home does better work in building character than the large institution. If this size of School does a better grade of work their grant should be so increased as to make it possible for them to make ends meet.
I do not know upon what basis you make grant to the day schools, but I infer you make a grant to the teacher's salary and also allow a sufficient sum to give the pupils a warm mid day meal. I find each that at the present time it costs approximately fifteen cents a day to board our pupils. The mid day meal where meat is used costs more than the other meals of the day, so that about seven cents would be a good allowance for this meal per day per pupil. The following statement would show something about where we would stand.

Dear Sir,

I am sorry to have to report that three large boys and a smaller one, pupils in our school, have been guilty once more of the offense of forcibly opening their dormitory window and going out at night and spying on the girls' window and in the same manner forcing and entering there. They admit trying to have sexual connection with the girls but from all the evidence we can gather they did not accomplish their object.

Mr Agent Blewett and myself have gone into the matter carefully and find they could be sent to jail for the offense but hesitate about sending these boys into prison surroundings. Two of them have been concerned in such wrongdoing before and have been thoroughly warned before of the penalties attached. Instead of sending them to prison we thought it might be better for the future of the boys and for all concerned to transfer them to other schools. We would suggest sending one to Brandon, one to Elkhorn and one to Battleford, providing the principals of these schools and the Department approve. Otherwise these are pretty good boys.

I am writing you at the Indian Agent's suggestion to ascertain what you would advise in this matter, and shall be pleased to hear from you as speedily as possible.

As an indication of the care we have taken to prevent such occurrences the boys had to use a hammer and chisel to open the windows.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just returned from the West, and during my trip I visited the School at Kamsack and found there was no sign yet of any school building for Indian work being erected, and that no contracts had been let, and that there were no materials on the ground. I decided that we would keep the boarding-school open until the end of November, so that we would be able to hold the children on the Reserve, and instructed our Principal, Mr. McWhinney, accordingly. I have just received a letter from Mr. McWhinney, dated Aug. 26th, in which he states that Mr. Graham was been in communication with you, and that you have stated that the school was closed, not to be reopened. My contention is that that communication should have been to me, and not to Mr. Graham, and this school will be reopened, and continue open until the end of November, and I have authorized the Principal to govern himself accordingly, and make arrangements with his staff. We will expect the per-capita grant covering that period, and I am writing to give you
Mr. D. C. S.,

notice to that effect, as in no case would it be good business for us to let the children scatter without any provision being made, especially in view of the fact that the building was not under way, and the time for the reopening of the school was near at hand. It seems to me that this is the only thing that can be done under the circumstances, and hope it will meet with your approval.

I note what you say in your letter of Aug. 25th, regarding the File Hills School and its Superintendent. We have several men who are far better qualified all round for the supervising of this school than is Mr. Gibson. As you are aware, it is not farmers only that we want, but men who are able on educational and religious grounds to conduct the work of the School.

I was very much pleased with my visit to the Protagon la Prairie School. The equipment there is everything that could be desired; the School is full of pupils already, and the crop this year is second to none in any part of the West.

There are several matters that will have to be gone into very soon in connection with this Indian work, and I hope to be able to have an interview with you before long in regard to these matters.

Yours sincerely,

ASG/EG.

Crowland Boarding School

Situation
This school is situated on Cote's Reserve in the Saulteaux Agency, Treaty No. 11, at forty-five miles north-east of the town of Yorkton in the District of Assiniboia N.W.T.

Land
The land in connection with this school consists of 320 acres and comprises the South Half of Section 19, Township 29, Range 31, east of the first principal meridian.

Religion
This is a Presbyterian School conducted under the auspices of the Synod of the Presbyterian Church.

Buildings
These consist of a stone building three stories high 36 x 40 ft and a frame building 26 x 38 ft, two stories high with dog kennel 27 x 40 ft. The buildings are heated by stoves with the help of a furnace. Wood is used altogether for fuel.

Accommodation
The school has ample accommodation for 50 pupils.

History of School
On Nov 2nd/79 A.G. Macdonald in his report stated that Chief Cote's band...
were desirous of having a school started on the Reserve and that there was 30 children within a radius of two miles who would attend.

By an O.C. dated March 26 - 1880, a grant of $100 was given by the Deptt towards the completion of the school building at the Crowfoot's and also an appropriation for the teacher's salary amounting to $12 per year for each pupil, the total however not to exceed $100 per annum.

This school was first opened in 1880 and conducted as such up to the end of the March 9th 1889, the teacher being paid an allowance of $12 per capita for each pupil.

On the 28th January 1899, the boarding school was started and the day school ceased to exist. It has been conducted as a Boarding School ever since. The average attendance at that time was 29. Acton Jones in his annual Report for 1889 (see page 63) says "that the Presbyterian mission have erected a large building for the purpose of a boarding school, which was opened about March (1889) and is under the direction of the Rev. Geo. A. Laird.

On the 15th Oct/88 the joint convenors of the Presbyterian Church, writing to the Comm. of Indian Affairs stated that a substantial frame building costing about $1800 had been
been erected at the Crowfoot. They also asked that a grant of 60¢ per capita for the average attendance be given them by the Deptt. for each of their three schools viz. Birch Clowstand & 4 Mile Hills.

By an O.S. dated the 29th Nov. 1888, a grant of 60¢ per capita for 25 pupils was allowed each of these schools, the whole amount to each not to exceed the sum of $300.

The Commrs requested for these schools as follows: "That in case of the attendance being less than 25 at one school and more than 25 at another, the money not needed for the former case be applied to cover the excess of pupils in the latter."

This request was acceded to by the Deptt. and the Commrs notified to this effect. It was also stated that this decision was not to form a precedent for similar procedure in regard to other Boarding Schools.

On the 23rd May 1889, the Commrs was notified that after the first July 1889, a grant was available for these schools of 60¢ per capita for each of 20 pupils.

On the 14th July 1890 the Rev. Andrew Baird wrote the Sup't of Indian Affairs and he stated that the accommodation at the school was not sufficient — that the Church was erecting a new building to increase the accommodation and that they had already spent $2700 on the building and wished the Deptt.
(continued)

make an appropriation towards helping them erect the new stone building for promised school purposes at the Crowfoot, and also asked that the per capita grant be increased from 60 to 160.

The Dept. considered that it would not be advisable to give a grant toward the erection of a new building for the reason that they did not consider it proper to expend Govt money on buildings situated on land which did not belong to the Govt and as to increasing the per capita grant Mr. Baird was informed that only schools of the industrial class received the rate for which he asked.

In reply to this argument, the Rev. Mr. Baird writing in behalf of the Synodical Committee of the Presbyterian Church says: "That the Committee is willing to convey to the Govt a site for the building with the hope that the Dept. will then give them a grant of $1000.00 towards completing the stone building. The whole cost of the erection of the building to the amount of $2700.00 has thus far been borne by the Church without assistance from the Govt. The site on which it is proposed to erect the building is homesteaded by the Presbyterian Church although the patent has not yet been secured. It is intended that the patent be secured so that interest in the ownership in the hands will be given..."
History (continued)

On the 17th Febry 1891, Mr. Baird forwarded to the Dept' copy of a letter which he had written to the Indian Comm., stating that owing to a change in the proposed plans of the new school whereby another story was added to the height, a considerable increase in the cost was necessary and that instead of £1000 as at first estimated the cost would be £2700 00 and he asked that the Govt bear the additional expense thus incurred, in addition to the £1000 already asked for making altogether the sum of £2700 00 asked for by the Church authorities for the Crowland Bldg School.

In a memo which was submitted to the Sup't-General of Indian Affairs by Mr. Vanderburgh, he stated that he concurred with the above proposition as being a fair one and that it should be accorded to thus equalizing the cost of the buildings as between the Church & the Dept' being £2700 00 to each party making the entire cost of the school building amount to the gross sum of £5400 00

By O.C. dated the 27th June authority was given for the payment to the Presby. Church authorities of the sum of £1000 00 towards the erection of the new building at the Crowland, so soon as they shall have

A cheque for the amount of $1000.00 was forwarded to the said Commrs. on the 29th March 1892 in payment of the grant to the Crowsland Boarding School.

On the 7th Nov. 1892 the said Indian Commrs. Mr. Forget wrote the Dept. asking that a cheque for the sum of $1700.00 in payment of the balance of grant in lieu of the Boarding School at Crowsland be forwarded as provided for in the Estimate of 1892-93.

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Minister of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

It has been reported to me several times of late that it is the intention of the Government to build a rather expensive Indian Boarding School on the Keeseekoose Reserve, five miles north of the present Cote Improved Day School on the Cote Reserve. In connection with this, I would like very respectfully to call your attention to the following considerations, which may not have come under your notice:

1. There was a boarding school at or near the same location several years ago, which was closed owing largely to a lack of sympathetic support from the Indians. Later a day school was started in the same buildings.

2. There are only about ten Roman Catholic families on this Reserve and in order to get any considerable number of pupils from the neighbouring reserves, an effort may be made to recruit from Protestant families. This would naturally lead to friction and difficulties for Departmental officials.

3. If, as is stated, it is the intention to draw a large number of the pupils from other reserves a hundred or more miles away, would it not be better to build the school nearer those reserves from which most of the recruits would naturally come?

4. The Cote Day School has been serving the educational needs of the great majority of the Cote Indians for the past ten years, but, as you may readily suppose, there are some who would like to be set free from the responsibility of caring for their children, and these have been talking of petitioning the Government to replace the present Cote Day School with a boarding school. I do not think such action is necessary at the present time, but the grounds for the request are as good as in the case of the proposed school on the Keeseekoose Reserve. But if that school is erected, then the situation is changed and it may become very desirable from our point of view.

You will see therefore the complications that this proposed building would lead to and quite unnecessarily. The needs of the Keeseekoose people could very well be served at a fraction of the expense by the erection of a day school in a central position. Such a school could be so located that only one family would have more than two miles to come to school.

In conclusion, let me say that I write you in confidence that this matter will receive your careful consideration and that you will try to do what is best for all concerned.

I am,

Yours very respectfully,

W. McWhinney.
I think in the near future a day school should be located on Devil's Creek in Tp. 15, R. 5, east in the Northeast portion of the reserve. There are a number of families settled there who are not liable to sell out. If North St. Peters is closed, it might be re-opened with advantage at this place.

Dear Sir,

I write to make application to your Department for 1300 lbs. of barbed fence wire for the Crowstand Indian Boarding School. The grounds on which I make the application are as follows:

We are very much isolated, being 45 miles from Yorkton, our nearest Railway Station.

In consequence of this, the expense of running the mission is much increased, and it becomes necessary for us to grow as much as we can at home. We have to keep sheep and cattle for milk, butter and meat. We have a half section of land, but unfortunately there is no hay on it.

Heretofore we have been buying our hay from the Indians, but now owing to increase in herds and the decrease in available hay, they require it all for themselves. My desire is to break up a quantity of our land and when it is ready seed it with brome-grass.

And it is for this purpose I am asking your department for enough wire to fence a quarter section of land.

I think from the facts stated, you will see the reasonableness of my request, and I trust your Department will feel disposed to grant it.

I am, Sir,
Yours obediently,
Neil Gilmour.

Crowland, April 24th, 1901

Mr. J.M. Douglas, Esq.,
Hornby Road, Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Douglas,

A year ago, you assisted us very much in getting an increase in the number of grant-earners, at the Crowland School, and I am grateful. Now is another matter that I would like very much to have you bring to the notice of the Department.

When our new building was completed, at a cost to the church of upwards of $6000, with no assistance at all from the Department, I tried very hard to get them to give a grant to furnish iron beds for the school. But I was informed, that the Department did not pay to Boarding Schools, anything beyond the per capita grant, and therefore my request could not be granted.

On two or three occasions I made several appeals for assistance in purchasing something very much needed for the better equipment of the school, but have always been refused upon the same grounds. Now Mr. Douglas, I must positively, from figures given from the books,
of the Auditor General, that this had not been the policy of the Department in the past, as it looked like a large special grant to both Church of England and Roman Catholic Boarding Schools.

But Mr. MacLaren, a copy of some notice found in Park 2, and in the paper mentioned by Departmental Secretary, for last year, to show that it is not yet the policy which the Department is putting into practice.

Now Mr. Douglas, it is a fact, that calling the Presbyterian Church, has not received fair treatment and if we do not get at least a proportion of the assistance that is being regularly given to other denominations engaged in similar work there is going to be a strong protest made.

We claim that we are among the country, equally as well as either of the other denominations, and we prepared at any time to compare the thoroughness of the work being done, with that of either the R.C. or C.E. We ask no favor, only fair treatment.

Now I am not going to ask for $2000 as a Roman Catholic principal, would ask for and never. But there are two things of which
we are very much in need, and for which there are no funds available. Owing to our isolation, we are compelled to keep cattle to provide fresh milk and butter for the school. We have some 300 acres of land connected with the school, but it is not enclosed, and we are constantly having trouble because our cattle getting down into the hay meadows of the Indians, and wandering off sometimes to great distances so that we lose the milk and it is bad for the cattle. A grant of $150 would enable us to purchase the wire and posts necessary to fence in our land, and it would be a great blessing for us.

The other matter is this. Our mission is situated on the top of the cattle land overlooking the Assiniboine River. We tried twice for water, but for 40 or 60 feet down the moisture in the soil is so charged with alkali as to be quite unfit for use. The consequence is we have no water at the mission at all either for use in the school or for fire protection. But how to draw all our
water in barrels, up the hills from the river. You can hardly realize what this means. When it rains and the face of these clay hills is wet, it is almost impossible for a team to get up, with a load, and get water in much less, and a great deal of it for all purposes.

And thus for this reason too, we have an adequate fire protection. It is true we have some hand grenades and a couple of Babcock extinguishers, but if fire were discovered just in the principal shop, they would do nothing. A pound of gunpowder, if they could always be kept upon & work when you want them & - which is not the case -

But if a fire had gained any headway, which in a frame building such as ours, it would in a very few moments, these little things would have no effect, and we would be wholly at the mercy of the fire.

There is nothing that we could have here, that could give us protection, except having a constant and sufficient supply of water always available. There is just one feasible way that I know of by which we may have this
supply of water at Buck Lake Boarding School. The conditions were somewhat similar to surface water, too alkaline for use.

The Indian Department gave a grant for the purpose, and the Government will again be kind, and a six-inch well put down something like 200 feet, when an excellent vein of water was struck, which rose almost to the surface. A tight fitting pipe, which could pull down in the well, as it was sunk, so keeping out all the bad surface water. Then a force pump was put in, and loose connection made, so that by raising the pump, at any time, they could be raised throwing a stream of water on any part of the building. If we had such a well the cost would be double purpose of giving us a supply of water for the use of the mission and also giving us the fire protection, which is so much need. I do not know what the cost of this well and pump would be, but the department will know, because of having made a similar expenditure at Buck Lake.
If any schools have a special claim for consideration, on account of circumstances, then I think ours should be of the number. The fact that we are 45 miles from the nearest town, our railway, and that much of the surrounding country is of a swampy boggy nature, with bad roads, adds very much to the cost of running the school. We have to hire all our own porters down, as our team has to be kept constantly at the school to draw water up from the river. This alone means a loss to us of over $250 a year. Our borrowing becomes difficult each year, to finance, with the funds available. We are anxious if possible, to avoid the necessity of asking the Government to come to our assistance in wiping out an annual deficit—although it would seem that some of the other schools that have received quite liberal special grants from the Government, have still quite large deficits, and I think the Auditor General's report will prove that the Government has paid their deficits in the past. Surely this

Sir,

I have received your letter of the 4th instant covering an application from the Principal of Crowstand Boarding School to Mr. Agent McKenzie, for a grant for fencing unenclosed land and assistance to enable him to improve the water supply of the school.

It is somewhat singular that the Principal of this School did not, through the Agent at Pelly, forward to me a representation of these requirements of the school, with a statement of probable cost, along with the other estimates of the Agency sent in last autumn, in order that provision, if deemed advisable, could have been made, in the votes for the next financial year. This is the first I have heard of these wants of the school; but may say that they are doubtless important for the school. It is true that the Presbyterian Church without any aid from the Government expended about $6000.00 last year to reconstruct and enlarge the Crowstand buildings, and I think the Department might now consistently help the school to enclose its land with a fence.

With respect to the insufficient water supply for the school, I cannot avoid saying that the management of most of our

our Boarding and Industrial Schools have been at fault in this particular. They locate school buildings with very little consideration of how they are to obtain a sufficient water supply. Dear Sir,

Re Crowstand Mission.

The Presbyterian Church in Canada looks after an Indian Mission adjoining Cote Indian Reserve No. 64 - Post Office address Kamsack, Sask.

When the Church acquired title to the property the Government intended to make a grant for the erection of a school building and according to its rules required that the land on which the Government money was to be expended should be retained by the Government so that there was excepted from the grant a portion of the farm which the Church was to obtain. This excepted piece is a block about ten chains square containing 9.68 acres being a part of the south half of section 19, township 29 range 31 west of the principal meridian. The northerly boundary is the southerly boundary of the reserve.

The property belonging to the Church is vested in the Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada - an incorporated body. The certificate of title bears date 22nd February 1905. The building into which the Government money went has long since disappeared, we are instructed, but the Government property as well as the church's property was all used as one and
by some oversight or perhaps through ignorance the church's buildings have largely been erected upon that portion of the farm, the title to which is still vested in the Government. There are no longer any buildings upon which Indian money was expended and the church desires to obtain title to the portion of the farm above referred to.

Under the circumstances we presume that the Government will not ask the church to make any payment for this.

Will you please take the matter into consideration and let us know with what officer of your Department we should communicate in order that the matter may be brought to a conclusion.

Yours very truly,

Cassels, Brock, Kelley & Falconbridge.

Extract from an article—"On snow-shoes to the barren grounds", by Caspar W. Whitney, in the Harper's Monthly Magazine for December 1865. (Page 21)

We were making for the White-Fish Lake Indian reservation, where we had been told we could find food and a covering for the horses, and a schoolmaster who would give us a place to throw down our blankets, and the best of his lander. We were not concerned for ourselves, for we carried enough to provide a substantial meal, and, I think, all three of us would have preferred sleeping in the open to the average cabin. Then this drowsy child of nature led the way to a schoolmaster, but not to the schoolmaster we had been seeking, whose house was a few miles farther on, we subsequently learned.

The schoolmaster we found was a study in filth. He lived like a dog in a wretched hovel, and talked like a cockney Englishman; indeed, he confided to me, the following morning, that he had come from London, and was living there chiefly to learn the Cree language, that he might later preach "Jesus to the wayward heathen." Meanwhile he was educating him. This cockney's own idea of education seemed summed up in the single word coercion. If the Indians surrendered for the dance of their tribe, he scattered them; if they played the games of their childhood, he stopped them; if they asked for reasons, he told them it was the devil in them that they exploited and which he wished to curb out. A logical way forsook, of educating the ignorant? And this is why we find the broken-spirited Indian, who realizes he is the creature of an all-powerful master whose ways he cannot understand, so often "converted," but only in individual cases educated and civilized. He is "converted" because it requires only outward appearance, and he finds his material life made pleasanter thereby. He is willing to change his "Great Spirit" for the white man's "Great Spirit" when a few beads or an extra ration make the trade inviting. But he cannot be educated without being first civilized, and he cannot be civilized because in most cases the white man does not know how, or does not find it to his interest, to make the attempt in a rational way.

At present he distrusts, and sees only what he is being "civilized" off the face of the earth, and remembers the white man in his successive roles of welcomed guest, greedy hunter, settler, and exterminator. I am not dealing in heroics, and everyone knows that the savage must disappear before the civilized man; but if we are to attempt the civilization of those that remain let us first endeavor to gain their confidence, and then follow it up by methods which they can grasp. It is not to be done in one season, nor in two; the civilized red man cannot be brought forth full-flowered, as from a patent incubator; he can be evolved only after long periods of gradual and natural development; yet we expect by mere word of mouth
mouth to make him forsake the sentiments of a lifetime,
of generations of lifetimes. At the same time he should
realize there is a law in the land which punishes and protects
him as thoroughly as it does the white man. He should not be
allowed to escape with no severe penalty for fugitive warpath
festival than that of being merely herded back to his reserva-
tion, when white men equally guilty would be hanged or shot.
The surest way of civilizing the Indian is through his child-
ren, and possibly their children in turn will cease to remem-
ber that once their ancestors roamed over the country hunting,
and learning the lessons of their common mother Nature, ins-
tead of living fenced in on a reservation, ploughing, and
studying the precepts of the white man.

We left the Indian reformer early the
next morning, after a broken night's rest on a dividor floor
than, I think, I ever saw in an Indian lodge. We must have
proved a blessing to that fellow, for we put money in his
purses, and such a meal in his stomach as I fancy he had not
for many a long day.

Sir,

Referring again to your letter of Nov. 26th, No. 116957, enclosing an extract from an article in "Harper's Monthly Magazine" for December, commenting unfavorably upon the School master at Wabasee Fish Lake, I beg to say that I communicated with the Rev Mr McDougall on the subject, and have received a letter from him in which he states that a vacancy having occurred in the school at Good Fish Lake in the autumn of 1894, the Missionary, the Rev E.B.Glass, temporarily engaged a man by the name of Zuhouset, who was in the neighborhood. In some respects he was a competent teacher, but his habits seem to have been very slovenly, and as soon as Mr McDougall knew the circumstances he was promptly dismissed. I am disposed to believe, therefore, that Mr Whitney had some ground for his remarks respecting the condition of the teachers' house; but so far as his general observations on methods of civilising the Indians are concerned, Mr Whitney's remarks are plainly those of a man who throws up the prejudices of a certain class against all religious work, and even to some extent in the belief that the only good Indian is a dead one." It would be well for Mr Mr Whitney to remember that in no case has any substantial attempt been made to civilise the Indians with the pioneer by religious work. I presume this will satisfy...
aries who knew the Indian character would be one in their efforts to put an end to the dances, because these, like the potlatches on the Pacific Coast, are one of the strongest ties binding them to their old heathen mode of life. If by stopping the "games of their tribe" Mr Whitney means their gambling, any teacher should be commended for that; but if he refers to healthfully outdoor sports, I very much doubt the statement. Our Teachers and Missionaries, as far as I am aware, have never discouraged these, but on the contrary have often joined in them, and I know some today who in such sports as foot-ball, lacrosse, hockey, &c., are foremost among the leaders and young men of their schools or missions. Mr Whitney's sneer at the "conversion" of the Indian may be allowed to pass with the remark that I have yet to meet with the first case of a truly civilized Indian who has not been converted. His reference to beads and rations as an inducement to the Indians to change his "Great Spirit" is a simple untruth. I claim to have considerable acquaintance with missions and missionaries among the Indians, at least with those connected with the Protestant Churches, and I do not believe that such a case ever occurred as Mr Whitney speaks of. Some of Mr Whitney's remarks may apply to the American method of treating the Indians, but has no application to those North of the 49th parallel.

Your obedient servant,

"Yours of 29th July, re lost time in White Fish Lake school, and cause, was received on the 14th ultimo. One paragraph reads, 'Your attention is especially called to the last paragraph of Mr Reed's letter. If the facts are as stated they should have been reported to me long ago, and it is disappointing that they should have reached me at last through the Department at Ottawa instead of directly from yourself.' The last paragraph of Mr Reed's letter is, 'The Department is advised that Miss Fetherston, the teacher of this school is a cripple and a chronic invalid, and that the school has often to be closed on account of her ill health, &c.' In reply I have to say

"(a) That 'the facts are not as stated.' Though lame when she came to White Fish Lake, the teacher had no difficulty in getting to and from her school up to December 17th, 1895, and used to walk from house to house visiting parents and children, and attending prayer meetings, &c., without the aid of cane or crutch. I have seen her playing with the school children about the school, like a kid, many a time. Before the date mentioned she never had to close school on account of ill health. Mr Reed's and your own letter would seem to imply that Miss Fetherston came a 'chronic invalid'. On this point I have further to state,

"(b) That Miss Fetherston had to sit during last December for days in a school house with little wood, while the cold wind whistled up through the floor under the foundation of the house, and that sitting there, getting chilled, and remaining so throughout the day, she contracted a cold in the hip which laid her up
for a good many days, her illness commencing on 17th Dec., 1885.

All her illness proceeded from and was connected with that freezing operation. After the ground was frozen an Indian was sent to bank the school house, but he threw so little earth against the building that the banking was useless. Sometime after another was sent to haul manure in order to complete the banking; the last banking was done after 17th Dec. In the meantime the teacher and children suffered, and made complaint that the house was very cold.

"Now the Department which charges itself with building, repairing and furnishing school houses, should also charge itself with neglect, and the suffering endured by the teacher from that neglect. Miss F. now uses a crutch, but moves around lively enough and loses no time. Relative to her teaching and general efficiency I would refer you to the Inspector's report in the Blue Book last published, and to Missionary Reports.

"(d) As to lost time, 12 days were lost through this protracted illness, and 9 through absence from the Reserve while Mrs Glass and myself were at Edmonton,—that is the 21 days lost.

"I remain

AGENT'S REPORT FOR MONTH OF FEBRUARY 1940.

I endeavored to have a joint meeting of the Indians of the Saddle Lake and James Seenum's Bands but the Indians did not appear to be anxious to get together. A meeting was held at Whitefish Lake reserve at which the greatest interest appeared to be the establishment of day schools. A meeting was also held by the Indians of Saddle Lake reserve. Owing to expression of conflicting ideas, division of opinion and the apparent undercurrent of antagonism of one group against the other, however, nothing much was accomplished toward getting together on any definite progressive project. A proposal was made to oust Chief Moses and Councillor James Cardinal and it has been found that when they are in this mood, it is rather difficult to get them together on any definite subject. The matter of purchase of a tractor and ploughing outfit was brought up and discussed but the feeling of the majority was against the proposition. The matter was accordingly dropped, for the time being at least.

W. E. Gullion,
Indian Agent.
Calgary, July 17th, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have the honour to report on a visit I made to the Saddle Lake Agency.

SCHOOLS:

At Whitefish Lake the question of establishing a day school on the Reserve was mentioned by a few — four or five members of the United Church. I do not favour the idea: This Reserve is a long and narrow one; to place a school in the centre, somewhere near the Churches — U.C. and R.C.— would serve a limited number only. Children living at a distance could not walk to school, it being too far; and the parents are not equipped to drive them to and from school five days a week; to do so would mean spending most of their time on the road, and visiting on the way. I pointed out to them that they had a good residential school at Edmonton, where the children are well cared for — clothed and fed — and given a good education. The Roman Catholics are satisfied with the Blue Quills School; this is filled to capacity; however, the new addition to be built will help to relieve the situation.

C. Pant Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 5th instant, in which you seek departmental authority to dispose of the old school and the teacherage at the Whitefish Lake Reserve.

It is our understanding that neither of these buildings is in use and that both are in a somewhat dilapidated condition. MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

The school building at Whitefish Lake was erected during the summer of 1893. It is built of logs, with shingled roof, and is 20 by 22 feet, with a small entrance porch attached. This school has been closed since June 30th, 1911, on account of poor attendance. At the time the school was closed the building was reported to be in good repair. It was built and is owned by the Department.

There is no likelihood of this building being required again for school purposes, as the children from this reserve are Methodists and have been attending the Red Deer Industrial School.

I can find no information as to the cost of erecting the building, nor what its present value would be. This latter information could, no doubt, be supplied by Mr. Agent Hughes.

Rev. Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a communication from the Rev. Arthur Turner, Calgary, requesting permission to sell the old school building on the Whitefish Lake Reserve, Saddle Lake Agency, Alta.

There has been no school at this point for several years and no likelihood of its being re-opened, as the Indian children from this reserve have been attending the Red Deer Industrial School. From the information which the Department has on file it is of the opinion that this building is the property of this Department. Our Agent at Saddle Lake is being written to and asked to furnish a report regarding the ownership of the building. Revd Sir,

I have noted the contents of your letter regarding the services rendered by Mr. Lowen as dispenser at Norway House Reserve. You state that he only claims payment for the issue of supplies from the 16th April 1901 to the 30th April 1902. It is presumable then that he only issued supplies during that period. How do you know that he issued the rations during the period for which he has not claimed payment (viz: from March 1899 to July 1900)? If he did the work it is probably that he would be paid for his services. Under the circumstances the voucher first sent in by you had better be returned to the Department and it will be paid.

With reference to the question of paying the Chief for his services as dispenser, I beg to say that unless you can furnish good reasons for his receiving remuneration for his services the Department does not consider that he should be paid. In his capacity as Chief he is supposed to assume some responsibility without being paid.

Little Forks School
Memorandum:

The Secretary,

According to the request of the Deputy Minister, I had this morning an interview with the deputation of five Indians and their Interpreter, representing the Long Sault, Little Forks and Stangecoming bands of Fort Frances Agency.

* * *

The Councillor from Little Forks reserve and one from Long Sault reserve asked that the day schools on these reserves be re-opened. The school population at Little Forks is so small that I doubt if an average attendance of five or six could be maintained. But the matter should be inquired into and the Agent's opinion obtained. The Long Sault School, in my opinion, should be re-opened. There is an Anglican Church missionary there, and an improved day school would probably become a success. The Indians of the bands object to their children being sent so far away as Elkhorn, as they scarcely ever see them again. I sympathize with them in regard to these long, if not final separations from their children, and as there is no Church of English residential school nearer than Elkhorn, it would seem as if they are entitled to an improved day school at Long Sault.

* * *

Sgd. D. Laird
Indian Commissioner.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Inspector Semmens, in his report on the Little Forks Reserve, calls attention to the fact that there is no provision for the education of the children of this band. They formerly had a school there, but it was closed on account of the small attendance. The census return shows that there are only seven children of school age, while Mr. Semmens states that he was informed by one man that there are ten children on the reserve and by another nineteen, but I think we may take it for granted that the census return is fairly correct. It would not be advisable to re-open the school, as a new building would be required and there would never be enough children to justify the expense.

These Indians are given as nearly all pagans and I think it would be well if steps were taken to have these children placed in the Fort Frances Boarding School where
where there would be accommodation for them. The Indians apparently wish their children educated and they state that they would have to send them over to the American side of the river to school.

Ottawa, May 19, 1924.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Semmens, in his report on the Little Forks Reserve, calls attention to the fact that there are some children on this reserve of school age for whom no educational facilities are provided and that they are obliged to go over to the American side of the river for their schooling.

The Department does not feel disposed to re-open the school on their reserve, as a new building would be required and there would not be enough children of school age to justify the expenditure. The boarding school at Fort Frances has accommodation for more pupils and the Department would like you to use your best endeavours to have these children placed there and report the result.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Honorable Sir,

I take the liberty to draw your attention to the desirability of improving the facilities for the education of Indian children in the district of Rainy Lake and River. I dare say that the establishment of an Industrial School at or about Fort Frances would be a great boon for the said children.

The school on the Batchetah reserve is by far the better attended of that district; still there is room for improvement.

The Indians think that the schools on Red River are too far away but if I am well informed they would agree in sending their children to Fort Frances or the vicinity.

I take the liberty to ask that if an Industrial School is established in that region it should be under the direction of the Roman Catholic Church as there are ten Indians of that persuasion against one of another denomination.

Hoping that you will take this request under your favorable consideration,

I remain, Honorable Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I have seen the Chief of Standingstone lately with regard to the school; he is anxious to have the school completed, but on condition the contract be given to the Indians themselves. The walls of said school are built and measure 22 x 16 - about 14 ft high. Chief offers to take the contract of furnishing and finishing it for $250 - two hundred dollars.

He will purchase lumber for the ground floor, the rest Indians will manufacture themselves. He will also put stove in and tables and seats for class work.

He says he does not want a white man to come and do for them work that they can do as well themselves, especially when they are so badly in need of the means of livelihood. He insists upon this and will not allow the school to be completed unless the contract be
be given to themselves.

I presume the Department will have no objection to this. From what I can see myself on the Reserve, I believe these Indians are capable of doing fairly good work. Again you will not likely get a carpenter to do the same work at this figure.

I took care not to apprise the Chief of the exact sum that has been voted for this school. I thought $200 or would be sufficient for their work.

I trust this offer will not necessitate any delay. I shall be leaving by first navigation and would like to be here to assist these people.

It will be necessary to authorize the Chief for a certain amount of credit for provisions.

Extract from Report of Inspector John Semmens on the Fort Frances Agency, May 14th to June 5th, 1913.

STANGEKUMING.

He (chief) complained that there was not a day school on his reserve. There were ten children, he said on the reserve the whole year round and he thought that he should have a school. I subsequently discussed this matter with the agent and found that he was opposed to taking action owing to the nearness of the boarding school at Fort Frances.

The chief, when urged to place his children in the boarding school, said that three children from his band had died there and he is opposed to sending any more. He further stated that he found that too much freedom was allowed to the children, too much opportunity for the association of the boys and girls. He emphasized the fact that this was not so under previous superintendents, but that the present principal was lax in this particular, and that was another reason why he did not wish to send the children there.

Sgd. John Semmens,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Ottawa, January 27, 1912.

Sir,

The deputation of Fort Frances Indians who called at the Department the beginning of this week asked for the re-opening of the school on the Long Sault Reserve.

Before taking any definite action regarding the matter the Department would like to have a report from you as to whether you think it would be justified in acceding to their request, in view of the unsatisfactory results obtained at the school when it was in operation. Be good enough to state the number of children of school age and the probable average that could be obtained, as well as the general condition of the building in which the school was formerly held and what it would cost to put it into repair if the school were re-opened.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

J. F. Wright, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Frances, Ont.
Referring to your letter of 27th January last,

No. 116766/1, relative to re-opening of the school on the Long Sault Reserve, I beg to state that in view of the unsatisfactory results obtained at the school when it was in operation, and the nomadic habits of these people, and the lack of interest they take in education, think I do not the Department would be justified in re-opening this school. There are 12 children of school age on these reserves, but I do not think that an average of more than half that number could be obtained.

The school building is a good frame building, well equipped, and in good repair.

In my opinion, very little can be done to advance the seven bands on the Rainy river, until we can get them amalgamated into one band on one reserve, as there are only 247 in the seven bands, and scattered all along the Rainy river.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

At East St Peter's School during September Quarter there were 4 Boys, and 7 Girls, all Treaty, giving an average of 4. There are here 7 Families still holding part of their allotments, three of which have children of school age.

At Nuckles Creek School during September Quarter there were on the roll, 2 Boys, and 3 Girls all Treaty giving an average of 5'20. So far as known there are still four families holding parts of their allotments, but only three families have children of school age, and they are all at school. The Clandabye Public School is about 2½ miles distant and as the attendance is so small I would recommend that this school be closed.

About two hundred yards from the Peguis School is a Municipal Public School, but it has refused to take the Treaty children even if they do pay taxes, for the reason that the school is now overcrowded. But across the river and only about a mile away is another Indian School, East St Peter's, and during the winter all the children in the vicinity could attend either school as they can cross the river on the ice. Consequently there is no necessity to keep both schools open, and I recommend that one of them be closed. It might be left to the decision of the Councillors which one should be closed, but the East St Peter's is much the best building.

The other two schools at North, and South St Peter's I think it would be well to leave open for some time yet.

There are a number of families that have sold their allotments, still living on the reserve, undecided where to remove to. But next summer I think there will be quite a migration to other reserves.

The old people have had inducements held out to
them to retain a small part of their allotments, that they might live on and be within reach of relief when necessary. This accounts for so many families remaining there, without children.

The Reeve of the Municipality of St Clements which includes the reserve lands on the east side of the river, told me that with the Reeve of St Andrews which includes the reserve lands on the west side of the river, they had taken legal advice and had assessed all the old reserve lands for which Patents had been issued by the Government, whether held by Indians or sold, and if the taxes were not paid within the legal time allowed the land would be sold for taxes the same as other land. He said the names of Indian owners had been placed on the Municipal Voters list and they would have a vote accordingly. That so soon as there were sufficient settlers in any vicinity to petition for a school, a district would be organized and a school built at which the children of Indians that paid taxes would have as much right to send their children as other settlers.

I broached the question whether in the case of lands sold to white men and taxes paid by them but still occupied by Indians whether the Indian children could attend the Public School. He said so long as the taxes were paid he thought they could, but he was not sure and would take legal advice on the question.

No special school tax has been assessed in St Clements, but it has in St Andrews as there is a school in operation there and the District includes all the allotments on the west side except those included in the Town of West Selkirk. But there is no Public School on the east side of the river (St Clements) where Indian children can attend.

There is no school district there and no white people that would oppose it save the non-residents.
