Sir,

Last September you wrote me in regard to the St Peters Schools and at the time I was more than busy and I requested Indian Agent Lewis to write you his views on the general question. Subsequently I asked Mr Sutherland acting for Mr Lewis to see that the question was dealt with and he informed me that he had written you the information required.

Since that I have looked into the matter and have concluded that we are not under obligation to supply these people with educational advantages as they are tax payers and the Municipality which collects taxes are in duty bound to supply them with school accommodation.

However the Municipal authorities absolutely refuse to entertain all propositions looking in this direction and it may be good policy to continue two Schools for the present one at South end and one at Millcote. If we were to withdraw too suddenly misunderstanding and further friction might arise.

It is necessary to supply two Schools at the Peguis Reserve and it should be understood that we give privileges only on Reserves. This impression it will be my duty to give to all concerned but for the present I think it will
be best to continue the two Schools named.

I may say that the Municipal authorities object to the admission of Indian children to their day schools because they are Indian children but this foolish prejudice will wear away in time and the rights of the case will prevail.

So far as the Indians are concerned it is best for us to encourage their removal as much as possible to Peguis and if every advantage is allowed at St Peters they will be slower in moving. The erection of the two Schools which you have ordered at Peguis will be an extra inducement to parents to move their families there and a careful policy is the best under existing conditions.

I shall be glad to be further instructed in this matter and will carefully guard the interests of the Indians on the one side and the interests of the Department on the other although allowing the existence of the two Schools at St Peters for the present I think that the Municipal Council should be made to understand that the arrangement is only tentative and that the Department does not consider itself under obligation to continue the privilege indefinitely.

I have the honor to be

Dear Doctor,

In the summer of 1903, Rev. E. R. Steinhauer of Fisher River and others represented to me the necessity of a teacher at Bloodvein Reserve, pointing out that a school was there and a number of children. I took no definite action, believing very little in a day school under such conditions, but later on I had word that Jerry Rundle was available, in fact had gone to take charge.

Not seeing any report for the year, not being able to go and visit the Reserve, I knew little or nothing of the state of affairs. The Government Agent and Inspector were there at Treaty in 1904, and I learned from them that things were not in the best of condition; but still believing that children were attending school I placed it on the list for 1904-5. Some time in April last, I had word from Rev. E. R. Steinhauer that Jerry Rundle was over at Fisher River, and reported that his own children were all that attended the school last winter. I at once wrote Jerry not to return to the school until further instructed. I have already paid Jerry two-thirds of the
year's salary. Under the circumstances I think if the Government pay
a half-year's grant it would be a fair arrangement, with the under-
standing that the school will be closed.

Yours respectfully,

Sir,

Referring to your letter of October 28/09,

No.117585/1.

I made mention of this school in my last monthly report on Schools. This school was opened at the urgent request of the Indians. It is on the East side of the Winnipeg River, near the mouth. There never were very many children of school age at that point, but a school-house had been built there a number of years ago, and had been closed on account of insufficient attendance. The Chief and Council of the Band asked that this School House be moved further up the river where there are more children, as it is about impossible to allow school children to cross and recross the Winnipeg River. The River varies that Reserve from a half to a mile in width. During a West wind from the lake, the river is about as dangerous as the lake would be, with the added danger of the current. The Commissioner however demurred at having the School House moved, or recommending the building of a new school-house, and this was opened two years ago to attempt to pacify the Indians, thinking perhaps this would satisfy them.

To The Secretary,

The Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, Ont.
It has never just exactly suited them, but they have not made much protest since. I have looked over the situation several times, and I cannot see where a school-house could be built there that would be easily accessible to a very much larger number of children. There is a large creek coming down on the East side, in fact two of them. One of these was bridged by the Indians a year ago this Fall, but the other would be too great an undertaking as it is somewhere about two hundred feet wide.

It is difficult to recommend just what should be done. To be of any use it would really require two schools, both of which would be poorly attended. There is no road on the East side of the River, but in parts there are trails cut through. The Indians have asked that roads and bridges be constructed on the East side, the same way that we did in 1905 on the West side. I have never recommended it, leaving it for future consideration, as the other on the West side cost us over $3,000.00. In the month of September Miss Folster wrote that in August she had had no children at all for days at a time, and asked me what she should do. I told her to continue the school, and keeping it open until we would decide what could be done. She has had children attending in September and October. I do not know what the November attendance will be, and can only ascertain by correspondence. I would recommend that the school be kept open until the end of this quarter, and if the attendance does not improve get another teacher, and in any case not close the school until the first of April, as the winter is a part of the year in which they are best able to get the children to attend school.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

On my visit to Fort Alexander I visited the Lower Fort Alexander school and found only four pupils present, three girls and one small boy. Dear Mr. Simmons,

I beg to present again the need of moving the Red School, E side, St. Peter's Reserve, from its present site to the St. Peter's Church lot.

I have given the matter every consideration and I am convinced it would be the most convenient and would serve the highest interests. For should the school be moved according to our application, there would be three schools on the E side of the River almost equidistant from one another, and this speaks much, I believe, for the proposed location.

At present the Red School and the R.C. school are bunched in one place, and both are closed, and this shows that, at present, a school is unnecessary at this point, much less two. But should this part ever be settled, its educational needs could be met by the R.C. School.

Immediately half mile south of the R.C. School.
To the St. Peter's Church, a distance of one mile, there are 21 church families, while south of the Church there are 7 church families in a distance of ½ or ¾ of a mile. There are thus 28 families in the distance of ½ or ¾ miles.

In the list of children submitted I gave the number as 49. As a matter of fact there are 53, as the children of Tom Prince and John Anderson are left out.

I am ready, should this matter be approved, to submit the name of a first class and proper qualified teacher, who has had experience in Indian day schools, to the Department.

We are very anxious that you should take action in this matter as soon as possible, as the plan proposed will be a simple matter while the ice remains, but much more difficult to do in summer.

Trusting that you will approve of the matter,

Yours sincerely,

L. Laronde.
Some time since, a letter was received from the Rev. Louis Laronde of St Peter's, asking that the unused "Red School" be removed to a site on or near the Mission lot of St Peter's.

It was claimed that this could be done very easily while the ice was still on the river, but could not be moved easily at a later date.

The Indians interested, agreed to move the building without expense to the Department except for a new foundation, which might cost $25. or $30.00.

This whole matter was referred to the Indian Agent and received my approval so far as it concerned this Inspectorate.

This morning I received a second letter from the Rev. Mr Laronde in regard to it, which I send enclosed in this letter for your information.

To my own mind the case is worthy one, but I presume that the Department has already taken such action as their judgment will warrant.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

At the earnest request of the parents of the children of school age living in the district one mile North of St. Peter's Church, and half mile South, on the East side of the Red River in the St. Peter's Reserve, I beg to petition the Dept. of Indian Affairs to have the Red School at present located a little North of the Roman Catholic Church and is at present closed, moved to a location convenient to the children mentioned.

I submit the list of children, with their ages living in this district—in all 49. This number shows that this district is more deserving of a school than any other in the whole Parish.

The nearest school for these children is the South St. Peter's. But its location on the West side of the River, renders it almost impossible for the children of the East side to attend it. In summer it is impossible for them to attend it, as the parents cannot remain at home to row their children across and back every day. In winter, I find that a few attend, though but irregularly, on account of distance. The majority do not attend even in winter, as the school is fully two miles away. Thus about ¼ of these children attend school irregularly in winter, while ¾ do not attend school at all.

On behalf of the parents and children of this district I beg you to allow the people of this district to move the school to a new location.
Central for all their children. It is the unanimous wish of the people that the school be located on or near the St. Peter's Church lot, 212, which is high and dry, and easy of access. In return for the occasional use of the building for parish purposes we would be willing to lend the site to the Government for school purposes as long as it should be required, or the Government could secure, in exchange for the land on which the present school is situated, or otherwise, an acre of ground in the lot immediately adjoining the church lot and owned by Geo. Frank, of Selkirk.

The people concerned are willing to move the building to the new site without charge to the Government. The moving will not be difficult if done before the river breaks up. The Government would be asked to have a stone foundation put under the building in the new location. The moving of the building would be under the charge of Henry Geo. Prince, whose trade is to move buildings, and he guarantees to do the work without damage to the building.

After careful enquiry I find that the number of children that will attend this school should it be moved, will be steady.

I earnestly hope you will give this matter your careful consideration, and that you will give us a favorable reply soon, so that we can move the building while the ice remains.

Yours Sincerely,

Louis Laronde
Incumbent.

ST. PETERS INDIAN RESERVE SCHOOLS.

ST. PETERS SOUTH: Situate on River lot 52, west of river. School frame, in outward appearance the equal of the usual country school throughout the province. Building nearly new; value $800.00. Dear Mr. Smart,

You will remember that some time ago we had a conversation regarding Indian schools at St. Peters Reserve. I would now like to get your advice before recommending those interested in the matter what official action to take. I find on enquiry that there are three Indian schools in the neighborhood of St. Peters, two of them on the opposite side of the river and practically inaccessible, the third one not at all convenient. Not one of these schools is doing good work and the attendance is very small. The Indian population at St. Peters is practically unschooled. It appears that the Indians themselves on the Reserve would like a new school established in a convenient center under the direct control of your department. They do not wish a school under the Manitoba Act for that would bring them into touch with the municipality, and this they wish to avoid. I believe they have a great fear of municipal interference and therefore they wish a school carried on under your direction. They think of
Winnipeg,

presenting a petition to you asking for a school in the heart of the Reserve. I believe that this wish is practically unanimous. Would you advise those particularly interested in this movement to go ahead with their petition? If not, what steps should they take. The children are now growing up in ignorance and it is felt that a school would be patronized if it were in charge of a competent teacher, and it is believed that a competent teacher could be secured.

Hoping to hear from you at your convenience,

I am

OTTAWA, 20th August, 1900.

The Secretary,

In reply to the enquiry made by the Deputy Minister in regard to the suggestion made by Mr. W.A. McIntyre of the Provincial Normal school, Winnipeg, for the establishment of a convenient central school on the St Peters Reserve to take the place of the four schools now in operation there, the undersigned begs to say that three of the schools in question are under the auspices of the Church of England while the fourth school is conducted by the Roman Catholics. An amalgamation of two schools under different denominations was tried at Cornwall Island and though still in operation, has not been a success as it has only been attended by children of one denomination.

Four schools are more than are required for the number of children of school age shown to be on the reserve. Mr. McColl, in his report on these schools which was made in June last gives the number which should attend each school as follows:

- East St Peter's R.C. ---- 15, average 7
- North " " C.E. ---- 26 " 11
- South " " ---- 22 " 7

There are, in addition to this number, 78 Protestant children at the Rupert's Land school and 11 Roman Catholics at the St Boniface school, making a total of 196 children of school age belonging to the reserve.
Mr. McColl's last census return gives the total number of children of school age on the reserve as 250,- 210 Anglicans, 34 Roman Catholics, and 6 Baptists, which shows a difference of 54 between his tabular statement and his school reports.

I see two formidable drawbacks to the establishment of a central school, one being the religious difficulty and the other the scattered settlement of the reserve, which follows the river front about eight miles. Nearly half the children would have to cross the river and many of them would have to travel over four miles to reach a school situated at a central point. It would require a considerable amount of money to put up a suitable schoolhouse if it were decided to erect one, and as St Peter's Band has no money to speak of, funds would have to be voted for the purpose. I think the Department is now paying too much for the results obtained from this reserve but this is owing to the heavy drain made on the day school pupils by the Rupert's Land school.

Some years ago the South St Peters day school had an enrollment of about 50 pupils, with an average attendance of over 35.

The small average attendance at our Indian schools is, in most cases, due to the lack of interest and ability in the teachers, and I think that if the schools are carried on as they now are, the attention of the Roman Catholic and Church of England authorities should be called to this matter.

It is not quite clear to me from Mr. Mc-Intyre's letter whether he suggests the amalgamation of all the schools into a central one, or the establishment of a central in addition to the four now in operation. If the latter construction is taken, I have
no hesitation in saying that there is no need of an additional school.

Ottawa, August 28th, 1900.

I think it would be well to write to the Church of England authorities in connection with educational matters at St. Peters Reserve, stating that it is absolutely necessary for competent teachers to be placed in these schools. It is reported to the Department that the teachers on this Reserve are incapable of giving a proper education to the children and that there is a great lack of interest through the inability of the teachers to manage the schools. If this is true, it is absolutely necessary that some steps should be taken to appoint properly qualified teachers, and I would suggest that no teacher be appointed unless holding a Second or Third Class certificate and having had a thorough Normal School training. If these requirements are not met the Department will certainly have to undertake to provide proper educational facilities for the children on this reserve.

Another fact to be borne in mind in connection with St. Peters Reserve is that it is situated practically

General Remarks.

There are, as far as I am able to judge, two causes for the backwardness of the children in this school: (1) The indifference of the parents, which is the cause of the irregular attendance. (2) The poor qualifications of the teacher.

Mr. Harper is conscientious and tries his best, but he is not qualified, either in an academic or in a professional way. I do not think that he can make the work interesting enough to make the children anxious to go to school. I think that Mr. Harper, apart from what I have said above, is a good faithful worker but he could not be accepted in a public school.

A. Willows,
Insp.

The report shows clearly that Mr. Harper is not qualified to teach school although he is doing his best. It seems to me that the Department should take steps to put a qualified teacher here. There is no necessity to use the Provincial Compulsory Act, as we have provision in our own act to take care of a situation such as Mr. Willows mentions.

You will note what he says regarding the building. But it will not be advisable to spend more money on a building until we are satisfied with the progress of the school itself. The first thing to do is to get a good teacher and then the Department, I feel sure, will be glad to put up a decent school building.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner,

Sir,

As unexpectedly, I have been offered, and have accepted, a better position, in the Department of Immigration and Colonization, and am entering at once upon these new duties, I therefore desire to hand in my immediate resignation as Teacher of the North St. Peter's Indian Day School, near Peguis (Selkirk) Manitoba.

While I fully realize that up to the present I have been the Teacher of this school, and that you would have preferred some longer notice of my resignation, yet, under the circumstances, I trust you will therefore accept this my hurried resignation, instead of receiving the usual two weeks' notice thereof.

Since I have been in charge of this school, I have endeavoured to give satisfaction in my work, but I have found the conditions there very difficult, owing to:

(a) There being no proper accommodation for a Teacher;
(b) There being no proper accommodation there for my wife & child;
(c) The double expense incurred in keeping a home in Winnipeg for my wife and child, and my own boarding at North St. Peter's, together with the travelling expenses of my week-end visits to Winnipeg.

(d) The people residing in the vicinity of the school are mostly Indians, and Indian Half-Breeds, and hitherto the only accommodations could obtain with white people, within reasonable distance from the school, were very unsatisfactory in many ways.

Under these conditions I have been finding it almost impossible to live, even economically, within my school district.

The school also is in a very bad condition, quite unsuited for both the health and comfort of the attending pupils, and I had hoped that a better building would have been substituted for the present one 'ere this. Throughout I have endeavoured to do my best for the pupils, and I feel assured that they have progressed under my tuition educationally, and have shown an interest in their school work, but the various adverse conditions under which I have had to labour, has of late been a discouragement to me.

I gladly take this opportunity, however, of expressing my very deep appreciation of the kindness and sympathetic consideration that the Indian Agent, Mr. H.O. Latulippe, has throughout shown towards me and my school work. He has done much to help and encourage me in my work and I feel deeply indebted to him for his personal interest and readiness at all times to cooperate with his advice and practical help.

I feel sure that you will understand my position and that I felt unable to refuse this opportunity of bettering myself and conditions.
any by this change of being better enabled to establish a home with my wife and child under more congenial conditions, and in view of these circumstances you will be prepared to accept my immediate resignation.

I have already personally notified the Archbishop of the Diocese of Rupert's Land, and Mr. H.O. Latulippe of my resignation, and have handed over the school and school equipment to Mr. H.O. Latulippe. I am also sending him my school report (to date) to be forwarded by him on to you.

Please accept my apologies for giving such a short notice.

Thanking you for all your kindness and consideration towards me during the period of my Teachership at the North St. Peter's School.

We note that no religious services had been held in this old building during the past two years or more.

Relative to the site on which this building was located, the Department can find no record from the survey notice of Lot No. 135 or from the sale of this Lot to John Ryland of any building used for school purposes being located thereon. From the surveyor's notice it is stated that the St. Peter's North School was situated on River Lot No. 140, east of the river, and that no land was reserved for school purposes when this lot was disposed of. The Rev. W. Tinney, in his letter, a copy of which was forwarded to you under cover of official letter of June 30th, stated that there were a number of long seats and a pulpit in the old building which were supplied by the church authorities, also a bell. If these had not been removed before the building was taken down they should be placed at the disposal of the church authorities. We are unable from the record on our files to ascertain that the church authorities contributed any amount towards the cost of the erection or maintenance of this building. The proceeds of the sale, viz., $30, have been deposited to the credit of Casual Revenue.

Please interview the Rev. Mr. Tinney and advise him of the contents of this letter. He may be in a position to advise whether the church authorities expended any amount in erecting the building or towards the cost of its maintenance.

MEMORANDUM

Mr Inspector McColl forwards a petition from the Indians of South St Peters asking for the re-engagement of Mr R.F. McDougall, who formerly taught that school and resigned to take the place of Assistant Principal of the Rupert's Land Industrial school, from which position he was lately dismissed for intemperance.

Mr McDougall carried on the South St Peters school very successfully, having by far the largest and best Indian day school in the West. The school is now taught by Miss Grace Rolston, who holds a Third Class Provincial Certificate. Mr Agent Buckle in his report for last month makes the following remarks:

"Miss Rolston does not seem to be able to manage Indian children, and they are easy to manage; she is not inclined to take advice, and her manners are inclined to be rude, and not as they should be winning.

"The children do not seem to care for her and the consequence is that the parents cannot make them go to school; and in fact the parents do not make care to send them.

"As this is or was the best school in my agency, and as such a large number of children can attend, it either requires a woman of experience to conduct it properly or as I would respectfully suggest, a male teacher."

The report shows a great falling off both in attendance and efficiency since Mr McDougall was in charge.

The undersigned would remind you that an application for
for the re-instatement of Mr McDougall at Rupert's Land School was received a short time ago from Mr Richardson M.P., and while it might not be considered wise or in the interests of the school to again employ him at such an Institution, he might be given another chance at the South St Peter's Day School.

The South St Peters Indians are members of the Church of England and the school has been recognized as coming under the control of that denomination and the present teacher was appointed by the Church authorities although the salary is paid by the Government.

Should the Department consider the petition of the Indians favorably it would be well to communicate with the Church authorities and obtain their views on the subject before taking final action in the matter. This is a delicate case which might lead to future trouble were the Church entirely ignored.

OTTAWA, 26th April, 1905

Sir,

I have to call your attention to the following remark made by Rev. Mr. Sommese in his semi-annual report on the Clandeboye Agency in regard to educational matters there:

"The attendance at day schools has somewhat improved this year except at St Peters North and Muckle's Creek schools. The former has suffered some from the establishment on the west side of the river nearly opposite of a Baptist day school. It will be remembered that a year ago I tried to move this school to where more children could be found viz.-on the west side of the river near Harper's but we have now been foiled in this by the establishment of a denominational school as above.

"Muckle's Creek is a weak school always but owing to removals especially so this year. It has become a question whether it is wise to continue paying a teacher at this point. There are more non-treaty children than others and it might not be amiss to think of handing over this work to the Provincial authorities."

The Department would like to have your report on these statements, and especially in regard to the Muckle's Creek school.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th instant re the Huckle's Creek Day School, and to say that on receipt of Mr. Inspector Semmens' report I wrote to Mr. Indian Agent Lewis asking him to see that the next quarterly returns only show the actual number of days the school was open, so that the payment of the grant be made only for that period, or as the Department may see fit.

As to the fuel supply, this is a somewhat difficult matter. At other parts of the reserve the Indians deal in wood and are given permits to cut with the understanding that the schools are to be well provided in respect of fuel or be closed. Not so at Huckle's Creek, and there are no incentives to offer or punishment to exercise, if the Indians refuse to give a hand. All that can be done that I see is either the withholding of the grant or rely on the exertions of the resident Agent who may persuade the Indians from time to time to help themselves.

Sir:-

I have to acknowledge your letter number 233875/1 dated 16th April 1915, also an enclosure, the same being a copy of a letter signed by John Flett and William McCorrister, in reference to the education of the children on St Peter's Indian reserve.

In this connection I beg to submit the following report. The "Trindle" or North St Peter's school, before Harper teacher, was closed on the 18th of December 1914; this was done by the direction of the doctor, and on account of the prevalence of an epidemic of smallpox existing in St Peter's at that time, it was feared that the assembling of children would be dangerous, and be a possible means of spreading the epidemic. The school has remained closed since the date given above; when the end of the quarter ending March 31st 1915, was drawing near, I was asked if the school could be opened. I referred the request to the doctor, he intimated it was not advisable, and still more or less dangerous to open the school, as he was not sure that the epidemic of smallpox was completely stamped out; the school is still closed, at the time of writing, and the doctor will keep it closed a little longer, to insure safety from the smallpox, which was in the vicinity of this school.

The south St Peter's Indian Day school, was closed on the 28th Feb'y 1913, at this time the teacher was resigning, it was found that the number of children attending had fallen to the low quarterly average of 1 Treaty child and 2 non-treaty children, out
of reputed school population of over 40, and I find that Mr Agent Coleleigh, in reply to departmental letter number 117570-1 dated Jan'y 31st 1913, reported that the cause of this low rate of attendance was because the majority of these children were attending the Municipal school in St Clements, and I also find that the trustees of this municipal school entered into an arrangement to afford tuition to Indian children, on the terms of departmental letter 117570-1 dated the 17th March 1913, and that this arrangement has been in operation, with satisfaction, but that this municipal school was also closed, from the latter part of December 1914 until the latter part of Jan'y 1915, on account of the smallpox epidemic; it was opened and continued up to the end of March inst., and was then closed on account of some financial complication that the Municipality felt would not permit them to operate the school for the present, as soon as this complication can be adjusted, the school will operate.

From the foregoing, I think that the claim that is made by John Flett and William McCorristar, that they are suffering a great hardship with reference to the educational privileges for their children, is not well founded. I have met these men, and I have pointed out to them that the closing of the schools under the present conditions, and the conditions that have existed since the beginning of December 1914, on account of the smallpox epidemic, during that period, could not have been avoided, that the doctor was doing this as a protection to the people, and to prevent the spread of this terrible disease, and that the department would not interfere with the directions of the doctor in this very important matter. I also pointed out to them that, until this epidemic started, ample arrangements for the education of their children existed, and that the department was defraying the cost in connection with these arrangements, so that the department was providing the educational privileges they were entitled to, when there was no cause, such as the epidemic, to prevent operation of the schools, arranged for, to do this work.
I asked these men who had written this letter for them, and why they did not bring this matter to the notice of their Agent, who could have clearly explained this matter to them, they would not give me the name of the author, this action on their part gives me the impression that they were prompted to do this, not so much on account of the so stated hardship, but as an indirect complaint re land titles in the old reserve.

All of which is respectfully submitted,

I have the honor to be,

your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir,

re Patapun School District

The school in the above district has been closed for some two years owing to the lack of resident ratapuners with children to attend the school. Recent new families have settled in the northern part of the district and their children are attending the North District School. Recently our Inspector, Mr. Smith, visited the school and interviewed with Mr. D. Smith, the Indian Agent at Belcourt concerning the amalgamation of Patapun and the North District Schools. He stated that by moving the present school used in the North District and site North the building could be made to serve both communities. The attendance would be that of the students and at present twelve of these would be public school children.

I am writing to ask if your Department will be willing to share on an equal basis in the expense of moving the school to a new site and placing it on a foundation there ready for use and in operating it as a normal school for the children from the district and those from the Reserve. The Inspector estimates the cost of moving the building and placing it in condition for use at not more than Six Hundred Dollars, including the site.
It would appear to be an economy for your Department and for certain School Districts under this Department to put these two groups into one school which could be an efficient public school.

I shall be glad to hear from you in the matter.

Yours truly,

R. Fletcher
Deputy Minister of Education.

Dear Mr. Graham -

On my last trip to Manitoba I visited the Clandeboye agency at Selkirk, and, in company with the agent, drove down to the school along the river on the old St. Peter's reserve, and also visited Brokenhead Reserve.

While at the agent's office Mr. Matulippe showed me a letter from the Department, dated last May, in connection with the amalgamation of the Indian school on the old St. Peter's reserve and a white school which is situated three or four miles further up the river. It appears that this white school has been closed for something over a year and the Department of Education in the Province of Manitoba has made a proposal to our government to amalgamate the two schools for the purpose of keeping down expenses, as it appears that the white settlers are unable to finance the salary of a teacher. Our school on the reserve is an old log building and not worth very much, whereas the white school is a good frame building on a cement foundation and is in good shape, with the exception that it needs painting.

If this arrangement was gone into the white school would have to be moved down the river about two miles. It would be an easy matter to move it in the winter time on the ice as it stands right near the bank of the river and a level place can be found just below the school where it can be got down onto the ice and there is a good building site a couple of miles below where it would be an easy matter to move it off the river on to the site.

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

MEMO FOR FILE:

I discussed the amalgamation of the St. Peter's North Indian and the Patapun White Day Schools with Dr. Fletcher, Deputy Minister of Education for Manitoba, Public School Inspector Willows and Archdeacon Thomas. The St. Peter's North Indian school building is in poor shape and it is approximately 5 miles north of the Patapun school. If the Patapun school were moved two miles north, the majority of Indian children would be nearly 3 miles away. This would mean that the Indian children would have to be drawn to school. Mr. Setton, the present teacher, who is doing especially good work, says that the most central point for the Indians would be the ferry, which is somewhat south of the present site. It is possible that Inspector Willows might agree to the ferry situation if the Patapun school were moved and a joint school conducted.

Fort Alexander - Prot. Bpe School
We, the undersigned members of the Band on H. Alexander Indian Reserve, together with those on the neighbouring Reserves of Black River, Hole River & Brokenhead River, on Lake Winnipeg, beg to present our Petition for the grant of a Boarding School for the use of the Protestant Indian children in the district.

It is felt to be a necessity that there should be such a Boarding School where these children may be properly kept and educated during the absence of their parents when engaged in following their avocations on the lake or in the forest.

There are some fifty Indian children of school age on the H. Alexander Reserve above who have a claim on the Paternal Government for such care and education.

H. Alexander is a large and important Reservation at the mouth of the Winnipeg River and is worthy of this consideration by the Indian Department.

The proposed site is well adapted for the purpose. It is easy of access by steamers & vessels from all parts of the lake. From its central position it is well situated to benefit other Reserves in the district, as Black River & Hole River to the North, and also Brokenhead River Reserve to the South.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th inst., inclosing a petition from the Indians of the Fort Alexander and neighbouring Indian reserves for the establishment of a Protestant boarding school in their district.

In reply I beg to say that the Department has at present under consideration the whole Indian school policy in the West and, until some definite decision is arrived at, it is not prepared to extend the boarding school system.

With reference to the last paragraph of your letter I would say that the present boarding school on the Fort Alexander reserve is conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church and the attendance is not limited to Treaty children, Non-treaty children being also eligible for admission, but in either case they must be Indians.

WINNIPEG, Man., Jan. 6th, 1911.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Sir,

At a Council of the Indians held at Fort Alexander, Indian Reserve, December 23rd, 1910, the following requests are made; which I hereby transmit for the consideration of the Department.

1. The Protestant Indians request that a Boarding School be built at the upper end of the Reserve to replace the two Day Schools now in operation. The argument used by the Indians is that they move around so much that it is impossible for them to send their children to the Day School to any degree of regularity. They further argue that the Protestants should have equal privilege with the Roman Catholics of the neighborhood.

2. The Band ask that a yoke of oxen be furnished by the Department to the Indians of this Reserve.

3. It is stated that the Agent promised one hundred dollars to build a bridge across the creek known as "The Francois Bruyer Creek" on the East side of the river. It is four years since this promise is said to have been made and so far as known no authority has been issued and it is much needed.

4. Four years ago a ditch was surveyed by Dominion Land Surveyor of Blanchard and it was expected that work on the said ditch would be commenced forthwith, but nothing has been
done. The Council now asks that this work be completed in order to drain the large swamp behind the Reserve as the waters of the swamp are causing the banks to give way and slide into the river. A further reason is that the swamp might be made a hay ground if properly drained and at present there is very little hay ground available.

5. The Indians further ask that permits be issued to them to cut five hundred cords of green wood so as to give them employment because the dry wood has become exhausted.

-----------------------------------------------

1. With reference to the request of the Indians for a Boarding school, I feel confident that the Department will not entertain it when there is a Government school so near at hand, so I find it difficult to endorse their claim. At the same time I recognize the fairness of the request.

2. I am prepared to recommend that a yoke of oxen be given to the Band.

3. The bridge asked for is much needed and will cost $100.00 and I recommend that permission be granted to proceed with this work.

4. Mr. Blanchard's report must decide whether this bridge is necessary or not, but in my judgment it is much needed.

5. I also recommend that permission be granted the Agent to issue permits for five hundred cords of wood as requested.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

John Sommerville

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

J.S./H.

Selkirk, February 14th,

EXTRACT.

On January 24th and 25th I visited Fort Alexander Reserve, and beg to report as follows:

On 25th held Council meeting in school.

The Chief among other things mentioned a subject which I believe has already been placed before the Department viz. The establishment of a boarding school for the children of Protestant parents in this band. I promised that the matter would be brought to the attention of the Department, but held out no hope of the request being granted at present. There are two Protestant Day Schools on this reserve, the one on the south of the river was open had a fair attendance and the children seem to be making good head way. The other school I expect will be opened next week as the teacher, Miss E. Isbister, left Selkirk this morning for Fort Alexander.

In connection with boarding school, Councillor John Henderson said that if they could not have a boarding school the present school should be repaired, as it needed new shingles and an extra ply of boards on the walls as it was very cold. At the time of my visit the roof was covered with snow and I could not judge as to the condition of the shingles. On my next visit the snow will be gone and I will be able to see the shingles also the foundation and will report as to the repairs I believe necessary.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) John Watson,
Indian Agent.

Fairford, Little Saskatchewan and Lake St Martin.

At Lower Fairford, on the north side of the river, the Rev'd Mr Clark, Baptist Missionary, has opened a day school with an attendance of about 15 pupils. Hon. David Laird,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant re the opening of a day school under the Baptist Church auspices on the Lower Fairford Reserve, on the North side of the river, and would say that I am not aware of any authority having been ever given in this connection. The Baptists have located a mission on this reserve at least twelve years ago and there has been no clash between them and the Church of England that I am aware of, and I therefore did not feel like interfering. The establishment of a school is of more recent date, but, as the Inspector says, it seems to have a stimulating effect, and I have not thought it advisable to interfere. No grant is given or asked for, and the Baptists would even seem to object to Government support. I shall be pleased to take my future action according to the wishes of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA, 5th April, 1904:

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the establishment of a day school at Lower Fairfield by the Baptists, the Commissioner reports that he is not aware of any authority having been given to this end. The Baptists have had a mission on the reserve for some years and have apparently worked in harmony with the Church of England, the only other religious denomination carrying on work on the reserve and the Commissioner states that he did not think it advisable to interfere when they established the school.

While this particular case does not call for the interference of the Department, it seems to me that it should not be ignored and the least a religious denomination could do is to ask for permission before establishing themselves on a reserve.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Several years ago the Church of England had a teacher and a catechist at Rock Head, Government paying part of the salary and the Church supplementing the grant. Though we had some specially good men there the work was so discouraging and the Indians so troublesome that on the advice of the Superintendent of Missions, I withdrew from the work. Both the Superintendent and the Missionary advised me to close down the work and leave it closed until the Band would ask that it be resumed. A message has now come to me from the Band pleading that a teacher be sent. We have a good house there, a fair church, and I am told that there is a schoolhouse which is considerably out of repair. I beg to acknowledge receipt of the above noted letter in reference to the need of a day school, Sandy Bay Reserve. In reply I beg to state that I have made a survey of the reserve and have no hesitation in saying that a day school is very necessary as about 50 children of school age cannot be accommodated in the Residential School. The Residential School is located in the centre of the reserve, about two miles from the lake front. A day school should be built close to the school, accommodation could be found for the teacher at the Residential School, but would suggest a teacherage in close proximity to the day school, which should be erected between the Residential School and the Farming Instructional Assistant. The ground is suitable, a well would have to be drilled and the grounds fenced. The estimated cost would be in the neighborhood of $5000.

No building on the reserve is suitable for the purpose. The erection of a day school would not interfere to any great extent with the enrolment at the Residential School, some objections to a day school may be raised by the Church authorities on this point, but the fact remains that the Residential School on the reserve cannot take care of the education of all the children at present of school age. The members of the Sandy Bay Band are Catholic. I believe that this matter came up for consideration some years ago, the School Principal at that time was not in favour of a day school. The matter was talked over between the present Principal and myself, but he would not commit himself except to advise that the matter would be taken up with the Rev. Father Provincial.

Your obedient Servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Re: 126-15-1, Ottawa, Sept. 27th, 1934.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of the above noted letter in reference to the building of a day school at Sandy Bay Reserve. I beg to suggest the North end of the reserve for the proposed day school; several good sites are available, close to Lake Manitoba and situated about the centre of the Northern portion of the reserve.

A school to seat 30 pupils would be required with a teachers residence detached. I would suggest a full basement to the school, the cost would be very little, the basement being used for the seating of the children for their mid-day meal during the winter months. Coal will also have to be used for fuel and timber is getting very limited on this reserve. A heating furnace would have to be installed, a coal boiler.

The school should be about 1½ miles from the Farm Instructor's residence and approximately 2½ miles from the Residential school.

Work could be commenced immediately, the nearest point where materials could be secured would be Portage la Prairie. The work could be done under a white foreman, employing Indian labour.

The teacher's residence would not require a basement as sufficient wood fuel could be secured to heat a small residence.

The building site is in the open, close enough to the lake to secure water with very little trouble. A well would not be required for this school.

The policy of the Department, I think, should be the deciding factor as to the erection of a day school on the Sandy Bay Reserve. If the operation of boarding schools is to be continued, I do not see the necessity of a day school. On the other hand, if the Department is desirous of gradually eliminating boarding schools, a day school would be a step in this direction.

I would, however, draw the Department's attention to the fact that the Sandy Bay Indian Reserve is one of the poorest reserves we have in Manitoba and the Indians are perhaps among the most destitute. If the children were taken out of boarding school and the care and responsibility placed on the parents, it would certainly greatly increase the hardships. Another factor which makes the hardship even greater than it already is the fact that the Indians are obliged to be off the reserve from early spring until late in the fall in order to provide themselves with a living. The Indians leave their reserve for trapping and work out during the summer months for the white farmers throughout the southern part of Manitoba. If the children were not in boarding school, they would unquestionably be with their parents and consequently away from school.

I realise the present boarding school will not accommodate all the pupils on the Sandy Bay Reserve, but I think the policy of the Department should be the deciding factor as to whether this school is to be remodelled and made large enough to accommodate all the children, or whether the

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant informing the Department that the Indians at Swan Lake or Birch River Reserve No. 65 O have asked to have a day school opened on the reserve and that they have put up a log building, which could be used for the purpose, or are prepared to put up another building, if the Depart- ment will furnish lumber, etc., and submit a list of the children that would attend, if the school were established.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is in doubt whether a school at this point would meet with sufficient success to warrant any expenditure being made for the purpose of fitting up a building and paying the salary of a teacher. March 29th, 1922.

My dear Mr. Scott,

I have had another request for the opening of a school at Birch River, and this time it seems to be backed by Mr. Ogletree, the Agent. On a former occasion when the matter came up, the Department did not see its way to taking the matter up because the children were so few in number. The question is now made by them that if our little Church at Birch River could be used for the school the Department might consent to pay a Mrs. A. a small salary for conducting the school. This woman lives on the reserve and, I am assured, is competent to give elementary teaching. The missionary in charge suggests that this might be done as a beginning, and to test the case, I cheerfully consent to allow the Church to be used temporarily provided it is kept clean for the Sunday services, and maintained in good repair.

Mr. Ogletree, your agent at Portage la Prairie, writes strongly opposing the removal of Mr. Hyson from the Improved School at Fairford, and Mr. Hyson himself contends that he is being unfairly treated, and deprecates any action looking towards his removal. I have told him that the Church authorities have made no move against him, but that the Indians have petitioned for his removal. Matters have become so complicated that, under all the circumstances, I think that it would be well to have Mr. Ferrier hold an investigation and report on the matter before steps are taken to remove Mr. Hyson. When I visited Fairford last year, the Indians waited upon me, and urged that a change be made afterwards, as you know, they communicated with the Department on the subject with the result that I was asked by you to look out another place for Mr. Hyson.

Should Mr. Ferrier be coming West to hold an investigation, I should be grateful if he could call to see me about this school, and also about others. With kindest regards, I am,

Most sincerely yours,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.
OTTAWA, April 5th, 1922.

Most Rev. Sir,

I have been directed to acknowledge Your Grace's communication of the 29th ultimo regarding the opening of a school on Birch River Reserve, on Swan Lake, and nominating the services of Mrs. Awdy as teacher.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of giving a school at this point a trial. Its continuance to depend upon the success met with, and the attendance of the Indian children.

The salary we will allow Mrs. Awdy will depend upon the services she performs, and the enrollment.

It is noted that you will allow the church to be used temporarily for classroom purposes.

We will supply a reasonable amount of school material, such as textbooks, stationery, etc., upon receipt of a requisition for the supplies of this nature required. We cannot undertake at the present time to furnish desks, blackboards, etc. However, at a later date, should this school prove a success, we will then consider the question of furnishing these supplies.

We are informing Mr. Agent Ogletree of the approval being granted for the opening of this school.

I will be pleased if you will inform Mrs. Awdy of approval being granted for her to take up duties as teacher at this point, and also request her to prepare a list of the books, stationery, etc., she will require. When this is received by the Department, the supplies asked for will be forwarded.

I will also be pleased if, at a later date, you will inform me as to Mrs. Awdy's Christian name, and the date on which she begins duties.

Your Grace will be advised in a separate communication regarding the case of the Hysom's at Fairford Reserve.

I have the honour to be,

Your Grace's,

Most obedient servant,

Most Rev. S. P. Matheson, D.D.,
Archbishop of Rupert's Land,
Bishop's Court,
Winnipeg, Man.

Re:- Birch River Day School.

My dear Sir:-

In a letter recently received from our Missionary at Shoal River, he has the following to say about the above Day School:

"There are thirteen names on the Register, of these seven are of school age, and five under school age. The average attendance is five.

Mrs Audy is regarded as the Teacher and has taught from March to the present date, with the exception of two weeks.

The school needs slates and pencils, scribblers, lead pencils and five No. 1 Readers. A school Register, blackboard and books of simple arithmetic. Biscuits should also be provided.

The present Teacher, Mrs Audy, is an Indian woman; her knowledge of English is meagre, and her ability to teach limited, but she is able to fill the bill at the present time. Her salary should be about $15 per month and should be paid direct to the Missionary at Shoal River.

Personally, my own opinion is that these children should be made to attend school at Shoal River, or sent to a Boarding school."

The above was received after a visit paid to Birch River at our request, and we feel that the information will be of value to you.

I am, Very sincerely yours,

Archdeacon.

My Dear Commissioner:

In accordance with my promise, I visited the Reserve at Birch River on Wednesday last and now beg to report thereon.

After holding a Service at which about forty persons were present, I talked with them on the subject of their children's education. There is no doubt at all that they are sincere and unanimous in a desire to have a Day School opened in their midst. About three years ago, and on the recommendation of Mr. Ogletree, they put up the logs for a building in the belief that a school was about to be opened. The logs still stand, and the men are ready at any time to complete the building, in fact I am confident that they are prepared to do everything within their power if only a School can be established for the education of their children. In this they are undoubtedly sincere. I took a census of the children and found them to number in all 27, sixteen of them being of school age. They are entirely illiterate, not one being able to read or write, and having no opportunities their general intelligence appears to be of a low grade. I spoke to
the parents on the subject of Elkhorn but it did not appeal to them at all, chiefly because it was an unknown place to them and because of its distance.

While I am absolutely with you in a desire to maintain the enrollment at Elkhorn, yet I honestly think that this is a place from which we cannot, at the present time, expect to obtain any support. The children are too illiterate, their parents are frightened with the thought of parting with them, the distance from the Reserve to the Railway is great, the means of communication are practically nil, and for these several reasons I earnestly hope that you will favour the opening of a Day School at this place.

If such should be your decision, and I greatly hope it will, then I will advance the work in every possible way, and will nominate a well-trained teacher who has taken her course at St. Christopher's College, Blackheath, and whose training in the Froebel system makes her specially suitable for this particular place.

I am, dear Commissioner Graham,

Ever sincerely yours.

— Brandon.

Dear Mr. Scott:

While in Brandon recently attending the Bull Sale, I met His Lordship, the Bishop of Brandon, who discussed with me the matter of establishing an Indian Day School on the Birch River Reserve. I told him I was of the opinion that we should put forth every effort to recruit the children from this reserve for the Elkhorn Residential School, and that Day Schools were, generally speaking, not a success. I asked the Bishop when he next visited the reserve to go into the matter fully and ascertain if we could not get these parents to support the Elkhorn School by sending their children to that point. I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter which I have just received from him, from which you will see that he has not been very successful.

I am still of the opinion that the children from this reserve should be sent to Elkhorn, however. When the Brandon children leave Elkhorn, this school will be short of pupils, and I think it is up to the Department to assist the Principal and keep this school up to strength, as I consider it one of the best schools we have.

My dear Sir,

There are several hundred Indians living in the neighbourhood of Portage la Prairie in this Province. They are very poor and have been brought to Christianity through the efforts of the Church. They have no money but they do not want it. They live by working for farmers and doing any work they can get about the town. In summer they camp in the neighbourhood of Portage la Prairie and in winter they live in the woods to the southeast of the town. Our Church would like to begin a School for the benefit of the children and we are anxious to hear in prospect to rent a building. We are willing to pay something reasonable to get a good teacher and my object now is to ascertain what the Department can do to help us in this work. Our aim is to rent a room in Portage la Prairie for the summer and put an efficient teacher in charge and if the School is at all successful as we hope to have a building erected in the woods where the Indians camp for the winter so that School may be maintained its clear record. If the Indian population are to learn to be a menace to the peace
The proper of the County they must be Christianized and educated & the best hope is with the Chiefs and here our desire that they might be educated. Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of above date asking for a report with reference to an application you have received from the Rev. Mr Hines through Mr T.O. Davis, M.P., relative to reopening of the Indian School at Cumberland in the Pas Agency.

I have the honor to report that I do not think it advisable to reopen this School until the Indians decide to remain permanently on the Reserve, the School was closed before through lack of attendance and up to the present time I cannot see that the conditions have altered in any way, at times the Indians may promise to remain on the Reserve but they soon change their minds and scatter to their hunting and fishing grounds, in the summer they congregate for a short time on the Reserve and then disband for the balance of the year, some go to Sturgeon River, some to Pine Bluff, and a few who cannot hunt remain on the Reserve, the Indians of this Band depend almost entirely on hunting and fishing for a living.

The Secretary.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
they do not care for cattle and the few they had we have had to take away from them as they would not take care of them, the soil of the Reserve is poorly adapted for gardening and but little is done in this respect, it is the policy of The Hudson Bay Company to keep the Indians of the Saskatchewan out on the hunting grounds and this Band is particularly under this influence and really I cannot see that there is anything else for them to do as they cannot make a living on the Reserve.

The Indian Day School at its best is a very poor institution and when the children cannot attend regularly it is money thrown away to try to teach them, if they are absent but a short time they appear to forget all they had previously learned.

I may say that I have had a conversation with Mr Hines about this matter and I informed him that I would ask that a sum be placed in the estimates next year to reopen the School and it could be used providing by that time the Indians had settled down on the Reserve, but that nothing could be done this year, as no provision had been made to pay a Teacher.

I might add that there is a School on the Reserve supported by the Government of the N.W.T., it is for the benefit of the Half-breeds, but Mr Hines objects to the Indian Children attending, on the ground that it is a Catholic School.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your No. 1617-116 of the first instant, referring to the request of Archdeacon J. A. MacKay that the school being built at Pine Bluff be undenominational. I have noted the enclosed correspondence and I approve of your letter in this connection.

The history of school activities at Cumberland House is, to the best of information at my disposal, as follows: The Hudson Bay Factor was interested in a school in 1894 at Cumberland House and the Rev. J. Hines, Church of England Clergyman, in 1899. From 1909 to 1917, the Bishop of Saskatchewan was responsible for the Church of England Indian Day School that operated at Cumberland House. There has been no school for the Indians of this locality since the Church of England school closed in 1917. At that time, it appears that there was a migration of half the band from the vicinity of Cumberland Post Office to Pine Bluff.

The information contained in your No. 1481-116, of the 3rd of December, last, is that there are 17 R. C. children of school age at Pine Bluff and that the people still resident at Cumberland House will, in all probability, move to the first named site in the future.

Before the Department goes on record in connection with the future of this school, I would be glad if you could give me what available information you have concerning the religious belief of those resident at Pine Bluff and the faith of those that you believe will move there in the immediate future.

You will remember that the Department is at present sanctioning the R. C. management of the school now under construction.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

The school at this is a very poor building. It is far too small for the number of children that could go to school. This building is only 18 by 16. Now this Band is made up of Methodists and Roman Catholics about evenly divided. They have about 200 children or school age. This I know as I got them all together and counted them. Nearly all these children have to go to their parents' hunting grounds, let us say in September and they do not return till the beginning of June or the end of May. All those that are left around the Mission are those whose parents work for their living by driving dogs etc., so that there are only a few children left to go to school, so few that they can be taught in the kitchen of the Missionary's house. That is why they are asking for a Boarding School, so that they can leave their children at school, knowing at the same time that they are not far away from them. REPORT OF VISIT TO NELSON HOUSE
on the Lake Winnipeg District.

I left Brandon in a motor car Monday, July 8th at 9 A.M., for Neepawa and from there to the Pas by Canadian Northern Railway passing through Dauphin, Swan River, and Hudson Bay Junction; from the Pas by the Hudson Bay Railroad, a Government road, to Mile 137; then to Nelson House a journey of three days in a canoe, arriving at 10 P.M., Friday, July 12th.

On Saturday we held a meeting of the Chief, Council and an audience of about three hundred people at which we discussed the education of their children and the building of a boarding school that would accommodate thirty pupils in residence. The discussion proceeded under the following heads:

1. Should a boarding school be built?
2. The impossibility of the Government building during war time.
3. Where should the school be built? 1st.- Mile 137 or some point on the Hudson Bay railway. 2nd.- On the present mission property. 3rd.- Some other point on the Reserve or some site near the Reserve.

The people were unanimous on the question of building the school. They were also unanimous that it be built on the Reserve only one man seemed to be in favor of the railroad. If built there little or no help would be received from the people. It would require separate staff to run it. The objections of the people would be raised if it was too far away as a reason for non-support. I suggested to the Chief that the best place to build was on the present mission property so that it could be under the eye and care of our missionary. The children and staff would also be convenient for service. The class-room could be used for worship on extreme cold days or when only a few people were home. There is also quite a bit of good land ready for gardening.

The following conditions were unanimously agreed to and a document containing them signed by the Chief and two Councillors on behalf of the people. Nearly a hundred men subscribed their names to the paper pledging to do their bit.

1. That we will furnish all the logs and lumber of every kind that can be furnished in the community for the construction of the building.
2. We will prepare the site, dig the cellar and put in the foundation.
3. We will furnish all the labor required to put up the building.
4. We will supply all the furniture for the dormitory, beds, chairs, benches, tables, etc.

5. We will freight all the material supplied by the Methodist Church for the building and furnish the same from Mile 137 free of charge.

6. We promise to keep attendance of the school up to thirty pupils.

7. We will furnish all the fuel required for the heating of the building and cooking, free of charge.

8. That those having children attending the school shall furnish fish and native food for the same to the best of their ability also choose skins for mocassins for their own children, free of charge.

9. That all others will supply native food and skins for mocassins at fair cash prices. It is understood that the great bulk of food is to be secured from the lake, forest, and land, the boys assisting in the working of the gardens on the half day policy.

10. The people who have children attending school to assist to freight food and supplies from Mile 137 free of charge.

On behalf of the Methodist Church we promised the following:

1. We will provide for the building, windows, doors, roofing, nails and all material of every kind not available in the community.

2. We will provide one good mechanic to oversee the construction of the building.

3. We will provide rations of tea, sugar and flour if allowed by the Food Controller, to those who help to construct the building and freight the supplies from Mile 137 and provide lumber and logs.

4. We will supply stoves, kitchen range, dishes, cooking utensils and all furniture necessary for the staff quarters.

5. The management of the school to be under a missionary who shall be principal. A matron shall have oversight and responsibility for the welfare of the children and care of the building. A properly qualified teacher, one other male assistant to the principal.

The building to be sixty feet and to be known as a log building with ample accommodation for thirty pupils and the staff. To accomplish the above the Church has made a grant of $2,000.00 and the Woman's Missionary Society $1,000.00.
The Church was filled to overflowing at each of the three services on the Sabbath. At the afternoon service four children were presented for Christian baptism and the Sacrament of the Lord's Supper administered to about one hundred and eight. Forty of these came for the first time in response to an invitation to yield themselves to the Lord for an effort to lead the Christian life. The most of the forty were young men and women from fifteen to twenty years of age. The spirit and result of these services or the Sabbath were sufficient encouragement for the journey from Brandon to Nelson House.

On Monday Mr. McDonald, Indian Agent from the Pas paid the Annual Treaty of five dollars to each man, woman and child, and fifteen dollars to each Councilor and twenty-five dollars to the Chief, paying a total of two thousand, four hundred and forty dollars to four hundred and eighty treaty Indians. The entire population being over five hundred people. Many sports were enjoyed. Special mention might be made of two canoe races and a sack race. Twenty-one dollars were distributed in prizes. We spent Tuesday with the people, marrying four couples and holding a farewell service with the people.

The work of our missionary is greatly appreciated by the people and a very friendly spirit exists between him and his flock. The mode of living is by fishing, hunting, gardening, freighting; and many of the men are getting employment on the construction of the Hudson Bay Railway. Many of the people have gardens. The homes are kept neat and clean and altogether they are a very progressive, independent, fine band of Indians. This is shown by the work they are undertaking towards the construction of a school for the education of their children.

Before closing, I wish to make mention of the very efficient, faithful and much needed work of Miss Alice H. Jackson as missionary nurse, an agent of the W. M. S. of our Church. It is one of those illustrations of how much can be accomplished by a consecrated woman going in and out of the houses of the people, dispensing medicine, helping the sick and instructing the women on the necessity of keeping their homes in a sanitary condition. She also teaches how to care for the young children and many other minor instructions that cannot be accomplished by a male missionary, among a tribe not many generations removed from heathenism. The boat provided with the small gasoline engine is of great service in reaching those who need her care and attentions.

This work is of such importance and necessity that someone should be provided to continue it when Miss Jackson goes out on furlough.

Too much praise and support cannot be given to those who so unselfishly give their lives by going to these far away fields and labor for the extension of the Kingdom among our native people.
On Mr. Butty's return from the East he has brought the war conditions and needs of the Allies before the people. At one of the Sunday services I spoke to them of the food situation. Before leaving Mr. Butty handed me three hundred dollars as their contribution to the Red Cross, which was contributed by the band assisted by the traders and other white people attending Treaty. The request is made that this contribution shall be given to the General Board of Missions in trust with the understanding that if in their judgment there is any war fund more needed and which would be more appropriate for their offering to be given to, this should be done. If not, then it is to be given to the Red Cross Fund.

One Wednesday we called at the Treaty ground, married two more couples and I started to shake hands with the people. Our interpreter requested me to stand while the people came to me. After shaking hands with about four hundred we stood surrounded amid the waving of handkerchiefs, hand full of hands and firing of guns and rifles, feeling thankful that we had been honored with such a generous welcome, such kind hospitality and spontaneous farewell from these people of the forest in our most northerly mission.
Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Ottawa, Canada.

Sir,

His Lordship Bishop Charlebois, Le Pas, has requested that a grant for teacher's salary be provided for a day school which he states has been in existence during the last two or three years at Lac des Brochets. The school has been conducted by Rev. Father Egenolf, O.M.I., and his assistant Rev. Brother Drouin. He states that there is an average of 20 pupils in attendance, and that the results obtained at the present time are very satisfactory and encouraging, and that the R.C. Mission has, up to the present time, undertaken all expenses in connection with the school.

I have to request that you will be good enough to instruct the paying officer for Treaty #10, on the occasion of his next visit to the place, to visit the school and make a report upon the work being performed. His Lordship was informed that the providing of the grant for teacher's salary would depend upon the reports received as to the work being performed. I will, therefore, be pleased if you will have the paying officer furnish a report upon his return, which you will be good enough to forward to the Department with any views you care to make regarding the Bishop's request.

Dear Sir,

In accordance with your request for a report on R. C. Mission School at Brochet, Sask., I talked this matter over with Father Eganolf, who is in charge, and obtained information as follows—

When in session school class is quartered in the largest room in the Mission House about 20' x 18' in dimension. There is no other suitable building or room now available, but a separate and complete boarding school building is planned for next spring as this room is hardly large enough to accommodate all, and is becoming a bit cramped with the increase of students. About half the timber for this school has already been hewed and is on the grounds. With a larger school—boarding school—attendance will undoubtedly increase as many would-be students are unable to attend on account of the itinerant life their parents are forced to lead in this country. The school, such as it is, has been in session intermittently for 3 years; more regular of late. The students are allowed 14 months vacation in summer, commencing June 10th, this year, and one week at Xmas.

The teaching up to the present time has been done almost entirely by Brother Urbain Drouin. He speaks Cree, Chippewyan, English and French, and I should judge is quite capable. The children are all taught Cree, and some English. Their English vocabulary is taught from "De La Salle Reader" Parts 1 and 2, by phonetic system. They are also taught elementary arithmetic, spelling, geography, writing and reading. The majority of students now in attendance are half-breeds. The school attendance since opening has fluctuated a bit, but has averaged about twenty for the three years since its opening. At the present time there are twenty-five students of school age, who attend regularly; Chippewyan boys attend regularly during the summer, but absent all winter. Father Eganolf informs me that twenty-five is about the average number of children of school age resident here, but this will be doubled on completion of Boarding School. The ages of school children now in attendance ranges from 7 to 14, and there are 17 boys and 8 girls.

Hoping this report meets with your approval,

I remain,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Bartlett:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, with reference to Miss Helen McKay, teacher at the Birtle Indian Residential School. Employees at these institutions are not recognized as Civil Servants in any sense of the term; they are employed and paid by the church or the school management. There is, therefore, no Government provision for pension or gratuity upon retirement. Teachers of Indian day schools rank as temporary Civil Servants, and a small gratuity is allowed them after years of service. Even they cannot profit by the Civil Servant Superannuation scheme, as they do not contribute to the fund.
