Dear Sir,

I am writing to ask you if you will very kindly take up the cause of certificated teachers employed in the Indian Schools receiving grants from the Dominion government. Such teachers are not included in the Saskatchewan Teachers' Superannuation Act of 1930. In Section 3, it is stated that the act applies only to teachers employed in those schools "receiving grants from the Province of Saskatchewan."

Since your appointment in 1921 as Superintendent of Indian Education in the Dominion, it has been your aim to raise Indian Schools to the same educational standing as the white schools.

If certificated teachers employed in the Indian Schools are excluded from all superannuation benefits, it will eventually mean a falling in the status and educational standing of the schools under your supervision. I wonder if such a clause is in the Teachers' Superannuation Act in other Provinces. I have
not been able to ascertain
that information.

It seems most unjust that
Certificated Indian teachers should
go through the same educational
preparatory training, follow
the same course of study, (as
far as possible) be under the
same inspectorate, as the
teachers in white schools, and
yet should not receive the same
pecuniary benefits.

From personal experience I
know Indian teaching is a far
greater tension on the health
and nervous system, and the
teachers on Reserves are deprived
of social and educational
privileges.

You will understand how I
feel about Section 3.
I taught in England as a
Certificated teacher in Government
schools for 13 years, and paid
the Superannuation Premium for
that period.
I took Second Class Normal
at Saskatoon 1912, and then
taught in a white school for one
year.
In response to the late Ven.
Archdeacon McKay's appeal for
teachers to go into the Indian
work, I went to Lac la Ronge.
as senior teacher for a salary of $300.

If no certificated teachers had responded in the pioneer days, the Indians would not have been able to hold their own, and be intelligent self-supporting citizens of the province as they are today. May I give some instances of girl pupils, whose parents lived in tepees at Lac la Ronge.

Victoria gained her Second Class teachers' certificate, and is now married to a white clergyman engaged in the Indian work, and Jennie has been on the staff of the Indian Residential School at Stoney Lookout for more than 2 years. When she came to see me in August, on her way home for the summer vacation, I reflected on her happy, intelligent countenance; she was so enthusiastic in her work. She stated in a letter, "I received a few days ago, 'I'm going to like it too much, that I won't be able to leave it'." Both girls had innate musical ability, and were able to play the organ at the Sunday services.

Another pupil, to whom I taught music, bought a small portable organ, and carried it in the canoe.
as they travelled from camp to camp. She eventually offered to return to school, and help the kitchen matron, if I would continue to give her music lessons. She did splendid work for many years, and then married a white man in a good position.

I have not been able to resume teaching owing to continued ill-health, so I wrote to the superannuation commission, applying for the allowance for ill-health, and I received the following reply—The act applies only to teachers employed in those schools, receiving grants from the Province.

Thanking you in advance,

Yours respectfully,

Kate Le Clair.

CHAPTER 93

[Assented to April 10, 1930.]

An Act respecting the Superannuation of Teachers.

His Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Legislative Assembly of Saskatchewan, enacts as follows:

SHORT TITLE.

1. This Act may be cited as The Teachers' Superannuation Act, 1930.

INTERPRETATION.

2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires, the Interpretation expression:

1. "Commission" means The Teachers' Superannuation Commission appointed under the authority of this Act;

2. "Fund" means The Teachers' Superannuation Fund established under the authority of this Act;

3. "Minister" means the Minister of Education;

4. "Regulations" means regulations made under the authority of this Act;

5. "Salary" means the regular salary of a teacher, together with the value of residential allowances and of emoluments, perquisites and privileges incidental to the position, as determined by the commission, but not payment for janitor work or overtime or any other extra allowance or payment or any gratuity;

6. "Service" or "Teaching Service" means service rendered in teaching or in the supervision of teaching under a public education system, by a person duly certified in accordance with the regulations of the Department of Education of Saskatchewan.
3. This Act shall apply to teachers actually employed in teaching or in the supervision of teaching on or after the coming into force of the Act in those schools receiving grants from the Province of Saskatchewan.

4. This Act shall be administered by a commission attached to the Department of Education, to be known as "The Teachers' Superannuation Commission," which shall consist of five members to be appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council who shall hold office for a period of two years, one of whom shall be a woman, to be appointed by the executive committees of such provincial teachers' organisations as the minister may designate who shall hold office for a period of three years, and the fifth member to be appointed by the four members so appointed and who shall hold office for a period of three years.

5.—(1) One of the commissioners shall be appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council to be the chairman of the commission who shall hold office while he remains a member of the commission.

(2) The Lieutenant Governor in Council shall also appoint a commissioner as acting chairman who shall have all the powers and perform all the duties of the chairman in his absence.

6. In the case of the death, illness or absence from Saskatchewan of a commissioner or his inability to act from any cause, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may appoint some person to act pro tempore in his stead, and the person so appointed shall have all the powers and perform all the duties of a commissioner.

7. A member shall on the expiration of his term of office be eligible for re-appointment.

8. The pecuniary allowances to be made to the commissioners for their services shall be fixed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council and shall be payable out of the fund as part of the administration expenses of the commission.

9. Three commissioners shall be necessary to constitute a quorum of the commission.

10. Vacancies in the commission shall not, if there remain three members of it, impair the authority of such three members to act.

11. The minister may authorise the appointment of such clerical assistants as may be required for the administration of this Act.

12. The expenses of administration including the necessary salaries shall be paid out of the legislative appropriation for education and shall be charged to the fund.

SUPERANNUATION FUND.

13.—(1) There shall be a fund to be known as "The Teachers' Superannuation Fund" into which shall be paid all contributions made by teachers under this Act and such amounts as may be payable by the Provincial Treasurer in accordance with subsection (2) of this section, together with accruals of interest.

(2) There shall be paid into the fund by the Provincial Treasurer such further sums as may be necessary to provide for the superannuation allowances, refunds and other payments required by this Act. Such sums shall not be less in amount than twenty-five per cent of the annual contributions made by the teachers, provided that such sums shall be paid only when there are not sufficient moneys, computed on an actuarial basis, at the credit of the fund to meet all charges which may be made thereon. Such sums shall be a charge upon and paid out of the consolidated fund.

(3) All superannuation allowances, payments and refunds shall be a charge on and payable out of the fund.

(4) The fund shall be held in trust by the Provincial Treasurer and shall be invested by him from time to time in such securities as are authorised by The Trustee Act for the investment of trust funds and approved by the Treasury Board.

TEACHING SERVICE.

14.—(1) Except as herein otherwise provided all service shall be continuous and the following shall be reckoned for the purposes of this Act:

(a) service in Saskatchewan after the coming into force of this Act;

(b) service prior to the coming into force of this Act;

(i) in Saskatchewan;

(ii) in that part of the North West Territories now included in Saskatchewan;
(iii) under any other public education system in the British Empire for any period up to ten years, where at least ten years service has been rendered in Saskatchewan;

Provided that clause (b) shall apply only in the case of teachers employed in Saskatchewan at the time this Act comes into force and to teachers then unemployed whose continuity of service has not been broken.

(2) Continuity of service shall not be deemed to be broken by:

(a) absence on leave;
(b) absence due to sickness;
(c) absence due to the pursuit of studies appertaining to the teaching profession;
(d) temporary unemployment as a teacher;
(e) absence for any other reason satisfactory to the commission;

provided such absence or unemployment has not exceeded twelve consecutive months.

(3) Such periods of absence or unemployment shall be reckoned as service for the purposes of this Act only where contributions have been made, as herein provided.

15.—(1) Employment in any capacity other than as a teacher or in the supervision of teaching for any period in excess of twelve consecutive months, whether before or after the coming into force of this Act, or employment as a teacher for a like period outside of Saskatchewan after this Act comes into force, shall void all claim to prior service.

(2) Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (1) a woman teacher who, while teaching in Saskatchewan left the profession on account of marriage, and returned thereto owing to the death or illness or physical or mental incapacity of her husband, or for other reasons satisfactory to the commission, shall subject to the provisions of this Act and the regulations be entitled to have her prior service reckoned for the purpose of computing any allowance to which she may become entitled.

(3) Where the provisions of subsection (2) apply, and in case a refund of contributions has been made under section 28 hereof the service to be reckoned shall be limited to service prior to the coming into force of this Act unless such refunded contributions are repaid to the fund.

16. Service in His Majesty's forces during the Great War and where enlistment took place from the teaching profession or normal schools in Saskatchewan and the person enlisting returned to the teaching profession prior to May 1, 1925, shall be reckoned as teaching service.

17. Service with the Department of Education of such classes of employees as may be determined by the regulations, whether before or after the coming into force of this Act, if such service is continuous with teaching service, shall be reckoned as service for the purposes of this Act.

18. Subject to the provisions of section 19 hereof no period of service in excess of thirty-five years shall be reckoned in computing superannuation allowances.

Contributions.

19.—(1) Every teacher shall contribute to the fund four per cent. of his salary after this Act comes into force.

(2) The boards of trustees of all school districts shall deduct four per cent. from the salaries of all teachers employed by them.

(3) The minister shall cause to be withheld from the grants payable to boards of trustees of school districts an amount equal to four per cent. of the salaries of all teachers employed by them and shall cause such amounts to be paid into the fund semi-annually.

(4) A teacher who has thirty-five years service to his credit shall not be required to make any further contribution to the fund, but may continue to contribute in case his retiring allowance, if he were then retired, would be less than the maximum payable under this Act, and such additional contributions shall be reckoned in computing his superannuation allowance upon retirement.

20.—(1) A teacher who, for any period not in excess of twelve consecutive months, has been absent without pay for any of the reasons specified in subsection (2) of section 14, or temporarily unemployed, may make such payments after his return or re-employment as a teacher, as shall be equal to such sums as would have been deducted had his salary been paid during his absence or unemployment as the case may be.

(2) A teacher who has been granted leave of absence on part pay may make such payments after his return as are required to make his contribution for the period of absence the same as would have been deducted had he been in receipt of his full salary.
21. In the event of the appointment of a teacher to the Department of Education, all contributions paid by him to, and standing to his credit in the fund, together with accruals of interest, shall be transferred to and form part of the consolidated fund.

22. When, in addition to a cash salary, a teacher enjoys living or residential allowances or other emoluments, perquisites or privileges incidental to his office, the commission may determine the value of such allowances or of such other emoluments, perquisites or privileges.

SUPERANNUATION ALLOWANCE.

23.—(1) Subject to the provisions of this Act and the regulations, a yearly superannuation allowance shall be granted to:

(a) every teacher who has served as such for twenty years or more and who makes written application for such superannuation allowance at any time after attaining the age of sixty years;

(b) every woman teacher who has served as such for thirty-five years or more and who makes written application for such superannuation allowance at any time after attaining the age of fifty-five years;

(c) every teacher who has served as such for fifteen years or more, at least two-thirds of such service having been rendered in Saskatchewan, and who makes written application to be superannuated because of ill health or physical or mental incapacity.

(2) Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (1) no superannuation allowance shall be granted for a period of six months after the coming into force of this Act.

24. Where a teacher makes application for superannuation on account of ill health or physical or mental incapacity, the physical or mental condition of such person shall be established by the certificate of a medical practitioner nominated by the commission or by such further evidence as may be satisfactory to the commission.

25. The commission shall review from time to time the case of a teacher superannuated on account of ill-health or physical or mental incapacity and on his recovery his allowance shall cease unless he has in the meantime reached the age of retirement.

26.—(1) In the event of a teacher making application to be superannuated under clause (a) of subsection (1) of section 23, where the opinion of the commission is capable of obtaining employment other than as a teacher, his allowance may be reduced in the discretion of the commission.

(2) Where a teacher who has been superannuated on account of ill health or physical or mental incapacity obtains employment other than as a teacher his allowance shall cease or may be reduced in the discretion of the commission.

(3) Where a teacher who has been superannuated on account of ill health or physical or mental incapacity is re-employed as a teacher his allowance shall cease and the time during which such re-employment continues shall be reckoned in determining his final superannuation allowance, but the period of incapacity shall not be counted.

AMOUNTS OF ALLOWANCES.

27.—(1) The superannuation allowance payable hereunder shall be calculated upon the average yearly salary of the teacher during the five consecutive years of highest salary while employed in Saskatchewan and shall be one-fiftieth part of such salary multiplied by the total number of his years of service and any fraction of a year, provided that said allowance shall in no case exceed the sum of $2,000 per annum.

(2) In no case shall a superannuation allowance granted under this Act be less than $360 per annum.

MISCELLANEOUS.

28.—(1) Subject to the provisions of subsection (2) a teacher who leaves the profession before becoming eligible for a superannuation allowance, shall, upon written application to the commission, be entitled to receive;

(a) all contributions made by him to the fund, except those of the first year;

(b) accrued interest thereon.

(2) No refund of contributions or interest shall be made in the case of a teacher who has less than three years service.

(3) If a teacher dies before becoming eligible for a superannuation allowance all payments made by him to the fund, except those of the first year of contribution shall, together with accruals of interest thereon, be paid to his personal representative or nominee.
29.—(1) Where a teacher is superannuated at any time within three years after the coming into force of this Act, there shall be deducted from the annual amount of his superannuation allowance and paid into the fund, at such time or times and in such manner as shall be determined by the regulations, an amount equal to four per cent. of his annual salary at the date of superannuation.

(2) No such deductions shall be made after the lapse of three years from the coming into force of this Act.

30.—(1) The payment of any benefit under this Act or of any expense incurred in its administration, shall be made upon a requisition in writing, signed by the chairman of the commission, directing the issue of a check by the Provincial Treasurer for the amount named in the requisition. Such direction shall be final and conclusive.

(2) Checks shall be signed by the Deputy Provincial Treasurer and the Provincial Auditor, or by such other officials as may be designated for the purpose by the Treasury Board.

31. The Provincial Auditor shall conduct a continuous audit of the affairs of the commission.

32. Where a question arises as to the application of this Act, or as to the period or periods of service to be reckoned for the purposes thereof, it shall be determined by the commission.

33. Interest shall be calculated at the rate of five per cent. per annum or such other rate as may from time to time be prescribed by the Treasury Board, compounded half-yearly.

34. Any payments to be made under the provisions of this Act, shall be exempt from provincial and municipal taxes, and shall not be subject to garnishment or attachment or seizure or any legal process, and shall be unassignable.

35. The commission may, from time to time, with the approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council, make regulations for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this Act, according to their true intent and meaning, and such regulations shall have the same force and effect as if incorporated herein.

36.—(1) The commission shall, each year, transmit to the president of the Executive Council a report showing:

(a) the names of all teachers who have been superannuated or who have died during the last preceding fiscal year;

(b) the positions held by them or the nature of their employment respectively;

(c) the amount of salary payable to each at the time of superannuation or death, and the average of the five consecutive years of highest salary;

(d) the age of each at superannuation or death;

(e) the cause of superannuation in the case of retirement before attaining the age of sixty years in the case of men or fifty-five years in the case of women;

(f) the amount of superannuation or other allowance granted in each case;

(g) all regulations made under this Act;

(h) the expenses incurred in the administration of this Act;

(i) any other information considered necessary to make the report complete.

(2) The president of the Executive Council shall lay the commission's report before the Legislative Assembly during the first fifteen days of each three-year session, or within fifteen days after its receipt, if the Legislature is then sitting, together with a complete statement of the financial standing of the fund for the preceding fiscal year showing the moneys withheld from school grants as contributions by teachers and moneys paid out in respect of allowances or refunds of contributions.

37. This Act shall come into force on the first day of July, 1930.

Dear Mr. Ball:

I have your letter of the first instant, enclosing copy of the Provincial Teachers' Superannuation Act and requesting information concerning the superannuation of teachers at Indian schools. In reply I have to state that teachers at Indian residential schools are not employees of the Department of Indian Affairs. They are engaged by the Reverend Principal or by the Church which is directly responsible for the management of the particular institution.

Teachers of Indian day schools are classed as temporary Civil Servants and, as such, do not come under the Superannuation Act for permanent employees of the Federal Government. It is true that a few of these workers give many years of service and it is a matter of regret that a pension cannot be allowed. I may say, however, that most of the teachers of Indian day schools who give long years of service are in Holy Orders and the Department believes that the churches concerned should be responsible for their care during their old age and that they should not become a charge on public funds.

To recapitulate, there are few lay workers who give long years of service at Indian day schools. They do not come under the federal employees' superannuation scheme.

It would be a source of much satisfaction to this Department if the Saskatchewan statute could be amended to include these few lay workers. The Ontario Department of Education is considering an amendment to their Act. They hope to include Ontario qualified teachers who are teaching in Indian schools in Ontario which are regularly inspected by provincial officers.

Yours very truly,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Report of Actuary

The Ontario Teachers' and Inspectors' Superannuation Act could be amended so as to extend its full benefits and privileges to properly qualified teachers in Ontario Indian Schools, provided that:

(i) The Dominion Government pays into the Superannuation Fund for each teacher now in these Indian Schools, that sum of money which the next valuation will show that the Province holds as a reserve for one of its own teachers of similar age and service and salary.

(ii) The Dominion Government pays into the Superannuation Fund each August a sum of money equal to 2½% of the aggregate salaries of qualified Indian School teachers during the preceding school year plus one year's interest at 4¾%.

(iii) Each qualified Indian School teacher pays 2½% of all salary received, this percentage to be deducted from each salary payment by the payer and to be subsequently paid at the end of each school year into the Superannuation Fund.

(iv) All other requirements of the Teachers' and Inspectors' Superannuation Act are complied with.

The Province will make no charge for operating expenses in reference to such Indian School teachers, and the Fund will assume the additional liability created by previous Indian School service which has been given by some of our regular teachers now in Ontario schools.

The Honorable The Superintendent General,

I have your memorandum of the 27th instant, enclosing letter received from the Minister of Education for the Province of Saskatchewan, with reference to the superannuation of teachers of Indian day schools.

I would recommend that Honourable Mr. Estey be informed of the difficulties that would be presented if this Department arranged for placing teachers of Indian day schools in Saskatchewan under the Provincial Teachers' Superannuation Act and that, under these circumstances, this Department is not prepared, at the present time, to take any action in the matter.

Regina, March 23, 1936.

Dear Sir:

We have, in this Province, a number of schools for the instruction of Indian children maintained by your Department. In these schools you now require a teacher to have a first class certificate as obtained in the Province of Saskatchewan.

These teachers are not accorded the privilege of joining any superannuation scheme, either Federal or Provincial. I enclose to you herewith a copy of The Teachers' Superannuation Act which obtains in this Province. Under the terms of this Act a portion of the teacher's salary is deducted and paid into a Fund and the Government of this Province has a statutory liability thereto as fixed by section 12.

Section 3 applies to all persons teaching in the Province of Saskatchewan in schools that receive grants from the Province. This Province makes no contribution to the Indian schools and therefore the Act does not apply to teachers therein.

Under section 13 provisions are set out for the computation of teaching service which may be included in determining the amount of superannuation. This Act, not applying to the Indian schools, teachers who teach therein for a period and then return to teaching in the public school find that they must again start building up a superannuation fund. If they have taught in the Indian school for any length of time you can appreciate the seriousness of the position from the teachers' point of view.

A number of church officials and teachers in Indian schools have urged upon me from time to time the unfair position in which the teacher in the Indian school is placed. The matter has, upon previous occasions, been brought to the attention of your Department and the answer has been to the effect that teachers in Indian schools are not civil servants within the meaning of your Act and therefore no superannuation fund is provided.

I am disposed to agree that the teacher in the Indian school is placed in an unfair position. We cannot amend our Act to effectively cover the situation unless your Government is prepared to make an appropriate contribution to our Superannuation Fund.
I am therefore placing before you the representations which have been made to me and urging upon you that you give favourable consideration to the end that the teacher in the Indian school may be relieved of the unfair position in which that teacher is placed today.

Yours very truly,

Re: Superannuation Fund for Teachers in Indian Schools

Dear Mr. Estey:

Your letter of March 13, addressed to the Honourable J. G. Gardiner, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch inform me that, in response to requests received from Indian day school teachers, the claims of these teachers for the creation of a Superannuation Act, or an arrangement whereby they would qualify for superannuation under the provincial acts now in force, have been very carefully and very sympathetically reviewed during the last year. The officials, however, are of the opinion that the difficulties standing in the way of superannuation allowances for teachers are almost insurmountable.

We have at this date a pupil enrolment at Indian schools of approximately 15,287. Of these pupils 8,297 are enrolled at Indian day schools and 9,040 at residential schools. Teachers employed at Indian residential schools are the employees of the churches under the auspices of which the schools are operated. These teachers can be considered in no sense government employees. In the case of Indian day school teachers, about 60% are nominated by the church authorities and these nominations in each case are approved by the Department. The salaries of Indian day school teachers are paid in full by the Government, although in a number of cases a teacher, in addition

Honourable J. W. Estey, B.A., LL.B., K.C.,
Minister of Education,
Regina, Sask.
to his regular classroom duties, acts as a missionary on the reserve. Indian day school teachers are classified therefore as temporary civil servants. It is estimated that 40% of the temporary employees of the Government in all the services throughout the Dominion do not qualify for superannuation. In this respect, Indian day school teachers do not differ from the Dominion temporary employees in other branches of the public service. In view of the fact that the average length of service rendered by a teacher in an Indian day school does not exceed five years, it is very difficult for me to see how we could extend to them the benefits of a superannuation act and withhold such benefits from the other temporary employees of the Government.

The main difficulties standing in the way of superannuation benefits for teachers in charge of Indian day and residential schools may be summed up as follows:

1. An overwhelming majority of the teachers in charge of schools operated under the auspices of the Catholic Church are members of religious Orders and are not interested in contributing to, or receiving benefits from, a superannuation fund.

2. The teachers employed at Indian residential schools are not the employees of the Government and, unless their status were changed, could not qualify for superannuation under the Dominion or Provincial Superannuation Acts.

3. Indian day school teachers, particularly in the eastern provinces, move frequently from one province to another. It would be difficult, therefore, to adjust their superannuation allowances unless the Provincial Acts were somewhat uniform.

I am inclined to agree with you when you state in your letter to Mr. Gardiner that this is a subject that is going to be a source of constant complaint until such time as -
time as it is rectified. However, I feel sure you will readily appreciate the difficulties confronting us in any attempt we may make to find a solution. If the teachers in charge of Indian residential schools were employees of the Government and if the teachers in charge of Indian day schools were employed by the Government in the sense that public school teachers are employed by the local trustee boards, the matter would be comparatively simple. Indian school teachers would then become permanent civil servants and automatically qualify for superannuation benefits. I feel confident, however, that the churches would vigorously oppose any attempt that might be made to modify the policy now in force. The churches of Canada were the pioneers in the field of educational effort in this country, and the co-operative arrangement now in force has been, with one or two slight modifications, the policy of succeeding governments since Confederation.

I appreciate very fully your interest in this subject. If you find it convenient to visit Ottawa at any time in the immediate future, I shall welcome the opportunity to discuss this matter with you and with the officials charged with the responsibility of administering our schools.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

The purpose of my letter is to acquaint you with a situation in Saskatchewan which others and I consider more or less detrimental to the education of our Indian children in this province. Perhaps the best manner of accomplishing it is to describe to you an incident that actually happened here in the spring of this year.

I am a teacher with a B.A. degree and a teaching certificate. In March a certain principal requested me to take charge of some of the classes in the Indian School.
under his care. At first I was glad to consent, but later when I learned that our Department of Education does not consider the services of such teachers in Indian schools as services toward assimilation, I immediately cancelled my acceptance.

Since then I've often thought that you, perhaps, could influence the members of the Department of Education of our province to change their present regulations with regard to teachers in Indian schools. And if it can not be done, then qualified teachers will be reluctant to accept positions in those schools and the Indian children must necessarily suffer considerably for lack of such teachers to instruct them.

I hope my explanation of the situation has not been too lengthy or indistinct.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Trohak:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 18, in which you discuss the desirability of having either the Provincial Government or the Federal Government make provision for a superannuation fund for teachers.

I may state by way of comment that we have at this date a pupil enrolment at Indian schools in the Dominion of approximately 15,967. Of these pupils, 9,287 are enrolled at Indian day schools and 6,680 at residential schools. The teachers employed at Indian residential schools are the employees of the Churches under the auspices of which the schools are operated. Although the Government makes a per capita grant for the maintenance and operation of these schools, the teachers in charge cannot be considered in any sense government employees. In the case of Indian day school teachers, about 60% are nominated by the church authorities and these nominations in each case are approved by the Department. The salaries of Indian day school teachers, which are substantially higher than the salaries paid to teachers engaged in somewhat similar work in public schools, are paid in full by the Dominion Government. It is gratifying that in a number of cases teachers in addition to their regular classroom duties act as missionaries and are no doubt paid by the churches for their missionary effort on the reserves. Indian day school teachers are classified, therefore, as temporary civil servants. It is estimated that 40% of the temporary employees of the Government in all the services throughout the Dominion

Mr. Jos. Trohak,
Arbury, Sask.
do not qualify for superannuation. In this respect, Indian day school teachers do not differ from the regular temporary employees in other branches of the public service. In view of the fact that the average length of service rendered by a teacher in an Indian day school does not exceed five years, it is very difficult for me to see how we could extend to them the benefits of a superannuation act and withhold such benefits from the other temporary employees of the Government.

The main difficulties standing in the way of superannuation benefits for teachers in charge of Indian day and residential schools may be summed up as follows:

1. An overwhelming majority of the teachers in charge of schools operated under the auspices of the Catholic Church are members of religious Orders and are not interested in contributing to, or receiving benefits from, a superannuation fund.

2. The teachers employed at Indian residential schools are not the employees of the Government and, unless their status were changed, could not qualify for superannuation under the Dominion or Provincial Superannuation Acts.

3. Indian day school teachers, particularly in the eastern provinces, move frequently from one province to another. It would be difficult, therefore, to adjust their superannuation allowances unless the Provincial Acts were somewhat uniform.

The desirability of providing a superannuation fund for Indian day school teachers has been reviewed again and again by the officials of this Department. I think you will agree with me, however, when I state
that the obstacles standing in the way of the creation of such a fund are for the time being insurmountable.

Should you desire additional information, I want you to feel free to communicate with me again.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

As requested by you, I interviewed Doctor V.K. Greer, Director of Elementary Education, Department of Education, Toronto, yesterday with regard to the procedure that would have to be followed if we decided to complete arrangements to enable teachers in Indian schools in the province of Ontario to contribute to the provincial teachers' superannuation fund and thereby provide superannuation benefits for the teachers in our Ontario Indian schools.

To carry out this programme it would be necessary for the Ontario Government to pass legislation permitting our teachers to contribute to the fund and to benefit from it. Doctor Greer was quite willing to prepare and recommend such legislation, provided we made the following commitments:

1. All teachers in the Indian schools in Ontario would be required to contribute to the superannuation fund.

2. Each teacher would have to contribute $3½ of the monthly salary. This amount would have to be deducted from the monthly cheques by this Branch and forwarded to the Ontario teachers' superannuation fund.

3. This Branch would have to contribute an additional $3½ to the superannuation fund for each Indian day school teacher participating.
In our appropriation for the fiscal year 1945-46 we estimate the total payment for salaries of teachers of the regular Indian day schools and the combined white and Indian day schools to which we contribute at an amount of $87,545.00 and 3½% of this amount would be $3,064.07. In discussing this matter recently with you you will recall that we thought we might be able to handle this particular 3½% contribution by increasing each teacher's salary by that amount. However, Doctor Greer pointed out that this system would not be satisfactory, as it would actually increase the basic salary of the individual teacher and, as a result, increase the contribution that the teacher has to make. Consequently it would be necessary for us to provide in our appropriation the additional amount of $3,064.07 to permit our paying the 3½% contribution.

We had a very friendly talk over this matter and, as mentioned above, Doctor Greer is quite prepared to recommend the necessary legislation, if we are willing to comply with the three provisions previously mentioned.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Major MacKay:

We have recently been discussing in the office the possibility of arranging with the various provincial governments to allow teachers in Indian day schools to contribute to the provincial teachers' superannuation fund and thereby become eligible for the benefits accruing from that system. In bringing this matter to your attention, I wish to stress the fact that I have not yet had an opportunity of discussing the matter with the Minister; and consequently this preliminary letter to you should be considered confidential and in a very real sense exploratory, so that when we have the data gathered from the various provincial departments of education, I will be able to place before the Minister some concrete proposals.

However, I thought, on the occasion of your next visit to Victoria, you might discuss the matter in an off-hand manner with the Deputy Minister or other responsible officials of the British Columbia Department of Education.

The proposal has already been discussed with the Department of Education for the province of Ontario. They appear willing to allow teachers in this province to contribute to the Provincial Teachers' Superannuation Fund on the following basis:

(a) All teachers in Indian schools in Ontario would be required to contribute to the superannuation fund.

(b) Each teacher would have to contribute 5¢% of the monthly salary. This amount would have to be deducted from the monthly cheques by this Branch.

Major D. M. MacKay,

Yours sincerely,

Acting Director.

Dear Mr. McCubbin:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of November 13th, in which you seek information with respect to the eligibility of Indian day school teachers to qualify for pensions under the Superannuation Act.

I may state that Indian day school teachers are classified as temporary civil servants. They are not appointed to the positions they occupy by the Civil Service Commission, nor do they contribute to the superannuation fund, and consequently do not qualify for superannuation allowances.

You will, I feel sure, be interested to learn that the claims of these teachers for pensions have been reviewed on more than one occasion by departmental officials and at this date the matter is still under consideration. It is just possible that a decision will be reached at an early date whereby Indian day school teachers, or a certain number of them, will contribute to the superannuation fund. I am not sure, however, that it would be advisable to make a public announcement with respect to the matter until a final decision has been reached.

Yours sincerely,

Robert McCubbin, Esq., M.P.,

It will be necessary, as I have pointed out in my brief, to complete a detailed survey of all provincial teachers' salary scales before making a definite recommendation to you. However, I decided to present these suggestions to you more to indicate how I was approaching this problem and to enable you to compare your ideas to mine.

Teachers' salary scales fall into two main categories:

(a) Those in which a comparatively high minimum salary is given to the beginning teacher, with small increases for each year's experience. An example of this is the Province of Saskatchewan, where the minimum salary for a certificated teacher is now $1,200.00 per annum. This is the highest minimum salary required by law in Canada.

(b) Those in which a lower minimum salary is given to the beginning teacher, but with a substantial increase each year. An example of this is Nova Scotia, where minimum salaries begin at $900.00 a year but go up by $50.00 per annum.

Each of these two systems has merit, but I am not prepared to decide definitely the one I would recommend to you until I have completed a survey of the entire field.

A. DAY SCHOOL TEACHERS

1. Teacher, Day School, Grade I - $900.00 - $1,050.00
2. Teacher, Day School, Grade II - $1,000.00 - $1,250.00
3. Teacher, Day School, Grade III - $1,300.00 - $1,650.00
4. Teacher, Day School, Grade IV - $1,500.00 - $1,650.00

Classification Regulations:

1. Teacher, Day School, Grade I

(a) After 1 September, 1947, a Teacher's Training Certificate from a recognized Normal or Teachers' Training School will be required. Any non-certificated teacher employed as of that date can be retained in the Service but no further non-certificated teachers will be employed except in the event of an emergency.

(b) A salary raise of $50.00 a year to the maximum of $1,050.00 will be given for satisfactory teaching service.
2. Teacher, Day School, Grade II

(a) A Second Class Teacher's Certificate, or equivalent requiring High School Matriculation.

(b) Three years' satisfactory provincial teaching experience or as a teacher, Day School or Residential School, Grade I.

(c) At least one professional or academic course at a school of recognized standing during the teaching experience listed in (b) above. Such courses will include attendance at a Provincial Teachers' Summer School, University Summer School, Extra-mural Course from a University or a Provincial Correspondence School.

3. Teacher, Day School, Grade III

(a) A first class teacher's certificate or equivalent requiring high school Senior Matriculation (first year university).

(b) Six years' satisfactory provincial teaching experience or three years as a teacher, day or residential school, Grade II.

(c) At least one professional or academic course at a school of recognized standing during the teaching experience listed in (b) above.

4. Teacher, Day School, Grade IV

(a) A First Class Teacher's Certificate or equivalent or better.

(b) Three years' satisfactory experience as a teacher, Grade III.

(c) At least one professional or academic course at a school of recognized standing during the teaching experience listed in (b) above.

B. TEACHERS, WELFARE

Subject:

Appreciation of Two Possible Superannuation Plans for Indian School Teachers

1. Object.

To select one of the two superannuation plans listed below in order to provide greater benefit to, and more security for, the Indian school teacher:

(a) That the teacher of an Indian school be permitted to pay into the Teachers' and Inspectors' Superannuation Fund of the Province in which such Indian school is located, for the years of his teaching, in order that he might later receive credit for such years of service. This proposal shall be known hereafter as the Provincial Superannuation Plan.

(b) That the teacher of an Indian school be permitted to pay into the Civil Servants' Superannuation Fund of the Dominion of Canada, in order that he might later receive credit for such years of service. This proposal shall be known hereafter as the Dominion Superannuation Plan.

2. Assumptions:

(a) After some consideration I have concluded that it would be impractical to prepare a superannuation plan for the day school teacher and not for the residential school teacher. If the superannuation plan for the day school teacher was adopted, I feel sure that many of the teachers from residential schools who have their teachers included would be such that they too would soon have to be included in the superannuation plan. Therefore, I have decided to draw up a program for both classes of teachers in order that the requirements of these two groups could be properly assessed in relation to one another.

Whether these two plans are adopted simultaneously or whether the residential school teacher's plan is discarded or delayed, I leave entirely to the judgment of my seniors.

(b) That the key-stone of the educational system is the teacher and that it is most essential for the future of Indian education to provide at once, some form of security for our teachers. It is evident that the best form this security can take is a superannuation plan.

3. Provincial Superannuation Plan

(a) Advantages

I. It would not involve any change in the present plan of appointing and dismissing of teachers of Indian day schools.
II It would not involve any change in the present plan of appointing and dismissing of teachers of Indian residential schools.

III It would provide an optional plan for those denominations using religious orders in the teaching of Indians. Such denominations would have the choice as to whether or not they wish to contribute to such a Superannuation Fund on behalf of their teachers.

IV Teachers would be easily interchanged between Provincial schools and the Indian schools of that province because of their contribution to the same Superannuation Fund. Many teachers of the provincial schools now refuse to change to any Indian school because it would involve the loss of time and possibly payment made to the Superannuation Fund. The adoption of this plan would eliminate this difficulty and would provide for greater co-ordination between the provincial schools and the Indian schools.

(b) Disadvantages:

I The nine Provincial Legislatures would have to be called on separately to authorize in each instance the change in their Teachers' Superannuation Acts necessary before our teachers could participate. Three provinces, namely, British Columbia, Saskatchewan and Ontario, have already indicated their willingness to approve such legislative changes. However, it is possible that we might encounter some difficulty in arranging for such amendments. Some might well object to temporary Dominion Civil Servants being superannuated on a Provincial Civil Service Fund.

II The Teachers' Superannuation Acts of the Provinces vary considerably; we could encounter difficulties in providing applications for authorization to cover the contributions of the Dominion Government to the Provincial Plans. For example, in Saskatchewan, teachers contribute four per cent of their salaries whereas in Ontario and British Columbia they contribute only three and a half per cent of their salaries.

III The Department would encounter some difficulty in moving teachers from one province to another province in view of the lack of uniformity in the Provincial Superannuation Acts.

IV The teachers employed at Indian residential schools are not the employees of the Department, and unless their status were changed, could not qualify for superannuation. However, this difficulty would apply to both plans, as pointed out by the Honourable Mr. Crear (Flag No. 1 down).

V The question of the change in status of residential school teachers as involved in number four above is one that would have to be referred to the four denominations at present running our residential schools. It is understood that there may be considerable opposition to a change in the policy.
now in force (as stated by Honourable Mr. Grigor
(flag No. 2 down).

VI It is understood that some of the Provincial Plans
are not as financially sound as might be desired.
For example, in British Columbia, it has been neces-
sary during recent years to require the teachers
there to pay in extra sums into the Fund in order
to maintain the payments to teachers already
retired.

VII Separate provision would have to be made for teachers
in the Northwest Territories and the Yukon. It would
probably be necessary to include them in the present
Dominion Government superannuation system. Then we
would be adopting two separate plans.

4. Dominion Superannuation Plan

(a) Advantages

I. It would only require one legislative change to
enact this plan.

II. It would be easier from a finance point of view
as it would mean only the addition of some six
hundred teachers to the present Civil Service
superannuation Plan. There would also be a standard
rate of deduction.

III. The department could easily move teachers from
one province to another without interfering with
their superannuation funds.

IV. The Dominion Government superannuation policy is
a very sound one and would provide the greatest
security for our teachers.

V. Our day school teachers are already Dominion Civil
Servants but exempt from superannuation. For them
it will only be necessary to lift this exemption.

VI. It will enable the department to authorize "training
in service" by having teachers attend advance
courses on reduced rates of pay without losing
their superannuation benefits.

VII. The adoption of the Provincial Plan would lead to
endless correspondence about leave or absence,
illness of teachers, etc. It will require a staff
of experts to determine the contributions and
interpret the nine different provincial systems.

(b) Disadvantages:

I. It might involve a change in the present plan of
appointing and dismissing teachers of Indian day
schools. At first this seemed a very serious
disadvantage. However, I have since found out
that the Department of National Health and Welfare
does the appointing and dismissing of nurses and kitchen aids at Indian hospitals and nursing stations. With this precedent it should not be difficult for our Department to convince the Civil Service Commission that we should continue with our present plan.

II. It will mean that the Department will assume the cost of paying teachers of Indian residential schools rather than the various denominations as at present.

III. It will hardly be feasible for this to be an optimal plan and all denominations will have to be called on to agree to this new procedure. As the Honourable Mr. Crear has pointed out, this may well be difficult (see IV below).

IV. It will mean a change in the present plan of appointing and dismissing teachers of Indian residential schools. It would be most unreasonable to expect the Crown to assume the payment of these teachers and yet have no voice in their appointments. It will probably be necessary to compromise by having the denominations given the power of nomination. As this has worked successfully for day schools, it should work for residential schools.

V. It will not be easy to inter-change between provincial and Indian schools as teachers would thereby lose their superannuation years (it would not affect administration funds). However, this will work in two ways: teachers will not want to change to Indian schools but on the other hand once they are in they will not want to change back to provincial schools. Thus our holding power will be greater.

VI. Teachers will have to be paid on a 12 month basis to be full-time employees.

5. Conclusion:

After weighing carefully the above factors, I have decided in favour of the Dominion Superannuation Plan.

6. Plan:

If you concur in this decision, I propose to next attack the problems as follows:

(a) To conduct a survey of all provincial superannuation plans and teacher's salary schedules.

(b) To classify the various grades of teachers and to list their duties and qualifications. (I attach as appendix A, a rough outline of my present ideas).

(c) To prepare an estimate of the cost of this proposal.

Order-in-Council No. P.C. 242588 of December 16, 1922, grants power to the Superintendent of Indian Affairs to appoint nurses to hospitals and nursing stations located on Indian reservations. In 1924, this privilege was extended to the appointment of ward aids and hospital attendants on various types. In 1946 this privilege was extended to the Department of National Health and Welfare and it was specified that these positions would be totally exempt from the Civil Service Commission. It was felt therefore that they should be exempt from the Civil Service Commission.

Special reference should be made to P.O. 38/1721 of March 14, 1945, which specifically states that five years' temporary service when excluded from Civil Service Commission regulations, entitles application to Treasury Board for superannuation. (This was amended by P.C. 221/3185 of July 27, 1946.)

Further to our recent conversation, I submit herewith proposals for submission to the Treasury Board concerning the above.

Suggestions for Submission to Treasury Board:
The attached proposals are for grades of civil servants to be employed in the Welfare and Training Service of the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources. These proposals include a salary scale and the changing of Indian day school teachers from temporary civil servants to permanent civil servants, at the conclusion of two satisfactory years' teaching experience with the Department.

Every year we are experiencing greater difficulty in obtaining certificated teachers for our schools. All provinces have now introduced teachers' superannuation plans and are our teachers are leaving the service for provincial schools which offer them greater security. If we wish to compete with the provincial systems, it is most essential that we grant superannuation rights to our day school teachers.

Insofar as the salary scale is concerned, you will find attached a complete appreciation of the salaries paid to teachers throughout the Dominion and a copy of Education Bulletin No. 1, 1946, entitled "Teachers' Salaries and Qualifications in Eight Provinces - 1945."

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
APPENDIX A

PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY TEACHERS

I would recommend that

(a) the provisions and regulations of the Civil Service Superannuation Act apply to this new class of contributor,

(b) that at least two years' satisfactory teaching service in Indian day schools be required before application for permanency be made, and that the teacher by then hold a permanent teaching certificate.

(c) that, in the case of day school teachers who teach only for the academic year of ten months, this ten month period shall count as one year of service within the meaning of the Act.

(d) that teachers, who do not elect to become contributors, continue to be classed as temporary civil servants.

(e) that teachers of schools which are in operation less than ten months continue to be classified as temporary civil servants.

In order to qualify for increased salaries, most of our teachers will be attending a five or six weeks' summer school course during their "holidays". Therefore, they will actually be improving their own qualifications and teaching ability during this two month period.
APPENDIX B.

PAYMENT OF TEACHERS ON A 12 MONTH BASIS

This would not only make payment of salaries easier for our Treasury officials but is also in line with recent provincial legislation.

(1) Nova Scotia

Education Act, 1946; Regulation 3 (a) "Teachers' salaries must be paid in twelve equal instalments, the first to be paid not later than the last day of September, and the last not later than the last day of August".

(2) Alberta

School Act 172 (3) "Every teacher shall be paid his annual salary in twelve equal monthly instalments, on the last day of each month".

Therefore the salaries in our scale have been made divisible by twelve so that our teachers can be paid monthly.

After much consideration it was found necessary to discard this latter plan of provincial superannuation contributions because of the following disadvantages it possessed:

(a). It would have been necessary to request nine separate Provincial Legislatures to authorize in each instance the changes in their present Teachers' Superannuation Acts necessary before our teachers could participate.

(b). The percentage contributions required by the superannuation commissions of the various provinces varied considerably. It would have involved a great deal of extra work by our Treasury officials in computing deductions at 3½%, 4%, 4½%, 5% etc. as required by different provinces.
(c). The Department would have encountered some difficulty in moving teachers from one province to another province in view of the lack of uniformity in the Provincial Superannuation Acts.

(d). Separate provision would still have to be made for teachers in the North West Territories. It would probably have been necessary to include them in the superannuation system. Then we would have been adopting two separate plans.

(e). In general, the Dominion superannuation plan provides for a larger pension rate than do provincial plans.

In view of the above it was decided to approach Treasury Board with the proposals included herein.

I. The teachers desire a retirement allowance to consist of two parts:

(a) A Service Pension provided by the Provincial Government, the amount of which would be determined by length of service at the age of retirement.

This pension is based on each full year and any fraction of a year of service to be paid in accordance with the following schedule:

| Age       | Women | Men |
|-----------|-------|-----|
| 60 or over| $20,000 | $25,040 |
| 59        | $18,586 | $21,174 |
| 58        | $17,304 | $19,508 |
| 57        | $16,124 | $18,110 |
| 56        | $15,074 | $16,685 |
| 55        | $14,104 | $15,453 |

The maximum for which a service pension could be drawn would be for forty years.

(b) An Annuity, to be purchased by the accumulated funds derived from the reasonably deductions from the teacher's salary.

That for the annuity account a compulsory rate of interest be made from the teacher's salary and that it be optional for the teacher to contribute an amount up to 10% of salary.

II. The normal retirement age should be set for all teachers and provisions should be made for optional earlier retirement in which case the pension would be actuarially adjusted.

Normal retirement age shall be 60 years; compulsory retirement at age 65; optional retirement at age 55 with 15 years of service.

III. A satisfactory disability pension should be provided.

Any teacher who has served at least 15 years in the schools of Manitoba under this act and who becomes totally disabled, and for that reason unfit for further service as a teacher, should be eligible to receive a retirement allowance. The retirement allowance should consist of the service pension, actuarially adjusted to the normal retirement age for the actual years of service plus the annuity that can be purchased by the accumulated five percent contributions made by the teacher with accrued interest. In any case where the retirement allowance so computed is less than $500 per annum such allowance should be increased to $500 per annum from the service pensions account.

IV. The estate of a teacher who dies before retiring will be paid out of the fund to consist of the individual's contributions together with accrued interest.

V. Teachers withdrawing from educational work should receive their contributions together with accrued interest.

We are willing to concede that persons withdrawing from teaching should receive all but their first year's contributions together with accrued interest until our experience of the new scheme justifies the payment of this concession. The contributions to be placed in the service pensions account.

INTRODUCTION

The Committee held four meetings during the year.

The work undertaken was a survey of conditions in the rural areas. Sixteen hundred questionnaires were sent out and six hundred and forty answers were received.

The survey had a two-fold objective:

(1) To provide a source of information about rural schools that would be useful to teachers applying for positions.

(2) To provide as complete a picture as possible of the educational situation in rural areas.

In the first part of this report your Committee has attempted to present an overall picture of conditions. The second part of the report gives tables and statistics supporting the impressions and conclusions drawn in part I.

All thinking people today, who are conversant with world events, realize that the development of an educated, thinking body of citizens is imperative if a world catastrophe is to be avoided. Many prominent writers whose conclusions cannot be ignored state that the world situation points to a race between education and catastrophe, and some think that even now it is too late.

In the face of these facts, what is the educational situation in Manitoba?

IMPRESSIONS DERIVED FROM READING 640 QUESTIONNAIRES

Education in rural Manitoba is at a low ebb. A large percentage of the teachers lack the necessary academic qualifications, experience and maturity to impinge successfully upon the children's knowledge, with still less possibility of producing a thinking body of students.

Classroom equipment and sports equipment are inadequate in a majority of schools.

Health and sanitary conditions are very unsatisfactory.

Schools employing permit teachers are on the whole more poorly equipped, have a greater teacher turn-over and less district cooperation than schools employing qualified teachers.

These impressions are supported by the following outstanding facts:

(1) 262 teachers out of 640 are teaching on permits (approx. 45%).

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Superannuation for teachers of Indian Day Schools

Please find attached a submission to Council concerning the eligibility of Indian day school teachers as contributors under the Civil Service Superannuation Act. This matter has been thoroughly discussed by our Superintendent of Education with Mr. Simonsley of your own staff, with Mr. Gallock, Superintendent of Superannuation, Department of Finance, and with officials of the Treasury Board. The teachers of our schools were circularized and requested to indicate their willingness to contribute under the Civil Service Superannuation Act. The attached list contains the names of those who wish to be classified as permanent Civil Servants for the purposes of the Civil Service Superannuation Act.

I feel certain that you realize the importance of this move. These teachers have no security whatsoever while they are employed in our schools whereas all nine provinces now have teachers' superannuation plans. I feel that these teachers, who live on isolated Indian reserves, far from electricity, running water and any other conveniences, are certainly as entitled to superannuation as are the clerks and stenographers employed in the Civil Service in the city of Ottawa. If we are to attract and hold a better class of teachers for our Indian schools, then it is most essential that we offer them the protection of a superannuation plan.

You will note from the attached list that many of these teachers who are applying have long and faithful records of service. Seven of them are Indians.

CHAPTER 180.

An Act to Establish a Teachers' Retirement Fund.

HIS MAJESTY, by and with the advice and consent of the Legislative Assembly of the Province of Alberta, enacts as follows:

Short Title.

1. This Act may be cited as "The Teachers' Retirement Fund Act."

[1939, c. 21, s. 1.]

Interpretation.

2. In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires—

(a) "Board of Administrators" or "the Board" means the Board of Administrators appointed and constituted under the provisions of this Act;

(b) "Fund" means the Teachers' Retirement Fund established under the provisions of this Act;

(c) "Teacher" means any person holding a valid certificate of qualification issued under the regulations of the Ministry of Education of the Province of Alberta, who is employed—

(i) by the board of trustees of a school district or a school division formed and constituted under The School Act, in the capacity of teacher in a school;

(ii) by the Lloydminster Public School District or the Lloydminster High School District in the capacity of teacher in a school;

(iii) by a superintendent, supervisor, principal or other such official of a school district or a school division formed and constituted under The School Act;

(iv) by the Alberta Teachers' Association.

[1939, c. 21, s. 2; 1942, c. 44, s. 2.]

Application of the Act.

3. This Act shall apply to all teachers actually employed in teaching in those school districts or school divisions receiving grants from the Province of Alberta and to any teacher acting as a full-time employee of the Alberta Teachers' Association.

[1939, c. 21, s. 3.]
The Fund.

4.—(1) The Department of Education is hereby authorized and empowered to establish a teachers' retirement fund to be derived from—

(a) gifts and legacies;
(b) amounts contributed by or on behalf of teachers as hereinafter provided;
(c) interest or other income derived from the fund;
(d) contributions from boards of trustees as hereinafter provided.

(2) A separate record of the payments into the fund made in respect to each teacher shall be kept by the Board of Administrators of the Fund.

[1939, c. 21, s. 4; 1941, c. 38, s. 2.]

5.—(1) Every teacher shall contribute to the Fund an amount equal to three per cent of his salary as a teacher earned by him at any time in the manner herein provided:

(a) The board of trustees of each and every school district or school division in the province of Alberta and of the Lloydminster Public School District and the Lloydminster High School District is hereby empowered to retain and shall retain from the salary of each and every teacher the percentage which such teacher is required to contribute to the Fund in accordance with this section, which percentage shall be deducted from each payment on account of salary made to the teacher, and all moneys so retained shall be deemed to have been paid out of the salary and shall be deemed to be a contribution to the Fund by the teacher from whom the percentage of salary has been retained:

Provided, however, that the Minister of Education may authorize in writing any board of trustees to pay the moneys so retained to the Board of Administrators and it shall then be the duty of the board of trustees to pay the moneys to the Board of Administrators at such times as the Board of Administrators may direct written approval but not oftener than once in each month and in any such case the provisions of paragraph (b) of this subsection shall apply only with respect to any amounts which have been retained by a board of trustees and not paid over to the Board of Administrators;

(b) The Department of Education is hereby empowered to retain and shall retain, semi-annually at the end of each school term, from the grant payable to each and every school district or school division under The School Grants Act in aid of schools.
organized and conducted under the provisions of The School Act, and from the grants available to the Lloydminster Public School District and the Lloydminster High School District an amount equal to the amount so required to be retained by the board of trustees from the salaries of all teachers of each school district or school division during each term, and to receive such payments to the Board for the purposes of the Fund the moneys so retained or received, and all moneys so retained and paid over shall be deemed to have been paid over to and received by the board of trustees on account of the legislative grant to the school district or school division for that term.

(c) A substitute or temporary teacher as defined in The School Act shall not be required to contribute to the Fund as hereinafore provided except when employed for a total of ten days or more in any month.

(2) During the first five years of any teacher's participation under the provisions of this Act, one-sixth of his contributions shall not be placed to the credit of the teacher in his account in the Fund but shall be placed in a reserve account to be disbursed as the Board of Administrators by by-law may decide, for the purpose of providing benefits for retiring teachers whose contributions under this Act have not built up an adequate retirement benefit.

(3) Any teacher who leaves his employment as teacher for such reason as may in the sole discretion of the Board entitle him to continue his contributions, may apply to the Board for permission to continue the same during his absence from his employment and the Board may, for such length of time and on such terms and conditions as they by by-law prescribe, accept contributions by or on behalf of the teacher not exceeding in any year three per cent of the annual salary earned by him immediately prior to leaving his employment.

[1939, c. 21, s. 5; 1941, c. 38, s. 3; 1942, c. 44, s. 3.]

6. For the purpose of assisting the Department in determining the amount which should be retained and paid over, the board of trustees of each school district or school division shall, semi-annually, with the returns for the school term which the board of trustees is by law required to furnish to the Department, furnish the Department with a complete and accurate record, certified to be such by the secretary-treasurer or other proper officer of the school district or school division, showing the name of each teacher employed by the board of trustees in that term, the amount of salary paid to each teacher together with such further information respecting any such salary as shall be required by the Department. [1939, c. 21, s. 6.]
7.—(1) The board of trustees of every city, town, village and consolidated school district (not being within a division), and of the Lloydminster Public School District and the Lloydminster High School District, shall pay into the Fund at the end of each month an amount equal to one-half of one per cent of the total amount of salary earned in that month by each of its teachers required to contribute to the Fund.

(2) In the event of the failure of any such board of trustees to pay any such amount as aforesaid, the Department of Education may retain semi-annually at the end of each school term from the grants payable to each such school district under The School Grants Act in aid of schools organized and conducted under the provisions of The School Act, and pursuant to The Border Areas Act or The Lloydminster Municipal Amalgamation Act, an amount equal to the amount which such board of trustees is then in default, and shall pay over to the Board for the purposes of the Fund all moneys so retained, and all moneys so retained and paid over shall be deemed to have been paid over to and received by such board of trustees on account of the Legislative grant to the school district for that term.

(3) Every such board of trustees shall make due provision for the payment required by it to be paid and shall make no deduction whatsoever from the salary of any of its teachers by reason of any such payment.

(4) The Board shall credit all sums received by it, pursuant to the provisions of this section, to the reserve account mentioned in subsection (2) of section 5.

[1941, c. 38, s. 4; 1942, c. 44, s. 4.]

Board of Administrators.

8.—(1) There shall be a Board of Administrators consisting of four members, of whom three shall form a quorum for the transaction of business, who shall manage, control and administer the said Fund and shall be a body politic and corporate with all the powers and immunities provided by law for such bodies.

(2) Two of the members of the Board shall be appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council in such manner and for such term or terms and at such times as he may determine.

(3) The two other members of the Board shall be teachers and shall be appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council, one of whom shall serve until the thirtieth day of June, 1943, and the other of whom shall serve until the thirtieth day of June, 1945, and their successors from time to time appointed shall serve for a term of four years each from the dates at which their respective appointments take effect. The two members so appointed under this sub-
section shall be nominated by the Executive Council of the Alberta Teachers' Association at least one month before the date on which they shall enter upon their duties as members of the Board of Administrators.

(4) If any member of the Board shall vacate his office or should the office for any reason become vacant, the Lieutenant Governor in Council shall appoint a successor to serve for the unexpired term. [1939, c. 21, s. 7.]

Powers of the Board.

9.—(1) The Board of Administrators is hereby empowered—

(a) to manage, control, invest and administer the Fund and its distribution and to act as and be the trustees thereof;

(b) to receive moneys therefor whether by way of contribution, gift, grant, legacy or otherwise;

(c) to appoint, employ, remove and discharge such officers or employees as it may deem necessary for the exercise of its powers;

(d) to determine who shall be entitled to participate in the Fund and the amount each participant shall receive, and the manner and times of such receiving;

(e) to refund and pay to any teacher who has contributed to the Fund, or to his estate, widow, or widower, or to his next-of-kin who are members of his immediate family, such sum or sums as it may determine, or may decline to so refund any moneys contributed by any teacher, or to require payment out of all moneys belonging to the Fund;

(f) to enter into any engagement or agreement from time to time to bring about or to facilitate the transferring of any benefit to which any teacher is or may be entitled in this Fund to any other similar Fund and the transferring to this Fund of the benefits to which any person may be similarly entitled in any other similar Fund; and

(g) to do all acts and make all such provisions and regulations as shall appear proper and necessary touching the proper ordering of all the affairs and business of the Fund, and for making any or any of them from time to time to pass by-laws and to amend, repeal, add to or re-enact all or any of such by-laws, and such by-laws as long as they shall be in force shall have the same force and effect as if part of the Act and be binding upon all persons to whom they apply:

Provided always that all moneys to be invested by the Board hereunder shall be invested in such bonds, debentures
or other securities as trustees are authorized by law to invest money in.

(2) All such regulations so made, and all by-laws so enacted or passed, shall, however, before having any force or effect, be approved by the Lieutenant Governor in Council and be published once in The Alberta Gazette.

(3) On or before the thirty-first day of December of each year the Board shall furnish to the Department of Education an audited statement showing the standing of the Fund as at the thirty-first day of August preceding and containing such other information as the Lieutenant Governor in Council may from time to time require.

(4) Without limiting the powers of the Board as otherwise provided in this Act, the Board is hereby authorized to include in its by-laws provisions to the effect that a differentiation may be made in the amounts of the pensions, which shall be granted to teachers after the passing of this Act, according as their service is of a contributory or a non-contributory nature. [1939, c. 21, s. 8; 1942, c. 44, s. 5.]

Penalty for non-compliance with provisions of Act

10. Any person required by this Act, or by the regulations or by-laws hereunder, to furnish any information or make any return or statement in writing to the Department of Education or the Board of Administrators, or to perform any act or duty, who refuses or neglects to furnish such information or make such return or statement or perform such act or duty, shall be guilty of an offence and liable on summary conviction to a penalty not exceeding fifty dollars, which shall be remitted to the Board and credited to the reserve account mentioned in subsection (2) of section 5. [1940, c. 28, s. 3; 1942, c. 44, s. 6.]

Every person entitled to receive a pension and entitled to receive a sum out of moneys appropriated for the purpose by the Legislature

11. Every person who under the regulations or by-laws of the Board is entitled to receive after the passing of this Act an amount as pension from the Fund, shall also be entitled to receive during such out of moneys appropriated by the Legislature for that purpose, and when calculating the amount to which such person is so entitled under the said regulations or by-laws, the Board shall also advance and pay such equal sums and the Provincial Treasurer shall at the end of each month pay over to the Board out of moneys so appropriated all sums which during such month shall have been so advanced and paid by the Board. [1939, c. 21, s. 9.]

Members of Board to serve without remuneration

12. The members of the Board of Administrators shall serve without remuneration, but shall be entitled to receive, and shall be paid all necessary and actual expenses including travelling expenses incurred in and about the performance of their duties as such members. [1939, c. 21, s. 10.]

Costs of administration payable out of Fund

13. All costs and expenses incurred in carrying out the objects of this Act shall be borne and paid out of the Fund, provided, however, that the Department of Education shall
provide office space for the performance of all clerical duties necessary to carrying out the objects of the Act as well as for the storing of all documents, files, cards, etc., necessary for the carrying out of the objects of this Act.

[1939, c. 21, s. 11.]

14. Neither the right of any teacher to receive a payment out of the Fund nor any moneys payable to the teacher under this Act as advances by way of gratuity whether made in periodic payments or otherwise shall be capable of being assigned, charged or anticipated or given as security, nor shall the same be liable to be seized, attached or levied upon by or under the process of any court, and such right or moneys shall be exempt from execution of any law relating to bankruptcy or insolvency, and the Board may in its discretion refuse to recognize any power of attorney granted by a teacher with reference to any such payment.

[1939, c. 21, s. 12.]
