Dear Mr. Henry:

You will recall that I wrote to you on October 29 concerning superannuation proposals for Indian day school teachers. We have now just been informed that an Order-in-Council has been passed in which the first group of day school teachers have been granted permanency as civil servants within the meaning of the Civil Service Superannuation Act.

In advising teachers of our intentions to approach Treasury Board in this regard, we informed them of the following regulations:

"The classification of permanent civil servant for the purposes of superannuation will be applied only to certain of our teachers as detailed below:

(a) Teachers who are in possession of permanent teaching certificates as granted by Provincial Departments of Education.

(b) Teachers who have been employed for a period of at least two years as Indian Day School Teachers and upon whose work satisfactory School Inspectors' and Indian Agents' reports have been submitted.

(c) Teachers who otherwise qualify within the regulations laid down in the Civil Service Superannuation Act.

(d) Teachers of day schools in operation for a full academic year of ten months.

"Note: Married women to be eligible must provide proof of the fact that they are, or necessity, self-supporting."
Some 22 teachers made application for inclusion, and all 22 have been made permanent civil servants, provided that they pass the necessary medical examination.

I am also enclosing a copy of an abbreviated office form of Civil Service Superannuation Act, which I hope will provide other information for you.

Dear Mr. Henry:

I have for answer your letter of February 2, which was here when I returned from an inspection trip. I can answer two of the three points which you have raised:

(a) Under the Dominion Government's Superannuation Act, civil servants are given the privilege of electing to contribute for previous years of service. They must make this decision within one year of being notified of their permanency. Our teachers would be in the same position, namely, they have a choice as to whether they contribute for past years of service, or not.

(b) I am referring this point to the Superintendent of Superannuation for the Department of Finance and will write you further concerning it.

(c) Only teachers of Indian day schools are classified as civil servants. Teachers at residential schools are employed by the denomination which operates the school for this Department. In other words, they are not paid directly by the Dominion Government but by the denomination which operates the school. Therefore, they do not contribute to the superannuation fund.

There has been some consideration given to having this condition changed but nothing definite has been decided as yet concerning teachers at residential schools. At the present time superannuation applies only to teachers of Indian day schools.

I have to advise you, that after considerable effort on the part of our Department, the Treasury Board has recommended the permanent appointment of certain Indian Day School teachers.

You are included among those who are now eligible for appointment to a permanent position for the purpose of superannuation. It will, of course, be necessary to present the required evidence of age, health, character and habits to the Chief of the Superannuation and Retirement Fund Branch of the Department of Finance before such appointment is finalized.

You will find attached the following documents:

(a) Two copies of Physical Examination Record (N.H. & W. Form 502).

(b) One copy of "Civil Service Superannuation Act" Form (FA74).

(c) Three copies of Civil Service Superannuation Act Election Form (Fin. No. 64).

(d) One copy of Memorandum re War Service (5/1947).

(e) One copy of Memorandum re Pensionable Employment (6/1947).

Physical Examination

We will require completion of the attached physical examination record (N.H. & W. Form 502). It is suggested that you have this form completed by either your own personal doctor or by a doctor of the Indian Health Services of the Department of National Health and Welfare. This form, when completed, should then be sent to:

Civil Service Health Division,
Department of National Health and Welfare,
Ottawa, Canada.

Please note that any expense attendant upon this examination will be borne by you.
Action to Contribute for Past Service.

When a Civil Servant has served in a temporary capacity, prior to being a contributor to the Civil Service Superannuation Act, he may, within twelve months of the date of his permanent appointment, elect to contribute five percent of the total salary received by him during such period of service with simple interest thereon at the rate of four percent per annum. By reference to section II para 2 of the Civil Service Superannuation Act pamphlet (FA 74) attached you can determine the rate of contribution in your instance.

Our records show that you have been an Indian Day School Teacher for a period of approximately _______ years. Therefore, it will be necessary for you to pay contributions, if you so elect, to the fund in either one lump sum or in installments. You will find a table of installments on page 2 of the election form (Fin No. 64).

If you desire to have this temporary service count for Superannuation purposes, kindly complete the enclosed forms (Fin No. 64) in duplicate and return them in duplicate to this office. I may point out that by Order in Council 2261 dated August 10, 1939, only service which is fully paid for shall be counted.

War Service.

A memorandum is attached for the information of contributors who may be eligible to count their War Service for purposes of the Civil Service Superannuation Act.

Pensionable Employment:

If you have had service with the Dominion Government prior to your present appointment, you should immediately furnish this office with full particulars regarding the nature of such service and the salary received.

If you have had other pensionable employment (e.g., as a provincial teacher) you will find details as to conditions, procedure, etc., outlined in the memorandum attached.
dealing with "Pensionable Employment" (6/1947).

Your attention is directed to para 2 under "Conditions" in this memorandum in which you will note that your contribution "for such employment shall be twice the amount that he would have contributed etc.". The only exception to this is service in a Provincial Employment Service or "Unemployment Board or Commission".

Under para 2 of "Exceptions", you are not entitled to count provincial service for Dominion superannuation services, when you are already receiving or have received a provincial superannuation benefit.

Deductions:

I may add that from November 3, 1947, a percent (as determined by the Civil Service Superannuation Act - form 74A) will be deducted from your salary on account of the superannuation fund. Whether or not you decide to contribute for past service, I would appreciate being informed at the earliest possible date of your decision.

I would finally remind you that you are given twelve months to make the election described above and that this offer expires on November 3, 1948. Therefore, it is most important that you inform the Department of your decision whether to allow for past service or not.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

REGISTERED MAIL

Ottawa, February 19, 1948.

Dear Miss Jamieson:

I have to advise you, that after considerable effort on the part of our Department, the Treasury Board has recommended the permanent appointment of certain Indian Day School teachers.

You are included among those who are now eligible for appointment to a permanent position for the purpose of superannuation. It will, of course, be necessary to present the required evidence of age, health to the Chief of the Superannuation and Retirement Fund Branch of the Department of Finance before you may become a contributor under the Civil Service Superannuation Act.

You will find attached the following documents:

(a) Two copies of Physical Examination Record (N.H. & W. Form 502).
(b) One copy of "Civil Service Superannuation Act" (Form PA-7).
(c) Three copies of Civil Service Superannuation Act Election Form (Fin. No. 64).
(d) One copy of Memorandum re War Service (5/1947).
(e) One copy of Memorandum re Pensionable Employment (6/1947).

Physical Examination:

We will require completion of the attached physical examination record (N.H. & W. Form 502). It is suggested that you have this form completed by either your own personal doctor or by a doctor of the Indian Health Services of the Department of National Health and Welfare. This form, when completed,
should be sent to:

Civil Service Health Division,
Department of National Health and Welfare,
Ottawa, Canada.

Please note that any expense attendant upon this examination will be borne by you.

Election to Contribute for Past Service.

When a Civil Servant has served in a temporary capacity, prior to being a contributor to the Civil Service Superannuation Act, he may, within twelve months of the date of his permanent appointment, elect to contribute an amount equal to five, five and one-half or ten percent of the total salary received by him during such period of service with simple interest thereon at the rate of four percent per annum. By reference to section II para 2 of the Civil Service Superannuation Act pamphlet (FA 74) attached, you can determine the rate of contribution in your instance.

Our records show that you have been an Indian Day School Teacher for a period of approximately thirty-eight years. Therefore, it will be necessary for you to pay contributions, if you so elect, to the fund in either one lump sum or in installments. You will find a table of installments on page 2 of the election form (Fin No. 64).

If you desire to have this temporary service count for Superannuation purposes, kindly complete the enclosed forms (Fin No. 64) and return them in duplicate to this office. I may point out that by Section 7 A (1) of the Act, only service which is fully paid for shall be counted.

War Service:

A memorandum is attached for the information of contributors who may be eligible to count their War Service for purposes of the Civil Service Superannuation Act.
Pensionable Employment:

If you have had service with the Dominion Government prior to your present appointment, you should immediately furnish this office with full particulars regarding the nature of such service and the salary received.

If you have had other pensionable employment (e.g., as a provincial teacher) you will find details as to conditions, procedure, etc., outlined in the memorandum attached, dealing with "Pensionable Employment" (6/1947).

Your attention is directed to para 2 under "Conditions" in this memorandum in which you will note that your contribution "for such employment shall be twice the amount that he would have contributed etc.,".

Under para 2 of "Exceptions", you are not entitled to count provincial service for Dominion superannuation services, when you are already receiving or have received a provincial superannuation benefit.

Deductions:

I may add that from December 27, 1947, a percent (as determined by the Civil Service Superannuation Act - form 74 A) will be deducted from your salary on account of the superannuation fund. Whether or not you decide to contribute for past service, I would appreciate being informed at the earliest possible date of your decision.

I would finally remind you that you are given twelve months to make the election described above and that this offer expires on December 27, 1948. Therefore, it is most important that you inform the Department of your decision whether to allow for past service or not.

Sincerely yours,

B. F. NEARY
Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Julia Jamieson,
Six Nations No. 2 Indian Day School,
Ohsweken, Ontario.

Ottawa, February 26, 1948.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Statement on Indian Day School Teachers

As requested, please find attached a statement prepared on the improved status of Indian day school teachers for presentation by you to the Parliamentary Committee.

We have endeavoured to cover the salient points in a brief presentation.

Enc.

Director.

BFN/EM
The Indian Affairs Branch is now employing some 352 teachers in its Indian day schools which are located throughout every province and territory of Canada. In the past, these teachers were classified only as temporary civil servants and were not placed on a regular graded salary schedule.

On 1 September, 1947, there went into effect an "Indian Day School Teachers' Salary Schedule" which provided for grades of day school teachers, welfare teachers and principals. This schedule provides for regular annual salary increases, based upon qualification and satisfactory teaching experience. This schedule has done much to retain in our service the type of teacher who can render a great contribution to Indian education.

The introduction of a separate class of teachers now termed "welfare teachers" is a progressive advancement which, we hope, will do much to improve living conditions on certain isolated reservations. This category of teacher is paid on a twelve month basis and in addition to normal teaching duties carries out other activities such as the formation of homemakers' clubs, the sponsoring of community recreation, the encouragement of home gardens and home improvement clubs, the improvement of living conditions and co-operates with Indian agents and nurses in matters of family allowances, drug dispensing, etc.

Early in January or this year an Order-in-Council was passed making eligible the first group of Indian day school teachers for appointment to permanent positions in the Indian Affairs Branch for the purposes of the Civil Service Superannuation Act. This means that for the first time teachers who meet the requirements are eligible for superannuation privileges such as are enjoyed by other permanent civil servants. We feel confident that this step will do a great deal towards the provision of a more permanent group of teachers in these schools and will reduce the large turn over in staff that has previously occurred every summer.

In addition to the above two improvements in status, we have also endeavoured to provide a better type of living accommodation at our day schools. The new standard type of day school now being constructed provides for a comfortable teachers'age in the same building. We feel that in these isolated points, a sound and well furnished teachers'age will help to attract a more satisfactory type of teacher. We are also carrying out improvements in many of the present teachers'ages.

To summarize, then, the achievements of the past year with regard to improved conditions for our day school teachers are three-fold:

1. the introduction of a salary schedule with regular increments as described above,

2. the first group of such teachers has been made eligible for privileges under the Civil Service Superannuation Act,

3. the provision of a better class of living accommodation for teachers.
Ottawa, March 1, 1948.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Re - Superannuation Act

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo, in which you wish to be advised whether or not there is any provision for a transfer of funds from the Dominion Civil Service to a fund such as the Ontario Teachers' and Inspectors' Superannuation Fund of the Province of Ontario.

In reply, I have to advise you that there is no such arrangement. However, if a contributor under the Civil Service Superannuation Act resigns to accept a position elsewhere, the contributor may at his option take a return of his contributions without interest or an adjusted deferred annual allowance payable at age 60, as provided in Section 6(1)(d) of the Act.

Yours truly,

(G.L. Gullock)
Chief, Superannuation Branch.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa

Mrs. M. E. MacNeill - Robert I. D. S.

Your letter of 30th March received, dealing with a permanent teacher's status in the Branch for the above teacher.

Mrs. MacNeill has been teaching in this Agency less than one full teaching year, and we are actually thus not in the best position to assess her capabilities. We have sought advice from School Inspector Greening, but he has not paid an official visit to the school this year, but anticipates doing so within a month's time.

Reports from the parents of those in attendance regarding Mrs. MacNeill's teaching ability tend to be conflicting - pro and con. I do feel that her services are of value to the Branch, that she is a hard worker, conscientious and devoted to her duties. She is inclined to be nervous and high strung by temperament and by standards of comparison with urban teachers, she is shaded, but undoubtedly conforms to an average insofar as our Branch is concerned.

All things considered, I feel that Mrs. MacNeill is deserving of permanent status. If Mr. Burk does not concur, he can write to that effect upon his return, for I shall draw this matter to his attention.

N. V. Peltier
Port Arthur Indian Agency.

P.S. Might I comment that the adoption by the Branch of a standard Assessment Form for the completion by the Assessing Officer, would appear to be a progressive step in these cases.

Dear Mr. Gibson:

I regret very much the misunderstanding which I have caused with regard to the payment of superannuation to teachers in Indian residential schools.

It is only the teachers of Indian day schools who are entitled to superannuation privileges, as the teachers in Indian residential schools are not paid directly by the Department but by the denomination concerned, and it is not possible to extend superannuation privileges to them.

Sincerely yours,

Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, April 19, 1948.

Dear Mr. Gibson:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of April 13th, in which you quote a statement relating to the status of teachers employed in Indian residential schools made by me before the Special Parliamentary Committee.

All teachers employed at Indian day schools who are fully qualified academically and professionally and who have had the necessary years of service contribute to the superannuation fund and qualify for superannuation allowances. In such cases, the residential school teachers are not employed by this department, but by the churches; these teachers don't contribute nor do they qualify for superannuation allowances. It is my intention to have the Director of Indian Affairs explain this matter to the members of the Committee at the earliest opportunity.

Yours sincerely,

Deputy Minister.

Dear Mr. Street:

This is in connection with your letter of March 10th regarding the payment of the arrears for Superannuation purposes. There are so many points I want to bring to your attention that I will take them up one at a time.

First, although your Form No. 64 is quite complete our records show that your estimated arrears are quite higher than you have, also we have more of the details, therefore, I am returning you your copies and am asking you to complete the front part of our three copies and forward two to this office. You keep the third. I wish to point out that the figures are, but an estimate and may be revised by the Department of Finance. Paying for these arrears will give you a credit of eighteen and one half years.

Second, your election to contribute for Active Service is quite in order and I shall keep the form on file until I get Form 64 from you and will forward the two with the copy of the Military Discharge Certificate to the Department of Finance. However, I will point out that you will not get credit for service during the World War II.

Third, the Department has ruled that your service in Provincial Schools cannot be counted towards Superannuation purposes. The regulation reads that an employee must have been employed in a "Pensionable Employment", which is employment where there was an established Superannuation fund or plan. Such a plan was
adopted in Manitoba in the Fall of 1925, while you were employed in Provincial Schools prior to that.

Fourth, it is noted that you have not forwarded your Birth Certificate. It will be necessary for you to send it in, as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Miss Beach:

I have for answer your letter of May 3, 1948. Our Indian day school teachers are now eligible to make application for superannuation privileges under the Dominion Government Civil Service Superannuation Act. I am attaching an office copy of this Act, which as you know applies to permanent Civil Servants of the Dominion Government.

Our requirements before presenting a teacher's case to Treasury Board for the necessary Order-in-Council are as follows:

"The classification of permanent civil servant for the purposes of superannuation will be applied only to certain of our teachers as detailed below:

(a) Teachers who are in possession of permanent teaching certificates as granted by Provincial Departments of Education.

(b) Teachers who have been employed for a period of at least two years as Indian Day School Teachers and upon whose work satisfactory School Inspectors' and Indian Agents' reports have been submitted.

(c) Teachers who otherwise qualify within the regulations laid down in the Civil Service Superannuation Act.

(d) Teachers of day schools in operation for a full academic year of ten months.

Note: Married women to be eligible must provide proof of the fact that they are, of necessity, self-supporting."

..... As
As teachers at Indian Residential Schools are employed by the denominations operating those schools and not by this Department, the Civil Service Superannuation privileges do not extend to them.

Yours sincerely,

SUPERANNUATION PLAN

1. It is anticipated that the amendment of the Civil Service Superannuation Act just completed by Parliament will make it possible for the employees of the Defence Research Board to participate in the scheme. Some time must elapse before all the administrative problems connected with employees of the Board becoming contributors be ironed out. In the meantime, however, the following outline of the provisions of the Act has been prepared for your information. It should be clearly understood that this summary has NO OFFICIAL STANDING and covers only those details of the scheme which are deemed to be of general interest.

A. ELIGIBILITY

2. All employees who meet the following qualifications are eligible to become contributors:

(a) Measure up to the physical requirements prescribed in the Civil Service Act.

(b)(i) Are in receipt of a stated annual salary and are designated by the Treasury Board as permanent employees, or

(ii) Are employed for a fixed term of years (probably 3) and are designated by the Treasury Board as eligible under the Superannuation Act.

3. Before an employee can be designated as permanent he must have served in a temporary capacity for at least one year and the position he is filling must be certified as one of continuous indeterminate duration. Part-time employees are NOT eligible.

B. CONTRIBUTIONS

4. Male

Salary $1200 per annum or less - 5%
Salary over $1200 but less than $1500 - 6%
but not in excess of an amount which reduces the remaining salary to a rate per annum of less than $1,147.50.

Salary $1500 per annum or more - 6%
but not in excess of an amount which reduces the remaining salary to a rate per annum of less than $1,417.50.

5. Female

5% for a period not exceeding 35 years.

No one pays for more than 35 years.
6. Any employee may elect to contribute in respect of prior service in the Civil Service. The contribution required for this prior service is in accordance with the provisions of Section B above with simple interest at 4%. Such payment can be made as a lump sum or by instalments with interest charged as required by the Treasury Board. This means that if you worked for 3 years as a temporary before becoming a contributor to the Superannuation Fund and your salary was $2000 per year, you would owe the Fund:

\[
\frac{6}{100} \times \$2000 = \$120.00 \times 3 = \$360
\]

\[
\frac{6}{100} \times \$120 = \frac{4.80}{\$120} \times (3 + 2 + 1) = \frac{28.80}{\$72}
\]

To this amount would be applied the amount of your credit in the Retirement Fund. You would then be required to make up the balance either in one payment or in instalments with interest.

7. Contributors who resigned from the Civil Service to join the Armed Forces during the War and received a withdrawal allowance at that time may be reinstated as contributors for that period of their service by repaying the allowance plus 4% simple interest.

8. A contributor who enters the service of the Board from an employment in which he was subject to a pension plan may count his period of employment therein as service under the Superannuation Act if his separation from such employment involves the loss of pension benefits under the said plan. He shall be required to contribute for such service twice the amount specified in paragraph 6 above.

9. A contributor who served on active service overseas in the forces during World War I or World War II, and was not immediately prior to enlistment, an employee in the Civil Service, may count his active service under the Superannuation Act provided he contributes for the period involved twice the amount prescribed in paragraph 6 above. For this purpose his salary shall be deemed to be that payable to him immediately after he is employed by the Board.

D. BENEFITS

10. The term "Retirement Age" means sixty years of age, at which time the contributor may retire voluntarily. The compulsory age of retirement is 65.

11. A contributor who has served 10 years or more (including temporary service, provided back payments have been made in accordance with paragraph 6 above) and has reached the retirement age or become incapacitated before reaching the retiring age or who became a contributor before 15 August, 1944, and is retired...
before reaching the retirement age by reason of abolition of his position, may be paid an annual allowance equal to his average salary during the last 10 years of his service multiplied by one fifth for each year of service, not exceeding 35. Thus, if your average salary during your last 10 years of service was $2500, and you had the maximum number of 35 years, your allowance would be

\[ \frac{35}{50} \times \$2500 = \$1750. \]

12. A person who has served ten years or more but did not become a contributor until 16th August, 1946, or thereafter, if he is retired before reaching retirement age by reason of abolition of his position may receive an annual retiring allowance equal, until he reaches the age of 65, to 2/3 of the retiring allowance, and thereafter to the full retiring allowance.

13. A contributor who has served less than 10 years, and retires either because he has reached the retirement age or because of disability may choose one of the two following options:

(a) An adjusted annual retiring allowance, i.e., \( \frac{1}{50} \) of the average annual salary

\[ \frac{5}{50} \times \$2000 = \$200 - \frac{15}{100} \times \$200 = \$170. \]

(b) A gratuity not exceeding one month's pay for each year of service.

14. A contributor with less than 10 years service who retires because of abolition of his position may select one of the two following options:

(a) A deferred adjusted annual retiring allowance, i.e., an allowance calculated as in paragraph 13(a) above but with the rights deferred until the age of 60 or until the person becomes permanently disabled so that he is incapable of pursuing a gainful occupation, whichever is earlier.

(b) A gratuity not exceeding one month's pay for each year of service.

15. A contributor who retires for any reason other than those above and other than misconduct (e.g., leaves to accept other employment) may select one of the two following options:

(a) A deferred adjusted annual retiring allowance, calculated in accordance with paragraph 14(a) above, or
(b) The payment in one sum of the total amount of his contributions, without interest.

16. A contributor who is dismissed for reasons of misconduct shall receive only the amount of his contributions, without interest.

17. The widow of a contributor who has served more than 10 years or who is in receipt of an annual retiring allowance may be paid an annual allowance until remarriage equal to ½ the superannuation allowance which might have been granted to the contributor if he had attained retirement age at the time of his death or retirement, as the case may be.

18. Each child of a contributor who has served more than 10 years and who dies while in the Civil Service or while in receipt of an annual superannuation allowance may be paid an annual allowance equal to 1/5 the amount of the allowance paid to the contributor's widow, up to a maximum of $500. If both parents are dead the allowance may be doubled up to a maximum of $600. In no case must the total amount of allowances granted to children of a contributor exceed the amount of the allowance granted to his widow, nor must the total allowances granted to both widow and children exceed ¾ of the annual superannuation allowance which might have been granted to the contributor if he had attained retirement age at the date of his death or retirement, as the case may be.

19. The widow and children of a contributor who has been awarded an adjusted annual retiring allowance or a deferred annual retiring allowance may be paid, forthwith, allowances calculated in the same way as those outlined in paragraphs 17 and 18 above.

20. The widow or children or both of a contributor who has served less than 10 years in the Civil Service and dies while in the Service may be granted allowances calculated on the basis that the contributor had been awarded a deferred annual adjusted retiring allowance, or a gratuity not exceeding one month's pay for each year of service.

21. When a contributor dies and the total amount of the allowances to which his widow and children are entitled is less than the total of his contributions without interest, a gratuity equal to the difference may be paid to his widow, children, or legal representative.

Dear Sir:

I visited Mr. Crookshank of the Canadian Teachers' Federation recently, and he told me of the work you are doing for the C.E.A. concerning teachers' salary scales and superannuation. You will therefore be interested in our procedure in regard to these two items:

(1) Teachers' Salary Scale.

This scale applies to all teachers in Indian day schools in all the nine provinces of Canada, the Northwest Territories and the Yukon.

We classify a Grade I teacher as one who does not hold a Provincial Teaching Certificate based on a full year at Normal School. Therefore, into this category fall teachers with Permits, Third Class Certificates, Model Certificates, etc. Their scale is from $1,220 to $1,320 an academic year.

A Grade II teacher is one holding a Second Class Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring high school junior matriculation plus teacher training at a recognized school). These salaries range from $1,440 to $1,920.

A Grade III teacher is one holding a First Class Teacher's Certificate (or equivalent requiring
high school senior matriculation or first year university plus teacher training at a recognized school).

Other details of our salary scale deal with high school teachers, welfare teachers and principals. I can provide you with a copy of the scale but it is under revision at the present time and we hope to have it completed within the next month or so. If this will be in sufficient time for you, I can then send you one.

I would ask you to particularly note that we require only a certificate granted by the Provincial Department of Education. In other words, we accept teachers in our Indian schools in British Columbia who have certificates from Manitoba, Ontario, Nova Scotia, etc.

(2) Superannuation.

After two years of satisfactory service in our Indian day schools, our teachers can apply to become eligible under the Civil Service Superannuation Act.

I have asked for additional copies of this Act and will send you one when they become available. In the meantime, I am sending you two memoranda dealing with recent revisions to this Act. I would ask you to particularly note the one dealing with "Pensionable Employment". This allows teachers who have been contributing to a provincial fund, to count the whole or part of such employment as service for the purposes of the Act, if he elects to make contributions in respect of such employment.

I intend to come to Toronto for the O.E.A. at Easter and would be pleased to present to you any other details concerning our salary scales and the superannuation plan. We now have a large number of schools and are naturally interested in having our system explained in your brief.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Barry,
Superintendent of Education.
